examples.en: ▶ {QaghHommeyHeylIjmo':n}

notes.en: This word takes the suffix {-Du':n:suff} when it refers to skin still on the body, and {-mey:n:suff} otherwise.[2]
When the context is clear, this is sometimes shortened to {DIr bID:n}.
This is the name of a specific skin disease from the time of Kahless.
This can refer to one pattern/design, or to a whole lot of them taken together.
This is a drum made with animal skin stretched over a cylinder, usually over only one end. If skin is stretched over both ends of a drum, it is an {'o'lav:n}.[1]
This is a type of {SuSDeq:n}.
For "years ago" and "years from now", see {ben:n:1} and {nem:n}, respectively.

DIS:v.hidden_notes: To "cave" (see {DIS:n:1}) is to give in to something under pressure. To "dish (out)" is slang for giving away information.

notes.en: There is no traditional Klingon way to say "Happy New Year", though a Klingon might understand {DIS chu' yItIv@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, yI-:v, tIv:v} or {DIS chu' DatIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, Da-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v} or {DIS chu' botIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, bo-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v}.
This is the name of a Federation starship.

This word is used to refer to "the Federation", a shortened form of "the United Federation of Planets" ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).

Coincidentally or not, this words sounds similar to {DI vI':n:nolink} "it accumulates debris".

DIvI':n.hidden_notes: The real reason {DIvI':n:nolink} and {DI vI':n:nolink} sound alike is because of the backfitting of {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}

DIvI' Se' wI'IjtaHvIS DaH ngoqDe' wIHevt.entry_name: DIvI' Se' wI'IjtaHvIS DaH ngoqDe' wIHevta'.

definition.en: We've just received an encoded message on the Federation frequency.
definition.de: Wir haben jetzt eine verschlüsselte Nachricht auf der Föderationsfrequenz empfangen.

notes.en: This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.
This can be used for "personality" in the sense of a quality or trait that forms a person's character.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {meHghem yoS botlh DI'on 'oH ghommeH yotlhvam'e':sen:nolink} "This plaza is a feature of the centre of the Cultural District."[3]
▶ {DI'ruj velqa' nIqHom:n@@DI'ruj velqa':n, nIqHom:n} "virtual reality software"

Do juvwI':n.hidden_notes: This term does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

notes.en: This is a {Qe':n} with a sign that says {moD Soj:sen:nolink}.[1, p.102]

Do QIn:n.hidden_notes: This is not canonical but is apparently widely known, after the model of {Do Qe':n}.

notes.en: This describes a rather un-Klingon way to behave.

definition.en: How much do you want for that?

definition.sv: mark, märke, punkt, komma, avskiljare (i koordinater)

notes.en: This refers to the separator used in specifying a set of coordinates, and not to a specific coordinate point or location (for which see {Quv:n}).

examples.en:
▶ {He wej pagh Soch DoD cha':sen:nolink} "course 3-0-7-mark-2"[2]
▶ {He pagh-pagh-pagh-DoD-cha' yInab!:sen}

notes.en: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur:sen@@Dogh:v, tIghla':n, rur:v}.[2, p.127]

Doghjey:n.hidden_notes: This consists of the words for "silly" and "defeat".

definition.en: back away from, back off, get away from
definition.de: sich von etw. entfernen, rückwärts gehen, weggehen
definition.sv: backa iväg från, rygga bort ifrån, ta sig bort ifrån

examples.en: ▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2]

notes.en: Based on the example of {qawmoH:v}, the subject of {DoHmoH:v:nolink} does the driving back, {-vaD:n} marks that which is driven back, and the object is the thing or location it is driven back from.

DoHmoH:v.hidden_notes: This is defined in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.

notes.en: This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally not say {Dojpu':n:nolink}.

definition.en: mass, masses, multitude, a very large but indeterminate group of something
definition.de: Massen, Mengen, eine große aber unbekannte Anzahl von Gegenständen oder Personen

notes.en: This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally not say {Dojpu':n:nolink}.

Dojmey:n.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.

examples.en:
▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people."
▶ {qoq De'wI' Dojmey:n}

Dol:n.hidden_notes: This is defined as "entity" in {TKD:src} and as "whole" in {TKW:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {wa' Dol nIvDaq matay'DI' maQap.:sen}

definition.sv: vara parallell, röra sig parallellt med

notes.en: To say that two or more things are parallel, this verb is used with a plural subject.[2]

Don:v.hidden_notes: The "go parallel to" definition suggests that this verb can be used transitively. However, the noun {HeDon} also suggests that {Don} acts like a verb of quality.

notes.en: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Dop:n:nolink} is used to indicate one face of a playing card.

examples.en:
▶ {DopDaq qul yIchenmoH QobDI' ghu'.:sen}[2]
▶ {'echletHom Dopvam yIcha':sen:nolink} "card must be turned this side up"[3]

notes.en: The construction {DopmoH:v@@Dop:v, -moH:v} is used for reversing a list.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {'u' Dop:n}

definition.en: Set fire on the side when there is danger.
definition.de: Stell das Feuer beiseite wenn Gefahr droht.

notes.en: This verb also covers colors which would be called "brown". To differentiate a brown object from another object which could also be described using {Doq:v:nolink}, a phrase such as {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen} is used.[2]

Doq:v.hidden_notes: All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v:nolink} and {SuD:v:1}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

notes.en: The expressions {Doq bIQtIq:sen:nolink} ("the river is red") and {Doq bIQtIq bIQ:sen:nolink} ("the river water is red") can be traced back to an old drinking song commemorating the slaying of {molor:n:name} by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.

definition.en: to be a particular shade of brown
definition.de: Doq und wie Kradsch-Lippen (ein bräunlicher Ton)

notes.en: A kradge has brown lips. This expression is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).
To be more specific about the shade of brown, a comparison is used. For example, one might say {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} (kradge lips are a particular shade of brown).[1]

definition.en: sink for cleaning hands, face, food, etc.
definition.de: Becken, Spüle, z.B. in Küche oder Bad

notes.en: A bathtub or swimming pool would be a {DoQmIv'a':n@@DoQmIv:n, -'a':n}. When needed, these can be distinguished using qualifiers: {Say'moHmeH DoQmIv'a':n}, {QalmeH DoQmIv'a':n}. A {DoQmIvHom:n@@DoQmIv:n, -Hom:n} would be a bucket or anything similar.

examples.en: ▶ {...-Daq qaDor.:sen} "I will escort you to ... ."

definition.sv: ta slut (om tidsperiod, t.ex. månad, år)

notes.en: The subject of this verb is a period or unit of time, such as a month. It should not be an event the ending of which one has some control over (for which see {van:v:2}, {ghang:v}).

examples.en: ▶ {tugh Dor qoSlIj. nom yIlop!@@tugh:adv, Dor:v:2, qoS:n, -lIj:n, nom:adv, yI-:v, lop:v}[2]

notes.en: This idiomatic expression, which literally means to lose or misplace a target, means "to digress". {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress", and so on.

definition.en: We have a target in sight.
definition.de: Wir haben ein Ziel in Sicht.

notes.en: This is generally crafted from bone.

Doy':v.hidden_notes: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means to "tire someone out".

definition.sv: vara tursam, vara lyckosam, ha tur, ha lycka

examples.en: ▶ {bach Do', qaH!:sen}

definition.sv: vara otursam, vara olycksdrabbad, ha otur

notes.en: This is essentially the verb {Do'Ha':v} as a standalone sentence.
This is the name of a planet which was disputed between the United Federation of Planets ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}) and the Klingon Empire ({tlhIngan wo':n}).
{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}:{SoH:n} = {Du-:v:pref,nolink}

The object is the thing which is improved.

This verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature, such as in status, skill, understanding, etc. For improvement in a more concrete sense, see {rach:v}.[2]

definition.en: If it's in your way, knock it down.
definition.de: Wenn dir etwas im Wege steht, schlag es nieder.

Dugh:v.hidden_notes: As a joke, this is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {yIntaHvIS qIrq DuHbe' roj.:sen:nolink} "There will be no peace as long as Kirk lives." ({Star Trek V:src} notes, not actually in the film)

notes.en: This can be used for a "setting" in a {SeHlaw:n}.[2]
This is a type of {jem'IH:n}. This word can be used if the emphasis is to be on the elegance or grandeur of the building.

DuHmor:n.hidden_notes: The Palatine Hill is one of the hills of Rome ({rom HuD:sen:nolink}).

notes.en:
This word can refer to any vehicle, not just spaceships, by specifying the environment in which the vehicle travels. See {puH Duj:n}, {muD Duj:n}, {bIQ Duj:n}.

Some special terminology is used for the parts of a {Duj:n:1h,nolink}. The section towards its {tlhop:n:1h} is called its {'et:n:2h}, while the section towards its {'em:n} is called its {'o':n}. To refer to a ship's dorsal, ventral, port, and starboard areas, see {Dung:n}, {bIng:n}, {poS:n}, and {nIH:n}, respectively.

For verbs related to ship movement, see under {'or:v}.

Known classes of Klingon ships include {neghvar:n}, {vorcha':n}, {qItI'nga':n}, {qISa'ruj:n}, and {toQDuj:n}.
It is grammatically correct to treat this word as singular (a bundle of instincts) or plural (individual instincts).[2, p.27]

DujDaj HubtaHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIn.entry_name: DujDaj HubtaHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.

definition.en: To die defending his ship is the hope of every Klingon.
definition.de: Es ist die Hoffnung jedes Klingon zu sterben während er sein Schiff verteidigt.

definition.en: There is nothing shameful in falling before a superior enemy.
definition.de: Es ist nicht schmachvoll vor einem überlegenen Feind zu verlieren.

notes.en: This expression means "be experienced".

examples.en: ▶ {Dujmey law' DachIjpu':sen:nolink} "You have navigated many ships", i.e., "You are experienced".

notes.en: This refers to the geometric figure, and not to an astronomical body, for which see {Hov:n}.

DujtlhuQ:n.hidden_notes:
This seems to be made up of the words {Duj:n:1} and {tlhuQ:n}.

The logo of Star Alliance, the largest airline alliance on Earth, is often painted on the tailfins of its members' airplanes.

examples.en:
▶ {ta'mey Dun, bommey Dun.:sen}
▶ {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen}

notes.en: See {'aqroS:n:1} and {yor:n} for the top parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

Dup:n.hidden_notes: This is a way to "dupe" your enemies.

notes.en: This is a bowl used for eating {chatlh:n:1}, which a diner pours into the {Duq:n:nolink} from a {maHpIn:n}.[1, p.99]

Duq:n.hidden_notes: Norm Duke is the name of a successful American professional bowler. Also, "duckpin bowling" is a variation of "ten-pin bowling" using a smaller ball.

notes.en: This means in the sense of astonished, astounded, dumbfounded, shocked. It is stronger than {yay':v}
notes.de: Dies ist im sinne von erstaunt, umgeworfen, schockiert. Es ist stärker als {yay':v}

examples.en: ▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

notes.en: This is said of good music or food.

This is used to refer to the spikes attached to {pogh:n}, {ghanjaq:n}, {'alngegh:n}, and so on.

For a stand-alone spike such as a stake, see {wIl:n}.
This is used to refer to the little spikes found on the {Daqtagh:n}.[1, p.61]

Duran lung:n.hidden_notes: This term was not defined independently, but is inferred from {Duran lung DIr:n:nolink}.

definition.sv: Duraniska ödleskinn (en slags mat, tar aldrig pluralsuffix)

notes.en: This is a food item. It never uses any plural suffix.
Brother of Lursa and B'Etor.

This is used for launching a {peng:n}.

The distinction between a {DuS:n:nolink} and a {chetvI':n:1} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]
This is the most general word for a place of learning.[1]

DuSaQ:n.hidden_notes: It's probably just a coincidence that this word looks like it's formed from {Du-:v} and {SaQ:v}.

Dut:v.hidden_notes: There is a Seinfeld skit about how one can't slam down a mobile phone, but must swipe or press a button.

examples.en: ▶ {toqwIn vIDut@@toqwIn:n, vI-:v, Dut:v} "I slam down the stamp."

notes.en: Do not confuse with {Duy':n}.
Do not confuse with {Duy:n}.
This refers to fruits or vegetables that come from a farm, as opposed to {naH tlhab:n}.[1, p.89]

Du'IHchoHmoH mIvvam.:sen.hidden_notes: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extra space right after {mIv:n:1}.

notes.en: This may have bones. In some regional dialects, {ghab:n:nolink} is not applied to meat lacking bones, but rather, {ghab tun:n} is used instead.

definition.en: meat from midsection of animal, no bones
definition.de: Fleisch vom Rumpf des Tieres, ohne Knochen
definition.sv: kött från mittdelen av djur, utan ben

notes.en: In the standard dialect, this would be expressed using the phrase {Hom Hutlhbogh ghab@@Hom:n:1, Hutlh:v, -bogh:v, ghab:n}.

definition.en: lurk, lie in wait, lie low

notes.en: This means that the subject is hidden but posing a threat, such as being ready to ambush.

ghach:v.hidden_notes: The first half of the example sentence was a lip-match for {ghaH vISammeH}.

examples.en: ▶ {ghach jIvvo' naH. DaH pIghvamDaq So''eghtaH.@@ghach:v, jIvvo':n, naH:v, DaH:adv, pIgh:n, -vam:n, -Daq:n, So':v, -'egh:v, -taH:v} "There is a criminal hiding in these ruins."

ghagh:v.hidden_notes: This is the sound made when gargling.

notes.en: This literally means "he/she wants the wind to respect him/her".

examples.en:
▶ {muvuvpu' SuS vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I acted like a fool."
▶ {bImaw''a'? Duvuv SuS DaneH'a'?:sen:nolink} "What's with you? Are you an idiot?"

notes.en: This word can be used both to indicate ownership over an object (see {yer ghajwI' chaw':n}) and possession of a more abstract nature (see {pIch:n} and {quv:n}).

examples.en:
▶ {pIch vIghajbe'.:sen} "It's not my fault."[1]
▶ {Hov ghajbe'bogh ram rur pegh ghajbe'bogh jaj.:sen}[2]
▶ {quv lughaj 'archer HoD beqDaj je.:sen}[3]
▶ {Duj ghajchugh pagh, beylI'vo' 'oH Daje' net chaw'.:sen:nolink} "If (the ship is) unowned, you may buy it from the Bank."[4]

notes.en: Jealousy is also expressed by the idiom {SuD veqlargh mInDu'.:sen}

ghal:v.hidden_notes: The word {ghal:v:nolink} was mistakenly used as a noun meaning "envoy" in the Dramatis Personae on {paq'batlh p.40-41:src}.

notes.en: This is the animal version of {ghIv:n}.

gham:n.hidden_notes: There is a slang word "gam" in English which means "leg".

notes.en: This refers to something one copies or refers to in making things.

definition.en: end prematurely (an event, voyage, battle, play, opera, story, song, etc.)
definition.de: vorzeitig beenden (ein Ereignis, Reise, Schlacht, Schauspiel, Oper, Geschichte, Lied, usw.)
definition.sv: avsluta i förtid (en händelse, t.ex. resa, strid, sång)

notes.en: The subject of this verb is the person causing an event to prematurely end. The object is the event that is ended. If the ending of the event was not premature, use {van:v:2} instead. To describe the ending of a period of time, use {Dor:v:2} instead.

ghang:v.hidden_notes: Quite often, the hitting of a "gong" brings an event to a premature end.

examples.en: ▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[2]

notes.en: This follows the final noun.

ghaptal:n.hidden_notes: The equator is at "lat"itude zero ({pagh:n:2}). Also, the transit token for the Capital Transit Company has a circular shape with the word "Capital" written across the equator.

notes.en: This word is also used for "support" in the monetary sense.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {potlhqu' Huch Daghaqbogh:sen:nolink} "money that you contribute is very important"[3]

ghaq:v.source: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2010.07.26:src}, [3] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.
The name of a Klingon Chancellor. He is portrayed by the actor {rabe'rIt 'o'raylIy:n:name}.
This word is avoided in {voSpegh Sep:n}, where {'IghvaH chej chatlh:n} is used instead.

definition.en: insecure one, one full of self-doubt
definition.sv: osäker person, någon uppfylld av självtvivel, självtvivlare

notes.en: This is a dialectical word used in {voSpegh Sep:n}.

definition.sv: spraya, spruta, bombardera, fälla, regna ner

ghay:v.hidden_notes: An English definition has never been given for this word. Its meaning is inferred from the examples of its usage.

examples.en:
▶ {bIQ ghaywI' pa':n}
▶ {jorwI'mey ghaymo' qarDaSnganpu', Hegh SuvwI'pu'lI' law' 'ej rIQ SuvwI'pu'lI' law'.:sen:nolink} "Suffer major losses after Cardassian bombing campaign."[2]

ghaytanHa':adv.source: [1] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}

notes.en: This is a condiment which is often used to bring out the flavor in {qagh:n} or {raHta':n}.

gheb:n.hidden_notes: {gheb rIl:sen:nolink} is a reference to the horn of Gabriel.

notes.en:
This verb is used to ask a question, whereas {tlhob:v} is used for making a request.[2]

The object of this verb is the question asked.

This verb expresses the idea of bringing thoughts together into a reasonably coherent form so that they can be expressed to someone else. It differs from {qon:v} in that {gher:v:nolink} suggests that information is merely being passed along.[1]

definition.en: assume duties of, take on responsibilities of
definition.sv: anta plikter ifrån, ta på sig ansvar ifrån

examples.en:
▶ {DaH yaS wa'DIch vIgheS} "I now take my place as first officer", or literally, "Now I assume the responsibilities of first officer"[1, p.182]
▶ {juDev 'ej Dujvam ra'wI' DagheS 'e' vItlhob} "I ask you to lead us as commander of this ship", or literally, "I request that you lead us and that you assume the duties of commander of this ship"[1, p.184]

notes.en: No deception is implied by the use of this word. It simply indicates role-playing.

definition.sv: någon som låtsas, person som låtsas

notes.en: No deception is implied by the use of this word. It simply indicates role-playing.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {ghetwI' luwIvlu'ta'.:sen}[2]

notes.en: This is the name of a warrior who singlehandedly defeated an invading force.

ghevchoq:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

notes.en: This region contains the city of {ruq'e'vet:n}. It is named after {ghevchoq:n:name}.

ghevchoq Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

notes.en: There is an idiom, {jeD; ghevI' rur}.

ghew:n.hidden_notes: In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", cricket (the sport) is translated as {ghew:n:nolink}. Specifically, "Cricket, please." was translated as {DaH ghew yIQuj.:sen:nolink}[3]

examples.en: ▶ {ghewmey tISuqQo'.:sen}

ghew:n.source: [1] {TKDA:src}, [2] {PK:src}, [3] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}

definition.en: be transformed, transmuted, metamorphosed, totally altered

ghe':v.hidden_notes: Gregor Samsa is the main character of the Franz Kafka novella "The Metamorphosis".

examples.en: ▶ {maS Daghe'moH'a'?:sen:nolink} "Are you terraforming a moon?"

notes.en: This is a short way to refer to an energy field of some sort that causes terraforming to happen. A longer way to refer to this concept would be {ghe'moHbogh HoSchem:n@@ghe':v, -moH:v, -bogh:v, HoSchem:n}.
An example of Klingon opera is "Aktu and Mellota" (see {'aqtu':n:name} and {mellota':n:name}).
This is a {ghe'naQ:n} following the traditional form preferred by purists.

definition.en: Gre'thor, netherworld (where spirits of dishonored go)
definition.de: Gre'thor, Unterwelt (wohin die Seelen der Entehrten gehen)

notes.en: This is also written {ghe''or:n:place,nolink}.

ghe'tor:n.hidden_notes: It is written {ghe''or:n:place,nolink} in {TKDA:src} and pronounced that way in {PK:src}, but is consistently written {ghe'tor:n:place,nolink} in later sources.

notes.en: This is similar to the Terran expression "when pigs fly".

examples.en: ▶ {jIjegh ghe'torvo' narghDI' qa'pu'.:sen:nolink} "I will surrender when spirits escape from Gre'thor." (That is, "I will never surrender.")

definition.en: You belong in a black hole in the netherworld!
definition.de: Du gehörst in ein schwarzes Loch in der Unterwelt!

notes.en:
There is an idiom, {boch; ghIch rur}.[2, p.133]

There is also a regional word {ley':n} which means "nose".

examples.en: ▶ {ghIchwIj DabochmoHchugh ghIchlIj qanob.:sen}

definition.en: If you shine my nose, I will give you your nose.
definition.de: Wenn du meine Nase polierst gebe ich dir deine Nase.

notes.en: This idiom is used to mean "Do not try to mislead me if you value your life."

definition.sv: vara slarvig, vara sjabbig, vara rörig, vara kladdig

examples.en: ▶ {Ha'DIbaH ghIH tIr ngogh je:n}

notes.en: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used in addition to {yepHa':v}.

examples.en: ▶ {vay' DaghIjlaHchugh bIHoSghaj.:sen}

definition.en: May your enemies run with fear.
definition.de: Mögen deine Feinde mit Schrecken davonrennen

notes.en: This sentence is archaic. It is ungrammatical in modern standard Klingon.
This is a small, irritating insect with no sting, which makes a slight buzzing sound. There is a Klingon idiom, {ram; ghIlab ghew rur@@ram:v, ghIlab ghew:n, rur:v}.

examples.en:
▶ {bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.:sen}
▶ {ghIlab ghewmey tIbuSQo'.:sen}

definition.en: Pay no heed to glob flies.

notes.en: This verb can be used with {turmIq:n}, {qeQ:n}, and {taQbang:n:2}.[2]
This refers to a device which dissipates heat.

ghImwI':n.hidden_notes: Some people believe this to be a mistake for {tlhuchwI':n:nolink} (see {tlhuch:v}). However, {tuj ghImwI':n} actually makes sense for a mechanism that dissipates heat.

notes.en: This refers to a building or group of buildings, including any accompanying grounds such as gardens. It does not refer to the group of people who live, work, or study there.

ghIn:n.hidden_notes: Plymouth Gin is produced by The Black Friars Distillery, formerly a Dominican monastery in Plymouth, England.
ghIn:n.source: [1] {Letter from MO 2010.11.15:src} ({KLI mailing list 2010.12.25:src}), [2] {Letter from MO 2011.01.07:src} ({KLI mailing list 2011.01.16:src})

notes.en: {lojmItjaj:n:nolink} tends to be used on formal occasions, while both it and {ghInjaj:n:nolink} are used, seemingly indiscriminately, otherwise.

ghInjaj:n.hidden_notes: This refers to a line in "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!" by The Beetles, which partly goes "on Saturday at Bishopsgate".

notes.en: Note that this is a verb, not a noun.

definition.sv: därefter, och sedan, efter det, efteråt

notes.en: Note that "then" in the sense of "at that time" is {ngugh:adv}.[2]

ghIqtal:excl.hidden_notes: In Semitic languages, the triconsonantal root "q-t-l" is related to killing.

definition.sv: stiga nedför, fara ned, komma ned, slutta nedåt

notes.en: This word is not used for sort order.[3]

ghIr:v.hidden_notes: When descending, you need to drop your landing "gear".

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This might be used to describe a good bowl of {qagh:n}.
notes.de: Damit könnte man gut einen Teller voller {qagh:n} beschreiben.

notes.en: This is a small animal, apparently not a very vicious one, though one with perhaps a predilection for trying to sound fiercer than it actually is.
There is an idiom, {yuDHa'; ghIt rur@@yuDHa':v, ghIt:n:0, rur:v}.[1, p.131]
There is an idiom, {yuDHa'; ghIt rur@@yuDHa':v, ghIt:n:0, rur:v}.[1, p.131]

ghItlh:n.hidden_notes: The word {ghItlhHom:n:nolink} was used for the "string" variable type in Klingon Blockly.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {ghItlh vIghItlhta'bogh DalaD'a'?:sen:nolink} "Will you read my manuscript?"[1, p.172]

definition.sv: skriva, gravera, rista in, skära in, märka

notes.en: This verb is used to indicate the making of markings on a surface. It applies not just to writing, but to any kind of marking. To "write" in this sense refers to the physical act of writing, and not to the creation of compositions, for which {qon:v} is used instead.[2; 3] Another verb, {gher:v}, is used for the compilation of lists and the like.[4]

ghItlh:v.hidden_notes: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "write". In {KGT:src}, it was clarified that this meant "engrave, incise, mark (upon)", that is, the phyiscal act of making marks on a surface.

examples.en: ▶ {ghItlh vIghItlhta'bogh DalaD'a'?:sen:nolink} "Will you read my manuscript?"[1, p.172]

ghItlhjaj:n.hidden_notes: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Wednesday morning papers didn't come."

definition.sv: stylus, skriftverktyg, penna, person som skriver

notes.en:
This word is used for any writing implement as well as for any person who writes.[1]

In {TNK:src}, {ghItlhwI':n:nolink} is used for "pen" and {ghojmeH ghItlhwI':n:nolink} is used for "pencil".[2]

ghItlhwI':n.hidden_notes: The instrument/agent confusion is similar to that for the English word "printer", which can refer either to a device or to a person.

notes.en: This is the person equivalent of {gham:n}.
There is an idiom, {wov; ghI'boj Sech rur}.

{SoH:n}:{maH:n:1h} = {gho-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
{tlhIH:n}:{maH:n:1h} = {gho-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)

There is an idiom, {vIHtaH gho:sen}.

There are 243 {lawmey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n:nolink}, or 360 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink}. (See {law:n} and {lawrI':n}.)

examples.en: ▶ {meyrI'Daq 'oHtaH gho'e':sen:nolink} "The circle is in the square."[3]

notes.en: This refers not to a bound notebook, but rather to a ringer binder that one can add papers to and take them out of.
This word refers to the geometric figure.
This word refers to the geometric figure.
It is probably significant that this word is homophonous with the verb for doing battle or waging war ({ghob:v}).[3]

examples.en: ▶ {ghob tIvnISbe'lu'.:sen}

definition.en: fight, battle, do battle, wage war

notes.en:
This verb refers to a concrete fight. For the concept of making war, see {Qoj:v}.

It is probably significant that this word is homophonous with the word for ethics or virtue ({ghob:n}).[2]

In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {ghobchuq loDnI'pu':n}

notes.en: This is the name of a famous statue showing {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} and {moratlh:n:name} locked in struggle.

This is the negative answer to a yes/no question (see {-'a':v}). Unlike the English word "no", it is not used as a stand-alone exclamation indicating refusal, disbelief, and so on (for which see {Qo':excl}).

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/7_rXiSTQmAE}
{qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} prophesied he would return there.
This is used for putting things inside a backpack or a pillow bag, but not stopping up an opening, which would be {qorgh:v}.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {Ho'Du'lIjDaq to'baj 'uSHom lughoDlu'bogh tu'lu'.:sen}
▶ {to'baj 'uS lughoDlu'bogh tIlaj.:sen}

notes.en: See under {QIch wab Ho'DoS:n} for the names of the Klingon consonants and vowels.

ghogh HablI':n.hidden_notes: Some people have taken to referring to mobile phones using {ghogh HablI' qenglu'bogh:n:nolink}. Context should make it clear if {ghogh HablI':n:nolink} refers to a mobile device.

notes.en: The idiom {jop 'ej way':sen:idiom} expresses a similar idea.[2]
This is a lesson as in a textbook, and not in the sense of "Let this be a lesson to you!", which is {ghuH:n}. It can also be used to express "tutorial about X", as {X ghojmeH mIw:n:nolink}.
See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

examples.en: ▶ {ghojwI'pu' chu' ghojmoH jatlhwI'pu' po'qu'.:sen@@ghojwI':n, -pu':n, chu':v:1, ghojmoH:v, jatlh:v, -wI':v, -pu':v, po':v, -qu':v}[2]

notes.en: A teacher held in high esteem, of higher rank than other teachers in the same institution, could be {ghojmoHwI' quv@@ghojmoHwI':n, quv:v} or {ghojmoHwI' Han@@ghojmoHwI':n, Han:v}. Probably the highest standing of all is a {'a'ghen:n:nolink}.[2]

ghojmoq:n.hidden_notes: This seems to be composed of {ghoj:v} and {moq:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {ngIq gholvo' wa'maH QaS yItlhap.:sen:nolink} "Collect 10 forces from every player."[2]

notes.en: This verb can be used with or without an object. If there is an object, then the subject is meeting the object. If there is no object, then the subjects are assembling or meeting each other.[2]

ghomHa':v.hidden_notes: In {DS9 - Sons and Daughters:src}, Worf dismisses a group of crewmen with {yIghomHa'!:sen:nolink} Since he was addressing multiple people, it should have been {peghomHa'!:sen:nolink}

notes.en: This refers to the duty roster on a Klingon ship.
The parts of a hand include its {toch:n} "palm", {chap:n} "back (of hand)", and {nItlh:n} "finger(s)" (including the thumb). The hand is attached to the {DeS:n:1} "arm" through the {yeb:n} "wrist".

ghop:n.hidden_notes: Something you "grope" with. The reverse of this is {pogh:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {ghopDu'wIjDaq yInmeyraj vIlaj} "I accept your lives into my hands"[2]

ghoq:v.hidden_notes: This is defined as "spy" in {TKD:src} and as "spy on" in {KGT:src}.

notes.en: This is also applied to words (see {mu'mey ghoQ:n}).
This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

examples.en:
▶ {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom}
▶ {pIpyuS yIghor!:sen}

definition.en: When will the water be hot?

notes.en: This is a creature also referred to as a "space whale". This is a loanword from another language.

ghormaghenDer:n.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Magic to Make the Sanest Man Go Mad:src}

notes.en: Chancellor Gorkon ({ghorqan Qang:n:nolink}) was a character in {Star Trek VI:src}. One of his legendary forebearers was also named "Gorkon", but the name was pronounced {ghorqon:n:name} during his time.
The reference in {Hamlet:src} is not to the Chancellor ({ghorqan:n:name}) who sought peace with the Federation, but to one of his legendary ancestors.[2]

definition.en: approach, go away from, proceed, come, follow (a course)
definition.sv: fortsätta framåt, nalkas, komma närmare, avlägsna sig ifrån

notes.en: This can mean either "approach" or "go away from" depending on the presence of nouns with the suffixes {-Daq:n} and {-vo':n}. The way to use {ghoS:v:nolink} and other verbs of movement are described in {HQ 7.4:src}[2]. See {jaH:v} for details.

examples.en:
▶ {bIghHa'Daq yIghoS:sen:nolink} "Go to jail"[1, p.170]
▶ {He chu' ghoS, DIvI' neHmaH.:sen}

notes.en: A single personnel file would presumably be a {ghot ta:n:nolink}.

definition.en: fish, most general word for fish-like creature

notes.en: Every {ghotI':n:nolink} is a {bIQDep:n}, but not every {bIQDep:n:nolink} is a {ghotI':n:nolink}.[3]

ghotI':n.hidden_notes: This is based on a joke English spelling for "fish".

gho'Do:n.hidden_notes: Someone going at sublight speed really needs to "step on" it.

notes.en:
This is a kind of skin blemish or inflammation affecting Klingons underdoing puberty.[1; 2]

This word is alien in origin. The reason Klingons use an alien word for this is to put some distance between themselves and something considered embarrassing.[3]

gho'rIch:n.source: [1] {Star Trek Insurrection:src}, [2] {How to Speak Klingon, p.7:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2013.07.29:src}

notes.en: This word refers to an infant, and should not be used in addressing an adult (unless the intention is to insult). Unlike in Federation Standard, calling someone "baby" in Klingon is not a sign of affection.

ghu:n.hidden_notes: This is probably the sound a Klingon baby makes. Also, "goo".

notes.en: This refers to the flower, fruit, or shoot before it develops.
This refers to sound emitted by an animal, but not speech.
notes.de: Dies wird nur bei Tiergeräuschen verwendet, nicht bei Sprache.

notes.en: This can also mean "lesson" in the sense of "Let this be a lesson to you!"[2]
See also the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v} for indicating preparation or readiness.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan quv DatIchDI' Seng yIghuH.:sen}
▶ {may' yIghuH!:sen:nolink} "Battle Alert!"[2]

notes.en: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

examples.en: {ropyaH yIghuHmoH!:sen}

ghun:v:2.hidden_notes: The example makes clear that this word refers to temperature, and not to perception, emotion, or character.

examples.en: ▶ {ghun 'Iw HIq, rap boqrat chej.} "The bokrat liver is as warm as the bloodwine."[1]

notes.en: There is an idiom {ghung; qagh rur}.

ghur:v.hidden_notes:
The word {ghurmoH} appears on {SkyBox 14:src} (see {nISwI' beH:n}).[2]

MO confirmed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {ghur:v:nolink} is intransitive.

examples.en: ▶ {jaghpu'ra' bopujmoHtaHvIS, ghur tuqmeyraj quv.} "Honor will rise in your houses as you bring your enemies to their knees."[3]

notes.en:
The object of this verb is the thing to be launched, usually torpedoes. If the object is not specified either explicitly or by context, it is assumed to be torpedoes. Besides torpedoes, this verb can be used for rockets, missiles, energy beams, or anything else which goes from one point to another. It is also used to describe the action of pulling back the elastic band of a slingshot, or the lowering of a spear to a horizontal position to attack (see {ghuS:v:2}). This verb never takes the suffix {-rup:v}. ({TKD 4.2.2:src})

See also the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v} for indicating preparation or readiness.

examples.en: ▶ {cha yIghuS!:sen}[2]

definition.de: den Speer zum Angriff horizontal senken
definition.sv: sänka (spjut) till horisontellt läge inför attack

notes.en: This verb can be used to describe the readying of any kind of projectile weapon, such as pulling back the elastic band of a slingshot. On a starship, it's used almost exclusively to refer to torpedoes (see {ghuS:v:1}).[1, p.64]
This refers to predicting based on one's feelings or just a wild guess.
notes.de: Wird verwendet für Vorhersagen aus dem Bauch heraus, oder durch Raten.

ghut:v.hidden_notes: The term "gut feeling" refers to one's intuition.

notes.en: She is the actress who plays {be'etor:n:name}.

examples.en: {ghuy' po'qu'!:sen}
▶ {ghu' Dachupbogh vIlaj.:sen}

definition.en: You don't seem to understand our situation.
definition.de: Sie verstehen anscheinend die Situation nicht.

notes.en: Spoken by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} to {qotar:n:name} in the {paq'batlh:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {Hab SoSlI' Quch!:sen}

definition.en: Your mother has a smooth forehead!
definition.de: Deine Mutter hat eine glatte Stirn!

notes.en: This is a classic insult.
notes.de: Dies ist eine schwere Beleidigung.

notes.en: This is a command given to a data transceiving device ({HablI':n}).

HablI', Su' labbeH.:sen.hidden_notes: The subtitle says "Ready to transmit", which was the original English line spoken by the actress playing Valkris. However, the Klingon is phrased as a command, so "Prepare to transmit" is a better translation.

definition.sv: vara utvecklad, vara högtstående (om t.ex. civilisation)

examples.en:
▶ {Hagh qoHpu' neH HeghtaHvIS SuvwI'pu'.:sen}
▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

definition.en: Only fools laugh while warriors die.
definition.de: Nur Narren lachen während Krieger sterben.

notes.en:
The object is the thing being soaked or drenched.

{HaH'egh:v@@HaH:v:1, -'egh:v} is used to refer to drinking a great deal, or bathing.
This word is used by upper-class speakers for {gham:n} served as food.
notes.de: Dieses Wort wird durch die Oberklasse verwendet, wenn {gham:n} als Nahrung serviert wird.

notes.en: This is the name of a famous play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of its eponymous protagonist.
notes.de: Dies ist der Name eines bekannten Stücks von {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, als auch dessen Hauptfigur.

notes.en: This refers to a biological unit.
This word has a negative connotation in Klingon culture.[1]
This word has a negative connotation in Klingon culture.[1]
This is a doctor (see {Qel:n:1h}) who performs surgery (see {Haq:v:1}).[2]
notes.de: Dies ist ein Arzt (siehe {Qel:n:1h}) der operiert (siehe {Haq:v:1}).[2]

notes.en: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v:nolink}.

Har'ey:n.hidden_notes: "Over the Rainbow" was composed by Harold Arlen and its lyrics were written by E.Y. Harburg.

notes.en: Note that {jIH:n:2} refers to the device, while {HaSta:n:nolink} refers to the visual information displayed on it. Also contrast this with {wIy:n}, which can also be displayed on a {jIH:n:2}.

Hat:v.hidden_notes: In slang, stolen goods are said to be "hot".

definition.sv: fly från, ta sig ur, smita ifrån

examples.en: ▶ {may'meyDajvo' Haw'be' tlhIngan.:sen}

notes.en: To challenge someone to a duel, say {qablIj HI'ang:sen:nolink}. To accept such a challenge, say {vISo'be':sen:nolink}.[2, p.68]

To answer in the affirmative, say {luq:excl} "okay".

To answer in the negative, say {Qo':excl} "no, I refuse".

examples.en:
▶ {Ha', pa'lIj wIjaH!:sen:nolink} "Come, let's go to your quarters!"
▶ {Ha', tach wIjaH!:sen:nolink} "Come, let's go to a bar!"
▶ {Ha', vaS'a' wIjaH!:sen:nolink} "Come, let's go to the Great Hall."

notes.en: For different ways in which meat may be prepared, see {wamwI' Ha'DIbaH:n}, {voDleH Ha'DIbaH:n}, and {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n}.

definition.en: Do not kill an animal unless you intend to eat it.
definition.de: Töte kein Tier, wenn du nicht vorhast, es zu essen.

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food.
This refers to the little piece of metal that holds sheets of paper together.

The object of {vev:v} is {Ha'on:n}. The papers stapled together are the object of {rar:v}.

To use such a device, one may {qIp:v}, {'uy:v}, or {ngaH:v} it, depending on the particular device.
In ancient times, this supported a sword. Now it is symbolic of one's {tuq:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

notes.en: The expression {Ha'qujlIj nge':sen:nolink} "take away your sash" means "wound your pride".

This word can only refer to a physical path, and not to a spiritual or metaphorical path. "The Klingon Way", for example, is {tlhIngan tIgh:n:nolink}.

A physical path would be a {taw:n}.
Here, "her" refers to the Enterprise ({'entepray':n:name}).

Hevetlh wIghoSchugh, veH tIn wI'el maH'e.entry_name: Hevetlh wIghoSchugh, veH tIn wI'el maH'e'.

definition.en: That course will take us into the Barrier as well.
definition.de: Wenn wir jenem Kurs folgen, überschreiten wir die große Grenze.
Neuer Kurs in die Neutrale Zone setzen.
Plan den Kurs, null-null-null, mark zwei.

examples.en:
▶ {Ha'DIbaH DaSop 'e' DaHechbe'chugh yIHoHQo'.:sen}
▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}

definition.en: retreat perfectly, make a full withdrawal

notes.en: The fact that {yIn:v} can be used transitively suggests that {Hegh:v:nolink} can be too.

examples.en: ▶ {bogh tlhInganpu', SuvwI'pu' moj, Hegh.:sen}
▶ {Hegh Duj DatIj 'ej ghe'torDaq Duqeng.:sen:nolink} "Barge of the Dead ferries you to Gre'thor!"

definition.en: A fool's only achievement is death.
definition.de: Das einzige, was ein Narr erreicht, ist der Tod.

notes.en: This may also be written as {Heghba':n:nolink}.

Heghbat:n.hidden_notes: It is written {Heghba':n:nolink} in the novel "Sarek".

definition.en: When a warrior dies, his spirit escapes.
definition.de: Wenn ein Krieger stirbt, entflieht sein Geist.

notes.en: The verb {nargh:v:2} means "escape", but it (or a phonetically identical word) also means "appear" (see {nargh:v:1}).

definition.en: Death is an experience best shared.
definition.de: Der Tod ist eine Erfahrung, die man am besten teilt.

definition.en: It is a good day to die.
definition.de: Heute ist ein guter Tag zum Sterben.

HeghmoH:v.hidden_notes: The definition in {TKD:src} only says "be fatal", but it's clear that the verb takes an object since it is formed using {-moH:v}.

notes.en: In {TNK:src}, {bIQ'a' HeH:n} is used to translate "beach". In the {paq'batlh:src}, {ngeng HeH:n} is used to translate "lakeshore".
notes.de: In {TNK:src} wird {bIQ'a' HeH:n} für "Strand" verwendet. Im {paq'batlh:src} wird {ngeng HeH:n} für "Seeufer" verwendet.

notes.en: This is an admirable trait and does not carry connotations of arrogance, for which see {nguq:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}

definition.en: Klingons are a proud race, and we intend to go on being proud.
definition.de: Klingonen sind eine stolze Rasse, und wir haben vor weiterhin stolz zu sein.

notes.en: This is the name of a character from a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of the play itself.

definition.en: finger (holes, strings of instrument) to vary sound
definition.de: mit den Fingern die Luftlöcher öffnen und schließen (spielen eines Blasinstrumentes)
definition.sv: fingra på (hål, strängar på instrument) för att variera ljud

notes.en:
This word is applied to {SuSDeq:n} and {HurDagh:n}.

See under {nItlh:n} for the verbs associated with each of the fingers.

Heq:v.hidden_notes: This was defined as "hail" among other weather words. The "weather" clarification was added to distinguish it from the communication sense of "hail" ({rI':v}).

examples.en: ▶ {nuch Hergh:n}
▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

notes.en: This is also shortened to {HerghwI':n:nolink}.
notes.de: Man kann dies auch als {HerghwI':n:nolink} abkürzen.

HeSwI':n.hidden_notes: R. Hess was a famous war criminal.

examples.en: ▶ {yo'SeH yaHnIvvo' potlh De' wIHevtaH.:sen}

notes.en: There is an idiom, {tam; Hew rur}.
notes.de: Es gibt die Redewendung {tam; Hew rur}.

definition.en: battle or fight against one's own group

notes.en: This verb indicates fighting against one's own group, and not the supposed enemy.
notes.de: Dies bedeutet seine eigene Leute bekämpfen, anstatt den Feind.

Hey:v.hidden_notes: This may have been a back-fit for a mispronunciation of {Hegh:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {toH, Hey Humanpu'.}

notes.en: The components of an atom may include {yomIj:n}, {valtIn:n}, and {tem:n}.
notes.de: Einzelteile eines Atoms sind {yomIj:n}, {valtIn:n}, und {tem:n}

HeySel:n.hidden_notes: The Atomium is a famous building in Heysel, Brussels.

notes.en: This word refers to the emission of odor. It does not have the idiomatic sense of "be very bad" as the word "stink" does in English.

{SoH:n}:{jIH:n:1h} = {HI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
{tlhIH:n}:{jIH:n:1h} = {HI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)

HIchop!:sen.hidden_notes: This song is a translation of "Kiss Me" by the band Sixpence None the Richer.

notes.en:
This literally means "Come towards me!"

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/Wq5mvIWRSKc}
notes.de:
Wörtlich bedeutet dies "Komm zu mir!"

Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/Wq5mvIWRSKc}

HIj:v.hidden_notes: {HIj:v:nolink} is used for transporting goods, whereas it seems that {lup:v} is used for transporting people.

examples.en: ▶ {yIHmey DaHIj'a'?  ghobe', yIHmey vIHIjbe'.} "Are you transporting tribbles?  No. I'm not transporting tribbles."[2]

notes.en:
This is the positive answer to a yes/no question (see {-'a':v}). Unlike the English word "yes", it is not used as a stand-alone exclamation indicating insight, joy, and so on (for which see {toH:excl} and {Qapla'!:sen}). For an exclamation indicating compliance, such as in response to a command, see {lu':excl}.

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/KArQlviVXMk}

HIja':excl.hidden_notes: Looks like a combination of the Japanese and German affirmative answers ("hai" and "ja").

notes.en: This refers to the clothing worn in battle.
notes.de: Bezeichnet die Kleidung, die im Kampf getragen wird.

HIp:n.hidden_notes: In English slang, "hip" means fashionable in the context of clothing.

notes.en: Types of {HIq:n} include {baqghol:n}, {chechtlhutlh:n}, and {wornagh:n}.

definition.en: To find ale, go into a bar.
definition.de: Um Bier zu finden, musst du in die Kneipe gehen.

notes.en: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.
This is known as a tourist drink.
This is a variant of {HIja':excl}.

examples.en:
▶ {HIvbe' qoHpu' neH.:sen}
▶ {pujwI' HIvlu'chugh quvbe'lu'.:sen}
▶ {chorghSaD qelI'qam HIvchuq'e' vInoH.:sen}

definition.en: A ship cloaks in order to attack.
definition.de: Ein Schiff tarnt sich, um anzugreifen.

notes.en: In the {paq'batlh:n}, {molor:n:name} is referred to as a {HI''a':n:nolink} "tyrant" throughout.

definition.sv: alla, allihop, allt, allting, varje, varenda

notes.en: If the following noun is explicitly plural, it means "all the X's", taken collectively. If the noun is not explicitly plural, then it means "each X", considered individually.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {Hoch tlhInganpu':sen:nolink} "all Klingons"[2]
▶ {Hoch paqmey:sen:nolink} "all the books"[2]
▶ {Hoch 'ebmey tIjon.:sen} "Capture all opportunities" (and not "each opportunity")
▶ {wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.:sen} "To die while serving the Empire is the hope of every Klingon" (i.e., every Klingon, individually)

definition.en: end, last item in a list

HochHom:n.hidden_notes: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} seems to have the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

notes.en: This is an emphatic alternative for {reH:adv}.

examples.en: ▶ {Hochlogh no' yIquvmoH.:sen:nolink} "Always honor your ancestors", literally, "All times honor your ancestors".

Hoch Holmey mughwI':n.hidden_notes: The example sentence was MO's reply to the interviewer who asked him to choose his favourite Star Trek technology. He chose the transporter beam ({jol:n}).

examples.en: ▶ {Hoch Holmey mughwI' vIwIv 'e' DapIH'a'?:sen@@Hoch Holmey mughwI':n, vI-:v, wIv:v, 'e':n, Da-:v, pIH:v:1, -'a':v} "Did you expect me to choose the Universal Translator?"

definition.en: Pity the warrior who slays all his foes.
definition.de: Bemitleide den Krieger, der alle seine Feinde geschlagen hat.

notes.en: This is a famous line from the poem {lu qeng:n:name,nolink} by G'trok. The idiomatic expression {Hoch jaghpu'Daj HoHpu':sen:nolink} "He/she has killed all his/her enemies" means that a person leads a meaningless, empty life, one lacking any challenge.
This idiomatic expression, which is based on the homophony of the words {nuH:n:1} and {nuH:n:2}, means "to consider every possibility" or "to consider every option".

examples.en:
▶ {Hoch nuH yIqel!:sen:nolink} "Consider every possibility!"
▶ {Hoch nuH Daqel'a'?:sen:nolink} "Did you consider every option?"

definition.en: Eat everything or you will die without honor.
definition.de: Wenn du nicht alles aufisst, wirst du nicht ehrenhaft sterben.

notes.en: This is roughly like saying, "Eat, eat!"

en: Eat everything or you will die without honour.

notes.en:
This is the 5th rank of {yaS:n}.

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/9CTfqKn383I}

The Klingon week has six days, which are:
▶ {DaSjaj:n} "Monday"
▶ {povjaj:n} "Tuesday"
▶ {ghItlhjaj:n} "Wednesday"
▶ {loghjaj:n} "Thursday"
▶ {buqjaj:n} "Friday"
▶ {lojmItjaj:n} or {ghInjaj:n} "Saturday"

If an alien calendar contains more than six days, additional days are numbered beginning with {wa':n:num}. Thus, "Sunday" would be {jaj wa':n}. The eighth day of the week on {lenmaq:n}, which uses an eight-day week, is called {jaj cha':n:nolink}, and so on.[2]

examples.en: {wa' yIHoH. jISaHbe'.:sen}

notes.en: This is short for {romuluSngan Sambogh 'ej HoHbogh nejwI':n}.
This is simply the verb {HoH:v} with the suffix {-'egh:v}.[2]

In Klingon, names of languages are formed by attaching {Hol:n:nolink} to an identifier for the language. For example, "Klingon" (the language) is {tlhIngan Hol:n}, and {tlhIngan:n} by itself does not refer to the language, but to a person or people.

The identifier is usually a country, region, or political unit of some kind. For example, Federation Standard (i.e., "English") is {DIvI' Hol:n}. {tlhIngan Hol:n:nolink} is actually a shortened form of {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}.[2]

definition.sv: slang, "färskt språk" (mestadels använt av yngre klingoner)

notes.en: This term is used by younger Klingons to refer to the way they prefer to speak.
In Klingon, this is a command rather than a question. It literally means, "Identify the languages which you speak!"
This is also the name of the journal of the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.
This term does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction from {Hol:n} and {tej:n}.

Hol tej:n.hidden_notes: {Holtej:n:name,nolink} (no space) is the Klingon name of linguist and Klingonist d'Armond Speers.

definition.en: weakling, runt, scrawny one, skinny one
definition.sv: vekling, liten en, mager en, utmärglad person

notes.en: Due to the homophony with {Hom:n:2}, to point one's second toe at someone (typically an opponent or an enemy), while the other toes point downwards, is considered an insulting gesture. It signifies that one considers the other person to be weak.

examples.en: ▶ {jaghwI'Daq jIHom.:sen:nolink} "I claim my enemy is unworthy or weak."

notes.en: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIHon.:sen:nolink} "I doubt that you speak Klingon."[2]

notes.en:
This verb is used in the same way as {Sum:v} (it involves the concept of deixis).[2]

In Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".[3]

Hoqra':n.hidden_notes: The pun seems to be {Hoq:n} "expedition" = "trek", and {ra':v} "order", and hence "trekorder" = "tricorder". Another theory says that the "Expedition" is a model of adult tricycle ("trike").

definition.en: be honored falsely, be falsely honorable
definition.sv: vara falskt ärad, vara felaktigt hedrad

notes.en:
Deception is implied by the use of this verb.

This word is used in places where {quv:v} might be used, but when the honor was discovered to be illegitimate. For exampe, a {Duy quv:n:nolink} who turns out to be a spy would be called a {Duy HoQ:n:nolink}.

It differs from {quvHa':v} in that it indicates that one has demanded respect which is unearned or undeserved. A warrior who shows cowardice in battle is a {SuvwI' quvHa':n:nolink}. One who hides his cowardice, is awarded for valor (i.e., becomes known as a {SuvwI' quv:n:nolink}), and is subsequently discovered to be a fraud, is a {SuvwI' HoQ:n:nolink}.

Do not use this word lightly as it has very bad connotations in Klingon society.

There is an idiom, {HoS; 'Iw rur}.

This verb is also used for regular polygons and polyhedra.[2]

examples.en: {vagh reD mey' HoS:n@@vagh reD mey':n, HoS:v} "regular pentagon"[2]

▶ {Suvlu'taHvIS yapbe' HoS neH.:sen}
▶ {tIqDaq HoSna' tu'lu'.:sen}

notes.en: This is a device which changes energy from one form to another.

definition.en: You are a total waste of good energy!

notes.en: {pIraqSIS:n} is an important Klingon energy facility.

examples.en: ▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."

notes.en: It's not clear if this word is grammatically singular or plural. One energy being is a {HoS Dep:n:nolink} (see {HoS:n}, {Dep:n}).
The term {HoS Hal:n:nolink} (with a space) has also appeared in canon. See the example under {nISwI' beH:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {HoSHal ghajchugh vay', mI' naghmey tIronmoH. wa'maHlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey; chen qav'ap. ghajwI'vaD qav'ap yIDIl.:sen:nolink} "If [energy source is] owned, throw dice and pay owner a total ten times amount shown."

examples.en: ▶ {yIHotlh!:sen:1}

notes.en: This refers to an astronomical body, and not to the geometric figure, for which see {DujtlhuQ:n}.

definition.en: idol, someone worthy of emulation, something deserving of respect

notes.en: This word follows the grammatical rules appropriate to its literal meaning (see {Ho':n:1}). It takes the plural suffix {-Du':n:suff} and possessive suffixes such as {-wIj:n:suff}, even when it refers to a person or people.[1, p.152]

Ho':n:2.hidden_notes: This is defined in the {KGT:src} word list only as "idol". The expanded definition above is from p.152.

notes.en: This refers to the serrated blade found on a {qutluch:n}.[1, p.61]

definition.en: You have some stuffed to'baj leg in your teeth.
definition.de: Du hast etwas gestopftes Tobbajbein zwischen den Zähnen.

notes.en: There is a Klingon idiom, {Sagh; Ho''oy' rur}.
Note that this refers to a "system" in the sense of a way of doing something. For a physical (or physical-like) system, see {pat:n}.

▶ {QIch wab Ho'DoS:n}

notes.en:
This is the general term for a musical instrument with strings ({SIrgh:n}), which one may either pluck ({pang:v}) or strum ({yach:v:2}). To vary the sound, one "fingers" ({Heng:v}) the strings (touch them at different points while plucking or strumming).

Types of {HurDagh:n:nolink} include the {Supghew:n} (small), the {leSpal:n} (medium), and the {tIngDagh:n} (large).
This is a fully marinated {peb'ot:n}.
There is an idiom, {wIH; Hur'Iqngan rur}.

The name "J'puq" is a reference to Julia Child ({puq:n}). It also alludes to "puke" and makes fun of the use of French in otherwise English-language cookbooks.

The title of the book may be a reference to the Twilight Zone episode "To Serve Man".

examples.en: ▶ {beyHom bey bey'a' jachtaH:sen}

This means to throw or hurl something like a projectile.[1, p.91]

definition.de: Um den Feind zu besiegen, sei bereit, alleine zu kämpfen.

definition.en: May the bile of the vanquished fill your hands.
definition.de: Mögen deine Hände gefüllt sein mit der Galle der Besiegten.
definition.ru: Пусть желчь завоеванного врага наполнит твои руки.
definition.zh_HK: 願被征服敵人的膽汁填滿你的手。

jagh yIbuStaH!:sen.hidden_notes: This was the winning replacement proverb entry, submitted by Rich Yampell ({Qanqor:n:name,nolink}), in the proverbs competition at {qep'a' 2014:src}.

definition.en: I demand the blood of the enemy.
definition.de: Ich verlange nach dem Blut des Feindes.

jagh 'Iw vIpoQ.:sen.hidden_notes: This sentence does not appear in canon. It is included here because it is used in some fan ceremonies.

notes.en: If the verb prefix indicates an object, then the subject is going to a destination associated with the object, which may be marked with {-Daq:n}. If the verb prefix indicates no object, then the destination is unspecified. In that case, a noun marked with {-Daq:n:nolink} indicates the location where the "going" is taking place.[2]

jaH:v.hidden_notes: Some canon sentences don't seem to follow the grammar described in {HQ 7.4:src}, instead using a prefix indicating no object to indicate travel to the destination marked with {-Daq:n:nolink}.

examples.en:
▶ {bIQtIqDaq jIjaH.:sen:nolink} "I go in the river."  This means: I'm moving along in the river, traveling in the river.[2]
▶ {bIQtIq vIjaH.:sen:nolink} or {bIQtIqDaq vIjaH.:sen:nolink} (the {-Daq:n:nolink} is optional)  This means: I'm moving along to the river, traveling to the river.[2]
▶ {bIghHa' yIjaH:sen:nolink} "Go to jail"[3]
▶ {Ha', ... wIjaH!:sen} "Come, let's go to ... !"

notes.en:
The Klingon day goes from dawn to dawn. For the part of a day during which there is daylight, see {pem:n} (the opposite of which is night, {ram:n}).

The parts of a {jaj:n:nolink} are: {pem:n} "daytime", {jajlo':n} "dawn", {po:n} "morning", {pemjep:n} "midday", {DungluQ:n} "noon", {pov:n} "afternoon", {ram:n} "night", {ramjep:n:1} "midnight".

For "days ago" and "days from now", see {Hu':n} and {leS:n}, respectively.
The Klingon week ({Hogh:n}) contains six days. Days beyond the sixth on alien calendars are simply numbered, starting at {wa':n:num}.[3]

jaj wa':n.hidden_notes: According to Maltz, the numbering of Sunday as "day one" may have been to cater to Americans, who view it as the first day of the week.[2]
jaj wa':n.source: [1] {Star Trek The Exhibition:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2012.04.01:src}, [3] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2013:src}

notes.en: This refers to the visual phenomenon in the sky, not the technical moment of sunrise.

definition.en: A noisy animal (not a bird) known for making a ruckus at dawn, like a Terran rooster.
definition.de: ein lautes Tier (kein Vogel) bekannt für sein Krähen wie ein Hahn in der Morgendämmerung
definition.sv: ett slags djur (för oljud i gryningen)

notes.en: While both {DaHjaj:n:nolink} and {jajvam:n:nolink} mean "today", they are not quite interchangeable.[2] See under {DaHjaj:n} for details.
For a counterfactual (or "irrealis") statement, the phrase {... net jalchugh:sen:nolink} "if one imagines that...", "if it is imagined that..." is used.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {puvbogh targh yIjal@@puv:v, -bogh:v, targh:n, yI-:v, jal:v} "Think about a flying targ."[1]
▶ {tlhIngan SoH 'e' vIjal@@tlhIngan:n, SoH:n, 'e':n, vI-:v, jal:v} "I imagine you are a Klingon."[1]
▶ {tlhIngan SoH net jalchugh, qagh DatIv@@tlhIngan:n, SoH:n, net:n, jal:v, -chugh:v, qagh:n, Da-:v, tIv:v} "If you were a Klingon, you would enjoy gagh."[2]

▶ {baHjan:n}
▶ {botjan:n}

notes.en: This is short for {QoQ jan:n}, but that term is rarely shortened.
This is the name of the actor who played Kor (see {qor:n:name}).

This is the name of the {HoD:n} of the {'entepray':n:name} during the time of {puq poH veb:n}.

In Klingon, titles generally go after the name, so "Captain Jean-Luc Picard" would be {janluq pIqarD HoD:n@@janluq pIqarD:n, HoD:n}. Note that {pIqarD:n:nolink} does not follow proper Klingon phonology, since it is an alien name.

jang:v.hidden_notes: There is contradictory information regarding whether this is a "verb of speech". (See {jatlh:v} for an explanation.) In {HQ 7.4:src}, it is said not to be, but its usage in the {paq'batlh:src} suggests otherwise.[2; 3]

notes.en: This is said of music.[1, p.71]

This word means "deep" in the physical sense.

Note that in Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".
For "shallow" in a metaphorical sense, see {SaS:v:2,slang}.
For "months ago" and "months from now", see {wen:n} and {waQ:n}, respectively.

definition.en: similarly, likewise, in the same way
definition.de: gleicherweise, auf ähnliche Art und Weise

jaSHa':adv.hidden_notes: Apparently, MO had originally rejected this as a word in 2000, but had changed his mind by 2009.[2]

notes.en: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used instead of {Soy':v:1}.
According to legend, these are spirits of the dead that possess the living.

A typical object of this verb is that which is spoken, which might be a language or lecture. The listener is the indirect object and is marked with {-vaD:n}.[3; 4]

The "prefix trick" may be used with this verb: if the verb prefix indicates a first- or second-person object, that person is the indirect object, that is, the person to whom the subject is speaking.[3]

The verb {jatlh:v:nolink} is also used when giving a direct quotation, in which case the verb prefix indicating no object is used (except if the "prefix trick" is applied). The quotation may come before or after the sentence with {jatlh:v:nolink}.[3]

This is one of the few "verbs of speech" in Klingon. In Klingon, quotations must always be accompanied by one of these verbs.[4]

jatlh:v.hidden_notes:
In {TKD:src}, this is defined in the K-E word list as "say", and listed in the E-K word list under "speak". In {TKDA:src}, it is defined in both word lists as "say".

In the {msn:src} newsgroup message, it says only that the verb prefix indicating no object is used for a direct quotation if the speaker is first or second person.[3] It's left unclear if {lu-:v:pref} should be used if the speakers are third-person and plural, but the rule seems to be that a quotation is not treated grammatically as the object of the verb.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan Hol vIjatlhlaHbe'.:sen}[1]
▶ {bIjatlh 'e' yImev!:sen}[1]
▶ {SoQ Dajatlh.:sen:nolink} "You deliver an address", "You make a speech."[3]
▶ {qajatlh.:sen:nolink} "I speak to you."[3]
▶ {tlhIngan jIH jatlh.:sen:nolink} or {jatlh tlhIngan jIH.:sen:nolink} "He/she says, 'I am a Klingon'."[3]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh.:sen:nolink} "You speak Klingon."[3]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol bIjatlh.:sen:nolink} "You say, 'Klingon language'."[3]
▶ {SoHvaD pagh vIjatlh, Human.:sen}[5]

definition.en: sixth tone of nonatonic musical scale
definition.sv: sjätte tonen på den nonatoniska skalan

notes.en: The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2,nolink}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

jav:n:3.hidden_notes: In the TV show "The Prisoner", the main character is number six ({jav:n:1}).

javtIm:n.hidden_notes: {jav:n:1} in Roman numerals is "VI", and Tim Russ played Tuvok. VI + Russ = virus.

notes.en: It is unknown whether there is any difference between this word and {joH:n}.[2, p.41]

jaw:n.hidden_notes:
This word came about as an onscreen mispronunciation of {joH:n:nolink}.

In {TKD:src} this word is defined as "lord" only, same as {joH:n:nolink}. However, {KGT:src} expanded the definition of {joH:n:nolink} to include "lady". Though not explicitly stated, this extension applies to {jaw:n:nolink} as well.

notes.en: This adverbial always comes at the end of a sentence, and turns the entire thing into an invective.
This is one of the few "verbs of speech" in Klingon.[2] (See {jatlh:v} for an explanation.)

ja':v.hidden_notes: In the {HolQeD:src} interview, Will Martin suggested that a typical direct object of this verb is the person addressed. This was not contradicted by Marc Okrand, but not explicitly affirmed, either.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {nuja'rup.:sen:nolink} "They are prepared to tell us."[1]

notes.en: This verb is made up of {ja':v} plus the suffix {-chuq:v}[1, p.66]. In spite of this, it seems that it can take the topic of discussion as its object, although the exact grammar is unclear.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {'uQ wISoppu'DI' maja'chuq.:sen:nolink} "We will talk after dinner."[2]
▶ {quv HIja'chuqQo'!:sen:nolink} "Don't speak to me of honor!"[3]

notes.en: This is a ceremony performed by the candidates during the Rite of Succession (see {cho'tay:n:hyp}).

examples.en: ▶ {ja'chuq Dalopchu'. Qang Damoj.:sen:nolink} "Complete the Rite of Succession to become Chancellor."[2]

notes.en:
This follows the final noun.

In addition to nouns, {je:sen:nolink} can also follow a verb. See {je:adv}.

definition.de: auch (folgt dem Verb das es modifiziert)

notes.en: When {je:adv:nolink} follows a verb, it means "also, too". {qaleghpu' je:sen:nolink} means "I also saw you, I saw you too", and as in English, its meaning is ambiguous. (It could mean "I and others saw you" or "I saw you and others".)[1]

je:adv.hidden_notes: This is considered a noun conjunction, rather than an adverbial, in {TKD:src}.

definition.en: be thick, be dense, be viscous
definition.sv: vara tjock, vara seg, vara trögflytande

notes.en: There is an idiom, {jeD; ghevI' rur}.

examples.en:
▶ {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen}
▶ {jeghbe' tlhInganpu'.:sen}

notes.en: Conquered people: more than slaves, less than citizens, this status is given to occupants of worlds conquered by the Klingon Empire.

The idiomatic expression {jej pach} "the claw is sharp" means "the food is pungent (that is, good)".

There is also an idiom, {jej; Daqtagh rur}.

definition.sv: vara slö, vara oskarp, vara trubbig (om egg)

notes.en: The idiomatic expression {jejHa' pach} "the claw is dull" means "the food is bland (that is, bad)".

examples.en: {'etlh QorghHa'lu'chugh ragh 'etlh nIvqu' 'ej jejHa'choH.:sen}

notes.en: This can mean "feel" in the meaning of "sensing" something (like a Betazoid might), but it can also be used for a machine that detects something.

jem:v.hidden_notes: In {TOS - The Empath:src}, "Gem" was the nickname given by Dr. McCoy to an empath.
jem:v.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}

notes.en:
This is the name of the {HoD:n} of the {'entepray':n:name}.

Note that {jemS:n:nolink} and {qIrq:n:nolink} do not follow proper Klingon phonology, since they are part of an alien name.
This is a building built for protection or fortification.

jem'IH:n.hidden_notes: Himeji Castle is a famous landmark in Japan.

notes.en: A Klingon would recognise a Terran penguin as a {tera' jentu':n:nolink}.
This can also be used to refer to a saucer (see {Dargh HIvje':n}).

definition.sv: sticka ut från, skjuta ut ur

notes.en: The object is the thing from which the subject protrudes.

examples.en:
▶ {chor jeq taj:sen:nolink} "a knife protrudes from a belly"[2]
▶ {tajwIj 'oHbe' chorlIj jeqbogh Dochvetlh'e'.:sen:nolink} "That is not my dagger protruding from your midsection."[3]

definition.en: surge (aircraft suddenly moves forward or backward)
definition.de: ruckeln (Flugzeug bewegt plötzlich vor- oder rückwärts)
definition.sv: vara ryckande, vara i plötsligt rörelse framåt eller bakåt (om flygmaskin)

notes.en: It is unknown if this has meaning outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions.
This verb does not take an object, and is generally in a phrase following a phrase saying what the subject of {jeS:v:nolink} is participating in.[2]

examples.en:
All of the following can be translated as "I participate in the {qepHom@@qep:n, -Hom:n}," though the literal meaning of each is distinct.
▶ {qaStaHvIS qepHom jIjeS.:sen:nolink} "While the qepHom is happening, I participate."
▶ {qaS qepHom 'ej jIjeS.:sen:nolink} "The qepHom is happening, and I participate."
▶ {qaS qepHom vaj jIjeS.:sen:nolink} "The qepHom is happening, so I participate."[2]

notes.en: This literally means "volunteer to participate". It can be used even if the signing up isn't entirely voluntary. It is used both for signing up for something in advance or deciding on the spot to participate in an event which is about to start.
This is a loanword from {DIvI' Hol:n}.

This is a weather word, rather than a military word. This is made clear by the homophonous {jev:v:2}.

This verb is used in Sonnet 116, where its explicit subject is {muD:n:nolink}.[2]
Note the homophonous {jev:v:1}. Apparently, Klingons view storms as a form of wheezing or noisy breathing by the atmosphere.

jey:v.hidden_notes: This sounds like the Hindi for victory.

examples.en: ▶ {Dujeychugh jagh nIv yItuHQo'.:sen}

definition.sv: dubbelhövdad yxa, yxa med dubbelt blad

notes.en: There is an idiom, {yuD; jey'naS rur}.
This literally means "double-headed ax spy".

examples.en:
▶ {bIje'be'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen}
▶ {qa'vam De' vIje' rIntaH.:sen}

▶ {yIje'!:sen}
▶ {qa' wIje'meH maSuv.:sen}

notes.en: {jIH:n:1h}:{pagh:n:1h} = {jI-:v:pref,nolink}
This refers only to hair on the top of the head, and not to facial hair (see {rol:n} and {loch:n}) or body hair (see {pob:n}).

examples.en: ▶ {DaH jIbwIj vISay'nISmoH.:sen}

notes.en: This was spoken by Worf (in Klingon) during his Rite of Ascension.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan jIH.:sen}
▶ {DaHjaj SuvwI''e' jIH.:sen}

notes.en: Note that {jIH:n:2,nolink} refers to the device, while {HaSta:n} refers to the visual information displayed on it. {HaSta:n} and {wIy:n} are among the views which can be shown on a {jIH:n:2,nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {jolbogh ghom wa'DIch DamuvlaHmeH De' DaneHchugh, Se'vam yIjIHtaH!:sen:nolink} "Stay tuned for information on how you can be among the first to beam aboard!"[2]

notes.en: The subject is the cooperating parties.

jIj:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from E-K side of {TKD:src}, and furthermore the K-E side defines it as "cooperate". However, {KGT:src} clarifies that this word means "be cooperative".

examples.en:
▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink}
  "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[3]

definition.en: The stars will talk before I will.
definition.de: Bevor ich spreche, sprechen die Sterne.

notes.en: This is spoken to accept a request to become somebody's {cha'DIch:n:2}.

definition.sv: vara stigande eller sjunkande, vara lyftande eller fallande (om flygmaskin)

notes.en: It is unknown if this has meaning outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions.

notes.en:
The object of this verb is usually a phrase, and cannot be a thing.

To express a wish for something to happen, see {-jaj:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan jIH 'e' vIjIn.@@tlhIngan:n, jIH:n:1, 'e':n, vI-:v, jIn:v} "I wish I were a Klingon."

In {TKD:src}, this was defined as "lord". In {KGT:src}, this was expanded to "Lady, female head of house" and "Lord, male head of house".

In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", Lady Di (Diana, Princess of Wales) is translated as {Day joH:n:nolink}.[3]

notes.en: This is an archaic and upper-class word with the same meaning as {tlhorghHa':v}.
This means to take an object down off a shelf or other overhead structure.

jotlhHa':v.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in canon. However, when it was suggested to MO that {jotlhHa':v:nolink} would mean "put up" since {jotlh:v:nolink} means "take down", he corrected it by saying that "put back up" would be a better translation.[1]

joy':v.hidden_notes:
"Joy".

In the novel {Sarek:src}, the word {be'joy':n:nolink} is used for a form of ritualized torture performed by women.

definition.en: blow into a container of some kind

notes.en:
This means "inflate, fill with air, blow up". This is used for blowing up a balloon, a paper bag, a bubble, and so on. Unlike with {SuS:v}, air is trapped in the thing that's blown into and can't come out until it's let out (or the thing breaks).

If {-Daq:n} is used, it implies a miss: air was blown towards the object, but bypassed it.

jo':v.hidden_notes: "Bazooka Joe" is the mascot of the Bazooka brand of bubble gum. {ba'Suq'a' jo':sen@@ba'Suq:n, -'a':n, jo':v} means "he blows a great bubble".

notes.en: {SoH:n}:{maH:n:1h} = {ju-:v:pref,nolink}

definition.de: breit sein, eine Breite von ... haben

notes.en: For measuring a flat object such as a tabletop, {juch:v:nolink} and {'aD:v} are used for the two dimensions.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan juHqo'Daq tlhIng yoSDaq 'oH toQDuj chenmoHlu'meH Daq wa'DIch'e':sen@@tlhIngan:n, juHqo':n, -Daq:n, tlhIng yoS:n, -Daq:n, 'oH:n, toQDuj:n, chenmoH:v, -lu':v, -meH:v, Daq:n, wa'DIch:n, -'e':n} "1st Construction Site: The Kling District, Klingon Home World"[2]

notes.en: This literally means "sun gas".

julSIp:n.hidden_notes: Aside from the fact that Helium comes from the Greek word for "Sun" (helios), helium was also first detected by Jules Janssen.

notes.en: This means "odd" as in peculiar, unexpected, fishy.[2]

examples.en: {yIjuntaH!:sen}

jungwoq:n.hidden_notes: At the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, MO said that he deliberately chose the Cantonese pronunciation for China rather than the Mandarin one, because the latter would have ended in {wo':n}, and he didn't think Klingons would like to call an Earth country by their word for "empire".

notes.en:
This is the general verb for measurement. The subject of this verb is taking the measurement of the object.[2]

To indicate the length, width, and depth of an object, see {'aD:v}, {juch:v}, and {Saw':v}, respectively. For objects which are much longer or taller than they are wide, use {'ab:v} instead of {'aD:v}. The Klingon unit of linear measure is the {'uj:n}.

Distances can be described using {chuq:n}, {Sum:v}, and {Hop:v}. For large distances, use {qelI'qam:n}; for even larger (e.g., interstellar) distances, use {loghqam:n}.

To express a volume, use {muq:v} (see also {tIn:v}, {mach:v}). See {tlho'ren:n} for a unit of volume.

To express a weight (mass), use {ngI':v} (see also {tIS:v}, {'ugh:v}). See {cheb:n} for a unit of weight or mass.

examples.en: ▶ {naQjej vIjuv.:sen:nolink} "I measure the spear."[2]

notes.en: In other words, "upload" (or possibly "download", depending on context).

definition.de: übertreiben (zu oft oder zu nachdrücklich tun)

notes.en: This is the 8th rank of {yaS:n}.

definition.sv: ta sönder, plocka isär, montera isär

notes.en: This can also be used to express "feature" in the sense used in software.[2]
A patron at a {Qe':n} may {lajQo':v:nolink} a dish if the {jabwI':n} has {qawHa':v}.[1, p.102]

▶ {nuqDaq Dochvam vIlan?:sen}
▶ {HurDaq tu'HomI'raHvetlh yIlan!:sen:nolink} "Get that piece of junk out of here!"[2]

lang:v.hidden_notes: Something that is "long" is usually thin.

definition.de: flattern (wie Flügel eines Vogels, nicht wie Fahne)

notes.en: This verb describes movement like that of a bird's wings, and not like that of a flag (for which see {joq:v}). In flight, a bird's wings {laq:v:nolink}, and the bird is said to {laqmoH@@laq:v, -moH:v} its wings.

laq:v.hidden_notes: The example comes from the KLI website and not from the HolQeD article itself.

examples.en: ▶ {laq tel. tel laqmoH bo'Degh.:sen:nolink}
▶ {baS laSvargh:n}

definition.en: ink up, put paint on a brush

notes.en:
This is used both for the act of transferring ink from a {rItlh 'echlet:n} to a {toqwIn:n}, and the act of putting paint on a {rItlh naQ:n}.

A slang term for this action is {pID:v:2}.
This is the name of a {veng:n} located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on {tera':n}.

laS veghaS:n.hidden_notes: The Las Vegas Hilton hotel was the site of a themed attraction called Star Trek The Experience. The name of the city appeared in Klingon in the invitation to the grand opening.

lat:n.hidden_notes:
This is defined only as "shrine" in {KGT:src}. The definition "monument, memorial (building)" was added at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.

In English slang, a "lat"rine is sometimes called a "shrine".

definition.sv: ytterligare en, en annan, en till

notes.en: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of language (see {-pu':n:suff}), body parts (see {-Du':n:suff}), or things which are neither (see {-mey:n:suff}).

examples.en:
▶ {reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj puS.:sen}[2]
▶ {yIntaH qIrq 'e' vIneH. DaSwIj bIngDaq latlhpu' vItap.:sen:nolink} "Kirk I want alive. The rest I will grind beneath my boot."[3]

definition.en: Pour the cold bloodwine into another glass!
definition.de: Gieße den kalten Blutwein in ein anderes Glas!

notes.en: This idiomatic expression means "I don't believe you, maybe someone else will", or "That is irrelevant to me, maybe someone else will care."

lav:n.hidden_notes: People often just use a shrub when they can't find a "lav"atory.

notes.en: This is a traditional (in the sense of having been used a long time ago but no longer in use today) unit of angle. There are 243 {lawmey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}. (Note that 243 is 3 to the 5th power.)

This is a modern unit of angle adopted from other civilizations in the galaxy. It is also referred to as a {law chu':n:nolink} (although that term is used less and less). There are 360 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}.

definition.sv: vara många, vara talrika, vara mycket

notes.en:
The word {law':v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.

For things that are measurable or quantifiable, but not necessarily countable, use {vItlh:v}.[2]

This construction is used to form comparatives and superlatives. The two things being compared go into the two slots. To form the superlative, {Hoch:n} is used in the second slot.[1]

Other antonym pairs may be substituted in place of {law':v} and {puS:v:1} as a form of word play.[2]

To say that something is not more {X:sen:nolink} than something else, {law'be':v:nolink} and {puSbe':v:nolink} are used instead of {law':v:nolink} and {puS:v:nolink}. To say that something is as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {law':v:nolink} is used with {law':v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered positive), or {puS:v:nolink} is used with {puS:v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered negative), or {law':v:nolink} is used with {rap:v} or {nIb:v} (the latter of which implies the two things being compared are exactly the same in some way). It is also possible to use {puS:v:nolink} with {rap:v} or {nIb:v}, but that carries a connotation of disparagement. To say that something is not as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {pIm:v} is used in place of the second verb in the pair.[3]

To say that two things have the same amount of some quality, it's also possible to use {rap:v} or {nIb:v} without a {law':v:nolink}/{puS:v:nolink} construction. (See those verbs for details.)

The above constructions are typically used only to compare similar things. To form similes, which compare things which are unlike, use {rur:v} instead. When the above constructions are used to compare unlike things, they generally reference well-known similes.
This is some sort of technical term. It would be odd to say {lay vItlhuH:sen@@lay:n:2, vI-:v, tlhuH:v:1} for "I breathe air", but it would be understood.
This is the 6th rank of {yaS:n}.
A planet in the Ferengi Alliance.
The {la'quv:n:nolink} is head of the Klingon High Council, and the highest ranked {yaS:n}.
This refers to a Klingon creature that resembles a Terran turtle, which might be called a {tera' la'SIv:n:nolink}.

la'SIv:n.hidden_notes: Source is an e-mail from MO to loghaD.

notes.en: This is an officer in charge of certain specialized units within the military.

definition.en: be perpendicular, be at a right angle

notes.en: This is normally used with a plural subject.

examples.en: ▶ {leD rav tlhoy' je@@leD:v, rav:n:1, tlhoy':n, je:conj} "The floor and the wall are perpendicular (to each other)."[1]
examples.de: ▶ {leD rav tlhoy' je@@leD:v, rav:n:1, tlhoy':n, je:conj} "Der Boden und die Wand sind rechtwinklig (zu einander)."[1]

examples.de: ▶ {pa'vo' pagh leghlu'.:sen:nolink} "Das Zimmer hat keinen Ausblick."

definition.en: A sharp knife is nothing without a sharp eye.
definition.de: Ein scharfes Messer ist wertlos ohne ein scharfes Auge

notes.en: For the removal of something from the exterior, consider {teq:v}.
The inhabitants of Lenmak use an eight-day week ({Hogh:n}).

{leng:v:nolink} works like {jaH:v}.[2]

This word can be used to refer to traveling with or without a special purpose. If it is desired to indicate traveling on a mission, use {ve':v} instead.[3]
