▶ {yuQ vIleng.:sen:nolink} or {yuQDaq vIleng.:sen:nolink} "I travel to the planet."
▶ {yuQvo' jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam away from the planet."
▶ {yuQDaq jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam around/about on the planet."
examples.de:
▶ {yuQ vIleng.:sen:nolink} oder {yuQDaq vIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise zum Planeten"
▶ {yuQvo' jIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise vom Planeten weg."
▶ {yuQDaq jIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise auf dem Planeten."

When {A:sen:nolink} and {B:sen:nolink} share {C:sen:nolink} with each other, the construction is {C lulIn A B je:sen:nolink} (or {C lIn A B je:sen:nolink} if {C:sen:nolink} is plural). In this case, the speaker is non-committal about whether {A:sen:nolink} or {B:sen:nolink} is the one who decided to do the sharing with the other.[1]

This word is also used to express that a computer (or computer system) is online. (Offline would be expressed using {lInHa':v@@lIn:v, -Ha':v}.)[2]

notes.en:
The Klingon compass has three points, rather than four: {chan:n} (east), {'ev:n} (northwest), and {tIng:n} (southwest).

The areas around an object are its {Dung:n} (area above), {bIng:n} (area below), {retlh:n} (area beside), {tlhop:n:1} (front), and {'em:n} (behind). Something in an object's {retlh:n:nolink} can be on its {poS:n} (left) or its {nIH:n} (right). The area between two objects are their {joj:n} (area between).

In standard Klingon, locative nouns follow pronouns, e.g., {jIH tlhop:n:nolink} "in front of me". But in the dialect of the Sakrej region ({Sa'Qej Sep:n}), locative nouns take pronominal possessive suffixes, e.g., {tlhopwIj:n:nolink} "my area in front".[2]  However, the directional nouns are an exception to this rule, and take possessive suffixes in every known dialect, e.g., {chanwIj:n:nolink} "east of me, to my east". If the full pronoun is used with a directional noun, the pronoun is emphasized, e.g., {jIH chan:n:nolink} "east of ME, to MY east".[4]

The points in between the three cardinal directions are {tIng chan:n:nolink}, {'ev chan:n:nolink}, and either {tIng 'ev:n:nolink} or {'ev tIng:n:nolink}. {chan:n:nolink} always comes second in such a compound.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {veng chanDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt east of the city."
▶ {chan vengDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city in the east."
▶ {veng chan yoSDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city's east (the eastern part of the city)."
▶ {'evmajDaq jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here."  (Northwest is relative to the speaker's location.)
▶ {Daqvam 'ev jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here."  (Northwest is relative to a location indicated by the speaker, for example a point on a map.)

notes.en: Sister of B'Etor and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {barbara' ma'rIch:n:name}.

This is defined only as "treaty" in {TKD:src}. The additional definitions come from {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.

Possibly a reference to the fairy Queen Mab in Romeo and Juliet, who is known for making bargains with mortals.

magh:v.hidden_notes:
See the note under {mugh:v}.

Some word lists erroneously give another definition of {magh:v:nolink} with the meaning "indicate, reveal". This came from an old website called "Star Trek: Continuum", which had a "Klingon Linguistics Studies" section where someone (not Marc Okrand) took the official definitions and "expanded" them. This person apparently did not understand which meaning of the English word "betray" the Klingon word {magh:v:nolink} corresponded to.

notes.en: This is a person who betrays someone. For a person who commits treason, see {'urwI':n}.
This refers to a Klingon plant that most closely resembles grass.

magh:n.hidden_notes: In British English slang, to "grass on" someone means to betray them to a person in authority, such as police. (See {magh:v}.)

notes.en: Note that this is a number-forming element, and not itself a number. The number ten is {wa'maH:n:num}, literally "one ten", in Klingon.
This is a large bowl, used for serving {chatlh:n:1}, which diners pour into a {Duq:n} to eat.[1, p.99]
This term has not been used in canon, but its meaning is inferred by analogy with {vatlh DIS poH:n}, etc. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

This is an exclamation expressing satisfaction. For the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good", see {QaQ:v}.

This word does not have the sense of "good" as used in a greeting, such as "good morning" or "good night". While there is an idiomatic expression in Klingon, {maj ram:sen:nolink}, which is used in a similar manner to "good night", it actually means something like "Good, (it is) night".[2]

maj:excl.hidden_notes: In {TNK:src}, "Good morning" is given as {maj po:excl:nolink}, "Good afternoon" as {maj pov:excl:nolink}, and "Good evening" as {maj choS:excl:nolink}. In {DS9 - The Sword of Kahless:src}, Jadzia Dax and Kor said {maj ram:excl:nolink} to each other as she headed for bed.

notes.en: The first element of this word appears to be {maj:excl}. The second element may be related to {Qap:v:1}.

notes.en: This was spoken by Worf (in Klingon) during his Rite of Ascension.

definition.en: When a warrior goes to a battle, he does not abandon his friends.
definition.de: Wenn ein Krieger in die Schlacht zieht, lässt er seine Freunde nicht alleine.

definition.en: A Klingon does not run away from his battles.
definition.de: Ein Klingone rennt nicht weg von seinen Schlachten.

may'wIj 'oH may'vam'e'.:sen.hidden_notes: This sentence does not appear in canon. It is included here because it is used in some fan ceremonies.

definition.en: battle gear, panoply, complete set of armor and weapons
definition.de: Rüstung (vollständige Kampfausrüstung, inkl. Waffen und Munition)
definition.sv: stridsdon, full rustning, full uppsättning av rustning och vapen

notes.en: This is a type of {SuSDeq:n}.

may'ron:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Myron Floren, accordionist on "The Lawrence Welk Show".

definition.sv: inhysa, ge husrum, betjäna, utrusta, förse

ma':v.hidden_notes: MO accommodated the filmmakers by changing {qama':sen@@qa-:v, ma':v} to mean "prisoner" while {Star Trek III:src} was being filmed. See {qama'pu' jonta' neH.:sen}

notes.en: A death ritual that allows one who has lost honor to die well and go to Sto-Vo-Kor by being honorably killed by a House-mate or someone equally close.

ma'to'vor:n.hidden_notes: This is written as {ma' to'vor:n:nolink} in the glossary to {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, but the space appears to be a typo, as the word appears as {ma'to'vor:n:nolink} in the glossary to {A Good Day to Die:src}.
ma'to'vor:n.source: [1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, [3] {A Good Day to Die:src}

definition.sv: ett slags ceremoniell kniv, mevak (används i Mauk-To'Vor-ritualen)

notes.en: The "M'veQ" is a ceremonial knife used in the ritual of "Mauk To'Vor" ({ma'to'vor:n}).

ma'veq:n.hidden_notes: This word's spelling was confirmed by MO. However, in the glossary to the non-canon {A Good Day to Die:src}, DeCandido writes this as {mevaq:n:nolink} "mevak dagger".
ma'veq:n.source: [1] {DS9 - Sons of Mogh:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 1999.02.12:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2010.12.29:src}, [4] {paq'batlh p.184:src}

mech:v.hidden_notes: Latin "mercari", from whence merchant, merchandise, etc.

examples.en: ▶ {nom yer mechmeH Quj} "The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game"[2]

definition.en: end (of stick, rope, etc.), other end from {'er'In:n}
definition.de: Ende (von Stab, Schnur, usw.), das gegenüberliegende Ende heißt {'er'In:n}

notes.en: This can refer to either end of the rope, stick or whatever, but once you arbitrarily choose an end to call {megh'an:n:nolink}, the other end is called {'er'In:n:nolink}. Before you make this initial reference, either end can be called either {'er'In:n:nolink} or {megh'an:n:nolink}.

megh'an:n.hidden_notes: This is a private joke referring to a specific person.

notes.en: The word for the kind of bridge that goes over a river, or connects two locations, is {QI:n}.

According to {KGT p.79:src}, there is no single word for "art" or "artwork". This refers to visual art (painting, sculpture, etc.). {meHghem:n:nolink} is a bigger, more comprehensive term covering "the arts" or "art" as opposed to "science". It includes music, theater, dance, etc., as well as visual art. It's "culture" in this sense.

examples.en: ▶ {tera' DIS cha' pagh wa' wej meHghem Qat Sub boq cherlu'.:sen:nolink} "In 2013, Popular Culture Hero Coalition was established."

meHghem Qat:n.source: [1] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

definition.sv: lämna, avvika, ge sig av, avlägsna sig

notes.en:
In {TNK:src}, {DaH jImej:sen:nolink} is used for the Terran expression "goodbye".[2] This literally means "I'm leaving now". A Klingon, of course, would just leave, without superfluous niceties such as declaring his or her intention to do so.

To express leaving a person or object (rather than a location), consider {lon:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {bIghHa' DamejDI' pagh QaS yInob.:sen@@bIghHa':n, Da-:v, mej:v, -DI':v, pagh:n:2,num, QaS:n:1, yI-:v, nob:v} "Get out of jail free."[3]

notes.en: This was shortened over time from {mejmeH 'aD:n@@mej:v, -meH:v, 'aD:n}.
A character in a famous Klingon opera.
This is what a Klingon would call the Terran fruit.

meq:n.hidden_notes:
This is defined as "reason" in {TKD:src} and as "motive" in the word lists in {KGT:src}. It is also glossed as "logical thinking" (in the sense of "motive") in the body of {KGT:src} on p.154.

This was also used for the "logic" menu (instructions about program flow control) in Klingon Blockly.[3]

examples.en: ▶ {ram meqmey.:sen}

meq:v.hidden_notes: This is defined only as "reason" in {TKD:src}. The definition was later expanded.[2]

notes.en: This is the portion of a trial or appeal where the evidence is heard.
The {meqleH:n:nolink} is also called the {meqleH matlh:n:nolink}, to differentiate it from the similar sounding {betleH:n}.
In some dialects in this region, {letlh:n:2} refers only to the stairway connected to a ship, and {ngep'oS:n} refers to every other kind of stairway.

meqro'vaq Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.29 and not in the glossary. It appears as {meqro'vaq:n:nolink} and not as {meqro'vaq Sep:n:nolink}, but it is described as a region (see {Sep:n}).

notes.en: If there is no object, then the subject is the thing burning, e.g., {meQtaHbogh qachDaq Suv qoH neH.:sen}[2] If there is an object, then the subject is burning the object, e.g., {to'waQ meQ vutwI'.}[3] {meQ:v:nolink} can also be used adjectivally, e.g., {Ha'DIbaHmey meQ Sop 'e' tIv tera'nganpu'@@Ha'DIbaH:n:1, -mey:n, meQ:v, Sop:v, 'e':n, tIv:v, tera'ngan:n, -pu':n}.[4]

meQ:v.hidden_notes: In the sentence from {CK:src}, {tIv:sen:nolink} should have been {lutIv:sen:nolink} since {tera'nganpu':n:nolink} is plural.

notes.en: This is "the banner of unity and revolution" used by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} to rally his troops.

definition.en: Only a fool fights in a burning house.
definition.de: Nur ein Narr kämpft in einem brennenden Haus.

examples.en: ▶ {bISovbejbe'DI' tImer.:sen}

▶ {jImeS.:sen:nolink} "I make a knot."
▶ {tlhegh vImeS.:sen:nolink} "I make a knot in the rope."

notes.en: As with {So'Ha':v:nolink}, this implies that the person doing the decryption knows what he or she is doing ahead of time and is not cracking a code.[1]
This is an instrument which consists of interlocking tubes.

meSchuS:n.hidden_notes: A "noisy mess". Note that the words {meS:v:1h} and {meS:n} did not exist when this word was published.

notes.en: When used as a command, this word means to stop doing something. It would not be used for stopping a device (such as an engine).[2]

examples.en:
▶ {bIjatlh 'e' yImev!:sen}
▶ {not mev peghmey.:sen}

definition.sv: stopp, det är bra, det är nog

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call Terran sweet corn (maize).

This is technically a {letbaQ HoS:n@@letbaQ:n, HoS:v}.

This word can also refer to the "diamond" suit in a deck of playing cards (see {Degh:n:1}).[2]
A n-sided polygon is an {n reD mey':n:nolink} for n > 3. For example: {loS reD mey':n}, {vagh reD mey':n}.
The child of a {me':n:nolink} is a {tey':n:1}.

me':n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Aunt "Em" from The Wizard of Oz.

definition.sv: vara fordom ärad, vara tidigare hedrad

notes.en: Loss of honor is implied by this verb, which is used as an adjective to describe one who has fallen from grace. It is not applicable to someone who would be described as {'utlh:n}, a word which implies a voluntary, honorable retirement.

mIl:v.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Richard "Mil"house Nixon.

notes.en: This word can be used for any sort of depiction, including drawings, photographs, cartoons, icons on 21st-century computers, and so on.

mIllogh:n.hidden_notes: This is a combination of the Latin word for "thousand" with the Greek word for "word".

examples.en: ▶ {mImQo'. DaH Heraj yIchoH.:sen}

definition.en: Do not delay. Alter your course now.
definition.de: Zögere nicht. Ändere jetzt deinen Kurs.

notes.en: This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.
Note that this word is singular, unlike the English word "sunglasses".
This is the most common way to refer to a person who performs magic. For a true wizard or sorcerer, see {'IDnar pIn'a':n}.

mIQ:v.hidden_notes: This is a reference to McDonald's, which is known as "Mickey D's".

mIQ:n.hidden_notes: A Klingon forehead looks like it's deep-fried.

mIrSam:n.hidden_notes: "Meerschaum", also known as sepiolite, is a material from which some smoking pipes are made.

mIS:v.hidden_notes:
"Mish" mash.

This was clarified to mean "mental confusion" at {qep'a' 2017:src}.

notes.en: Shakespeare's play {paghmo' tIn mIS:sen:nolink}, literally "The Confusion is Great Because of Nothing", has been translated into English as "Much Ado About Nothing" by the {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}.

mIS:n.hidden_notes:
"Mish" mash.

This was clarified to mean "mental confusion" at {qep'a' 2017:src}.

mISmoH:v.hidden_notes: This was clarified to mean "mental confusion" at {qep'a' 2017:src}.

notes.en: This is the name of the sculptor who made Blood Oath Circles ({'Iw 'Ip ghomey:n}).

mIStaq:n.hidden_notes: The English spelling of this name was never given in {KCD:src}. The spelling is therefore uncertain.

notes.en:
In {TNK:src}, {mIv:n:1,nolink} is used for "hat".

See {mIvDaq pogh cha':sen} for an idiom involving {mIv:n:nolink}.

definition.en: a matter has been postponed or rescheduled

notes.en:
This expression literally means "to display a glove on one's helmet", and is used to convey the idea that a matter has been postponed or rescheduled. The phrase takes a number of forms, as appropriate to the parties to the commitment. For example, {mIvwIjDaq poghlIj vIcha':sen:nolink} "I display your glove on my helmet" implies that the postponed matter is between the speaker and the addressee.

This idiom has its origin in {HenrI' vagh:n:name}, a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}.
This is a {bargh:n} made of metal.

definition.en: fully dressed (as for a ceremonial affair)

notes.en: Note that this idiom does not follow proper grammar, in that normally {je:conj} would be at the end.

examples.en: ▶ {mIv je DaS tuQ ra'wI'.:sen:nolink} "The commander is in full dress uniform."

notes.en:
This is a scar which is the result of a wound (regardless of how the wound occurred).[1]

A tally or score is kept by counting {mIvwa'mey:n@@mIvwa':n, -mey:n}. This is also used for "census" or "headcount".[2]
notes.de:
Dies ist eine Narbe als Folge einer Verletzung (egal wie diese entstanden ist).[1]

A tally or score is kept by counting {mIvwa'mey:n@@mIvwa':n, -mey:n}. This is also used for "census" or "headcount".[2]

mIvwa':n.hidden_notes: This was defined as just "scar", with an accompanying explanation of the kinds of scars.

notes.en: This is a ceremonial headpiece worn by some emperors.

definition.en: procedure, process, step, stage (in a process)
definition.de: Prozedur, Prozess, Ablauf; Schritt, Stadium (in einem Ablauf)

mIw:n.hidden_notes: This was used to refer to a concept in computer programming, namely, a compartmentalized piece of computer code which has inputs and outputs and is used over and over, in Klingon Blockly.[3]

notes.en:
Number-forming elements include {maH:n:2,num}, {vatlh:n:num}, {SaD:n:num} ({SanID:n:num}), {netlh:n:num}, {bIp:n:num}, {'uy':n:num}.

When a number is used for numbering (labeling), as opposed to counting, it follows the noun. Ordinal numbers are formed with {-DIch:n:num,suff}. Repetitions are formed with {-logh:n:num,suff}.

examples.en: ▶ {ghogh HablI' mI' yIper:sen:nolink} "What is the telephone number?"[2]

notes.en: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {mI' naghmey:n:nolink} refers to the playing dice. The verb {ron:v} is used for the action of throwing or rolling the dice.

examples.en:
▶ {pIraqSIS HoS waw' ghajlu'chugh, loSlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey mI'; chen qav'ap.:sen:nolink} "If Praxis Energy Facility is owned, rent is 4 times amount shown on dice."
▶ {HoSHal ghajchugh vay', mI' naghmey tIronmoH. wa'maHlogh boq'egh mI' naghmey; chen qav'ap. ghajwI'vaD qav'ap yIDIl.:sen:nolink} "If [energy source is] owned, throw dice and pay owner a total ten times amount shown."

mI'QeD:n.hidden_notes: This was used in Klingon Blockly. The usage was vetted by Marc Okrand.[1]

definition.en: dance, run in place, do calisthenics
definition.sv: dansa, springa på stället, göra gymnastik, träna

notes.en: This can be used to translate "cabaret" if the cabaret show consists entirely or nearly entirely of dancing, but that's a special and infrequent situation.

mI'rab:n.hidden_notes: Jacob Bernouilli refered to the logarithmic spiral as "spira mirabilis".

notes.en: This is the father of {Qa'taq:n:name}.
An odd number is {mI' mob:n}.
An even number is {mI' mobHa':n}.

moD:v.hidden_notes: This may be a reference to "Depeche Mode". "Dépêcher" means to "to hurry" in French. However, {Qov:n:name} asked MO about this and he answered he didn't remember if it was deliberate.

examples.en: ▶ {moD Soj:sen:nolink} "the food hurries" (sign in a {Do Qe':n})[2]

notes.en: The father of Worf. See {wo'rIv:n:name}.

examples.en: ▶ {bogh tlhInganpu', SuvwI'pu' moj, Hegh.:sen}

notes.en:
This word may also be written {mojaQ:n:nolink}.

There are five types of noun suffixes and nine types of verb suffixes in Klingon, for which see {DIp:n} and {wot:n}, respectively.

This is the evil tyrant ({HI''a':n}) defeated by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}, as recounted in the {paq'batlh:n}.

There is an idiom, {mIgh; molor rur}.

mon:v.hidden_notes:
A reference to the Mona Lisa. {mon'a':sen:nolink} means "Is she smiling?"

This word is defined in {KGT:src} as "smile, grin, sneer".[1]  It is explained that it can also mean "snarl" and "smirk" in a message on the msn newsgroup.[2]

notes.en: A parry where you thrust a sword or other edged weapon behind your neck in order to block an attack from the rear.

This is used to signal the start of a duel.[1, p.68]

It is also used for beating {'In:n} (compare to {tlhaw':v} and {weq:v}).[1, p.75]

Note that the verb used for a heartbeat is {joq:v}.
This word is also used to refer to the spiked pommel at end of a {Daqtagh:n}.
This is the brother of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.
This means being rendered unconscious or into a dazed state as a result of being hit (by a fist or a projectile, etc.). This would be used for being hit by a phaser "set to stun".
notes.de: Dies bedeutet, nach einem Schlag oder einem Treffer bewusstlos bzw. kampfunfähig geworden zu sein. Dies würde man sagen, wenn man von einem Phaser getroffen wurde, der auf "betäuben" gestellt war.

definition.en: be usual, be standard, be normal
definition.sv: vara vanlig, vara normal, vara standard

motlh:v.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src}, this is defined only as "be usual".[1] In {SkyBox 14:src}, {nISwI' HIch motlh:n:nolink} is translated as "standard hand held disruptor".[2] In the {BoP:src} poster, {qughDo motlh:n:nolink} is translated as "normal cruising speed".[3]

definition.sv: vanligtvis, som vanligt, som väntat, normal sett

motlhHa':adv.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

definition.en: "Today was a good day to die."
definition.de: "Heute war ein guter Tag zum Sterben."

notes.en: This exclamation is archaic. It was spoken by Kahless to Lukara. The modern equivalent is {Heghlu'meH QaQ jajvam.:sen}

en: today was a good day to die

definition.sv: slunga, slungmanöver, gravitationsslunga (runt himlakropp med rymdskepp)

notes.en: The meaning and use of this slang word are explained on {KGT p.154:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {jaghpu' mo' wIyajnIS.} "We must understand the enemies' motive."[1, p.154]

notes.en: This is the House of {'uj'IllI':n:name}.
{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n}:{jIH:n:1h} = {mu-:v:pref,nolink}
Outside of a musical context, this word can also mean to "present a gift" to someone.

much:v.hidden_notes: This word was defined in {TKD:src} as "present". The definition "perform (music)" was added in {KGT:src}.

notes.en: This can be used for something like a show or a movie.[2] However, it isn't quite right for expressing "media" in general.[3]
This refers to the room in which a performance takes place.

muchpa':n.hidden_notes: Maltz revealed this word to translate "Bloomsbury Theatre" for the {Festival of the Spoken Nerd DVD:src}, but it ended up not being used on the DVD itself.

notes.en: This refers to the whole building, including the auditorium, lobby, dressing rooms, and so on.

much qach:n.hidden_notes: Maltz revealed this word to translate "Bloomsbury Theatre" for the {Festival of the Spoken Nerd DVD:src}, but it ended up not being used on the DVD itself.

notes.en: This refers to the location, such as a nightclub or restaurant, where there's food/drink along with a show ({Qe' much:n}).
The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:2}).[2]

The word for weather, meaning the state of the atmosphere, is the same word as for the atmosphere itself (see {muD:n:1}). When inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place, the expression {muD Dotlh:n} is used.[2]

The Klingon word for "weather" in the sense of the state of the atmosphere is just {muD:n:2}, the same word as for the atmosphere itself ({muD:n:1}). The expression {muD Dotlh:n:nolink} is used when inquiring about weather conditions at a specific time and/or place.[2]
This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown.

mugh:v.hidden_notes: This is similar to {magh:v}, and as the proverb goes, "a translator is a traitor".

notes.en: One of the more notable native animal forms on Neural.
This implies translation, and isn't used for closed captions.

mughbogh per:n.hidden_notes: This was actually given in the plural {mughbogh permey:n:nolink} as "subtitles".

notes.en: If this refers to a person, its plural takes the {-pu':n:suff} suffix. If it refers to a device, its plural takes the {-mey:n:suff} suffix.

examples.en: ▶ {vImuHlu' net wuqHa'!:sen}[2]

notes.en: Note that this means "be incorrect, factually wrong", as opposed to {waS:v} "be amiss, awry".

muj:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

notes.en: Do not confuse this with {waH:v:2}, which means "taste" in the sense of trying out food to see if it's been properly prepared or to determine if one likes it.[2]

mun:v.hidden_notes: People who joined the "Moon"ies were often subjected to a deprogramming process known as intervention.

notes.en: There is an idiom, {HoSghaj; mupwI' rur}.

definition.de: hassen, verabscheuen, starke Abneigung haben, Animositäten hegen

definition.en: I need a target that fights back.
definition.de: Ich brauche ein Ziel, das zurückschießt.

notes.en:
A {mutlhwI':n:nolink} is a person who puts things together.

A person who repairs things is a {tI'wI':n}. Most {mutlhwI'pu':n:nolink} are also {tI'wI'pu':n:nolink}.

When applied to {tlhIm:n}, {mutlh:v:nolink} means to assemble the carpet. The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}.

mutlh:v.hidden_notes: The original definition given on the {KLI mailing list:src} was "construct, assemble, put together". This word was also defined as "manufacture, construct, put together" in the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src} booklet.

examples.en:
▶ {ngogh mutlhwI':n} "bricklayer"
▶ {majyang mutlhwI':n} "tiler"
▶ {beb mutlhwI':n} "roofer"
▶ {'och mutlhwI':n} "plumber"
▶ {'ul pat mutlhwI':n} "electrician"

notes.en: The subject does the uniting, while the objects are united.

examples.en: ▶ {Qo'noS tuqmey muvchuqmoH qeylIS:sen:nolink} "Kahless united the tribes of Kronos"[1, p.179]

notes.en: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

definition.sv: trötta ord (används om äldre klingoners språk)

notes.en: This is how vocabulary used by older Klingons in everyday speech is referred to by younger Klingons.

definition.sv: slang, "färska ord" (används mest av yngre klingoner)

notes.en: This refers to the vocabulary used by younger Klingons.

mu'mey ghoQ:n.hidden_notes: This is defined only as "slang" in the {KGT:src} word lists, and erroneously written as {mu'mey qhoQ:n:nolink} in the K-E side. It is glossed as "fresh words" in the body text.

notes.en: Those who dislike slang refer to standard words using this expression.

definition.sv: tillfälliga ord (ogrammatiskt uttryck använt för effekt)

notes.en: This refers to words or phrases coined for a specific occasion, and which intentionally violate grammatical rules for impact.

definition.en: curse warfare, a kind of sport

notes.en: This word is used for the planning of an event, a battle strategy, etc., but not for the designing of a physical object (the word for that is {ren:v}).

examples.en: ▶ {nImbuS wej maghoS, He yInab.:sen}

notes.en: This word refers to the planning of an event, and not to the plan of a physical object (i.e., a blueprint, which would be a {pu'jIn:n}).
This word is never followed by the locative suffix {-Daq:n:suff}. ({TKD 3.3.5:src})

examples.en:
▶ {naDev tlhInganpu' tu'lu'.:sen}
▶ {naDev qaS wanI' ramqu'.:sen}

naDevvo' yIghoS!:sen.hidden_notes: There is a typo in {TKD:src}, an extra space after {naDev:sen:nolink}.

notes.en: This is a command given to an animal (or a subordinate) to fetch an object. It is in clipped Klingon.

definition.de: Sie wissen nicht, dass wir hier sind.
definition.zh_HK: 他們不知道我們在這裡。

naDev maH 'e' luSovbe'.:sen.hidden_notes: This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

definition.sv: ta avstånd ifrån, avslå, förkasta, förebrå

notes.en: This is the act of undoing someone's discommendation ({naDHa'ghach:n}).

nagh:n.hidden_notes: This is defined as "rock, stone" in {TKD:src} and as "ceramic material" in {KGT:src}.

definition.en: stone panel (artwork, similar to a painting)

notes.en: See {mIllogh:n} for a more general word for "picture".

nagh DIr:n.hidden_notes: It is unclear if this is considered a body part (i.e., takes {-Du':n:suff}), but it probably works the same way as for {DIr:n}.

notes.en: Known types of gemstones include {qevaS:n} and {Separ:n}.
By itself, {naH:n} usually refers to {Du' naH:n} rather than {naH tlhab:n}.[2]

This idiom refers to one's youthful days (a time before reaching an age considered appropriate for marriage). It was first spoken by {tlhI'yopatra':n:name}, in the play {'antonI' tlhI'yopatra' je:sen:nolink} by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}. In the popular Federation Standard version of the play, this is translated as "salad days".

examples.en: ▶ {naH jajmeywIj betleH vIyanbe'.:sen:nolink} "In my vegetable days, I did not wield a bat'leth."

notes.en: There is an idiom, {jejHa'; naH taj rur}.
This refers to fruits or vegetables not grown on a farm, as opposed to {Du' naH:n}.[1, p.89]

This word is also spelled {neHjej:n:nolink}.

Do not confuse this word with {naQjej:n}.

naHjej:n.hidden_notes: In the body text of {KGT:src}, this word is spelled {naHjej:n:nolink}, with a note that it literally means "sharp fruit".[1, p.88] However, it is spelled {neHjej:n:nolink} in both the E-K and K-E word lists.

notes.en: One typically {choptaH:v} on the nut, then {tlhIS:v} the pieces of shell.[1, p.87]

naH:v.hidden_notes: The first half of the example sentence was a lip-match for {ghaH vISammeH}. This word may also have been a back-fit for a mispronunciation of {naS:v} or {natlh:v:2}.

examples.en: ▶ {ghach jIvvo' naH. DaH pIghvamDaq So''eghtaH.@@ghach:v, jIvvo':n, naH:v, DaH:adv, pIgh:n, -vam:n, -Daq:n, So':v, -'egh:v, -taH:v} "There is a criminal hiding in these ruins."

notes.en: This verb can take the content or subject matter of a dream as an object.[2]
It seems that this word is composed of {nal:n:hyp}, a component found also in {loDnal:n} and {be'nal:n}, and {qaD:n}.

definition.en: the familiar beginning of a song

notes.en: After hearing just this short portion of the beginning of the song, a listener will recognize the tune.

definition.sv: holka ur, gröpa ur, gräva ur

notes.en: {HQ 10.2:src} says that this refers to "a particularly effective martial arts kick".

nan:v:3.hidden_notes: It's not entirely clear whether this is a verb or a noun.

definition.sv: vara fullständig, vara hel, vara total, vara komplett

notes.en: The verb {naQmoH:v@@naQ:v, -moH:v} is used for filling out forms (see {yu'muD:n}).

naQ:n:1.hidden_notes: This was defined as "cain, staff" in {TKDA:src}, but "cain" appears to have been a misspelling of "cane". It was subsequently glossed as "stick" in {HQ 12.2:src}.

notes.en: This may have originated with the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect's pronunciation of {DaQ:n}.[1, p.154]

definition.sv: pinne (används för att slå på slaginstrument)

notes.en:
Parts of a spear are its shaft {tIH:n:2} and its spearhead {QIn:n:2}. Types of spears include {ghIntaq:n:1} and {chonnaQ:n}.

Do not confuse this word with {naHjej:n}.
The Federation Standard name for this animal, "brush devil", has nothing to do with the Klingon name.
notes.de: Der deutsche Begriff "Bürstenteufel" hat nichts mit dem klingonischen Namen zu tun.

notes.en: This verb is used idiomatically with {'eb:n} to describe missed or lost opportunities.[4]

examples.en:
▶ {ghe'torvo' narghDI' qa'pu':sen}[2]
▶ {HeghDI' SuvwI' nargh SuvwI' qa'.:sen}[3]

definition.en: If the warrior's spirit has not escaped, the battle is still going on.
definition.de: Wenn der Geist eines Kriegers nicht enflohen ist, dauert die Schlacht noch an.
definition.zh_HK: 如果戰士的靈魂沒有逃脫,戰鬥仍在繼續。

definition.sv: vara illvillig, vara elak, vara hätsk, vara rasande

notes.en: There is an idiom, {naS; norgh rur}.[1, p.132]

definition.sv: sista posten i en lista, slutet på en lista
sista posten i en lista, slutet på en lista

natlh:v:1.hidden_notes: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means "to use something up completely".

definition.en: be reprehensible, be disgusting, be contemptible
definition.sv: vara förkastlig, vara äcklig, vara vidrig, vara usel, vara

notes.en: In its slang meaning, this verb does not take an object.[1, p.155]
A piece of paper has two {Dopmey:n@@Dop:n, -mey:n}.

nav:n.hidden_notes: This was originally defined as just "paper"[1], but was expanded to mean "sheet of paper" as well later.[4]

examples.en: ▶ {Quj wa'DIch MONOPOLY Huch nav qa' tlhIngan QaS:sen:nolink} "Klingon forces replace original MONOPOLY bills"[3]

notes.en: In context, {vaH:n} by itself is enough.
A {nawlogh:n:nolink} may or may not belong to a {yo':n}.

definition.sv: tillträda, komma åt, ha tillgång till

naw':v.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src}, this word is listed as a noun in the E-K side, and as a verb in the K-E side.

naw':n.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src}, this word is listed as a noun in the E-K side, and as a verb in the K-E side.

naw'wat:n.hidden_notes: NowWhat is a planet in {The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy:src}.

notes.en: {naychuq:v@@nay:v, -chuq:v} would be understood as a same-sex marriage between two women.[2]

nay:v.hidden_notes: MO confirmed at {qep'a' 4:src} that {Saw:v:nolink} and {nay:v:nolink} come from "sure" and "no" said with a Southern drawl.

na':v:1.hidden_notes: The chemical symbol for the element sodium is Na, from the Latin "natrium".

definition.en: be sure, be definite, be positive, be certain
definition.sv: vara säker, vara helt säker, vara viss

notes.en: This fruit is sweet. {na'ran rur} describes something sweet in taste.

na'ran:n.hidden_notes: The Sanskrit word for orange is "naarang".

neb:n:1.hidden_notes: "Neb" is an old English word for "nose", which is related to the modern word "nib".

notes.en: This word refers to nozzles on rockets, hoses, etc., and takes the plural suffix {-mey:n}.
This is associated with ritual and honor, and is much more than just a repository.
notes.de: Dies ist in Verbindung mit Ehre und Zeremonie, und nicht nur ein Behälter.

definition.de: seitlich, von der Seite, seitwärts bewegen
definition.sv: vara sidoställd, vara placerad åt/vid sidan, röra sig i sidled,

notes.en: The meaning of this word is similar to that of {QaS:n:1h}, but it includes officers ({yaS:n}).
It is unclear why Federation Standard corrupted the spelling of this word by adding an extraneous {qaghwI':n}.

definition.sv: bara, enbart, endast (kommer efter verb eller substantiv)

notes.en:
This follows the verb it modifies, and has the effect of trivializing the action.

This adverbial can also follow a noun, in which case it means "only" or "alone".

When this is the verb in the second sentence of a sentence-as-object construction, neither {'e':n:pro} nor {net:n:pro} are used.[1]

Watch a lesson on this word: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/JyeePTUXVa8}

neH:v.hidden_notes: The rule that {'e':n:pro} shouldn't be used has occasionally been violated in canon.

neHHa':adv.hidden_notes: The example Klingon sentence was presented to Marc Okrand by Chris Lipscombe. Okrand then translated it into English.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol neHHa' vIjatlh.:sen@@tlhIngan Hol:n, neHHa':adv, vI-:v, jatlh:v} "I speak not only Klingon", as in "I speak many languages including Klingon".

notes.en: See the example for an illustration of the difference between this word and {Sam:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {'avwI' nejDI' narghta'bogh qama' reH 'avwI' Sambej.:sen}

definition.en: (It is) a probe of ancient origin.
be mature, be grown-up, be adult

examples.en:
▶ {qaSDI' nenghep, qa' patlh chu' chav tlhIngan SuvwI'. poSDaq nIHDaq je QamtaHvIS SuvwI'pu'. chaH jojDaq yItnIS lopwI'. luchovmeH 'oy'naQmey lo'.:sen:nolink}
  "The Age of Ascension marks a new level of spiritual attainment by a Klingon warrior. The initiate must pass through a gauntlet of warriors who test him with painsticks."[2]

notes.en: This is smaller than a {SIla':n}.

neSlo':n.hidden_notes: Moroni Olsen was the voice of the Magic Mirror in Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs".

notes.en:
This pronoun is used in a sentence-as-object construction when the second sentence has an indefinite third-person subject (i.e., "one" or "someone").

Sometimes, {'e':n:pro} with {-lu':v} is used instead of {net:n:pro,nolink}. It is not clear why at the moment.

examples.en:
(using {X net Y:sen:nolink})
▶ {qama'pu' DIHoH net Sov:sen:nolink} "One knows we kill prisoners."[1, p.66]
▶ {Qu'vaD lI' net tu'bej.:sen} "One certainly finds it useful for the mission."[1, p.66]
▶ {Duj ghajchugh pagh, beylI'vo' 'oH Daje' net chaw'.:sen:nolink} "If (the ship is) unowned, you may buy it from the Bank."[3]

(using {X 'e' Y-lu':sen:nolink})
▶ {yInlu'taH 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Survival must be earned."[2]
▶ {yay chavlu' 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Victory must be earned."[2]
▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[3]
▶ {Qang QanmeH yan 'ISletlh Damuv 'e' wIvlu'.:sen:nolink} "You are chosen to serve on the Yan-Isleth and protect the Chancellor."[3]

notes.en: Note that the Klingon word for "ten thousand" is independent of the words for "ten" ({maH:n:2,num}) and "thousand" ({SaD:n}).

definition.en: myriad (a period of ten thousand years)

notes.en: To indicate "tens of thousands of years ago" or "tens of thousands of years from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[1]

definition.en: type of pot with handles (used for food preparation)
definition.sv: en slags skål med handtag (används vid matberedning)

notes.en: Its handles are called {DeSqIvDu':n:nolink} (see {DeSqIv:n}).
This refers to an everyday sarcophagus, which is strictly utilitarian.
notes.de: Dies ist der Begriff für einen normalen, alltäglichen Sarg.

nev'aQ:n.hidden_notes: Maltz said that {nev'aQ:n:nolink} and {nebeylI':n:nolink} ({nev'aQ:n:nolink} more frequently) are used for some sort of flying coffins.

notes.en: This is the 9th rank of {yaS:n}.
{chaH:n}/{bIH:n}:{SoH:n} = {nI-:v:pref,nolink}

The subject of {nIb:v:nolink} are the things which are identical.[2]

The use of this verb does not suggest in what way the things are identical, except when it is used in the following construction.

This verb is used to express the concept that two things have the same amount of some quality, in a similar manner to {rap:v}, but with the connotation of preciseness. If the quality is a measurable one, the connotation is that the two things have exactly the same amount of that quality. See the example below.[3]

examples.en: ▶ {'ugh ro'qegh'Iwchab, nIb raHta'.:sen:nolink} "The racht is as heavy as the rokeg blood pie." (i.e., they are exactly the same weight)[3]

notes.en: See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

nIH:v.hidden_notes: In slang, to "nick" something is to steal it.

examples.en: {puH nIl:n}

notes.en: Milk is seldom consumed by itself, but the milk of some creatures, such as the {targh:n}, is combined with other ingredients to create more complex drinks.[1, p.95]
This is how Klingons might refer to a lump or block ({ngogh:n:nolink}) of Terran cheese.

definition.de: Wir fliegen zu Nimbus III. Plan den Kurs.

nImbuS wej maghoS, He yInab.:sen.hidden_notes: The prefix should have been {wI-:v} instead of {ma-:v}.

definition.en: The Starship Enterprise has been dispatched to Nimbus III.
definition.de: Man hat das Raumschiff Enterprise nach Nimbus III geschickt.

definition.en: How much fuel do we have?

nIn 'ar wIghaj?:sen.hidden_notes: In {TKD p.170:src} and {CK:src}, this is given as "How much fuel do we have left?"

notes.en: This word describes an activity best translated using the verb "weave", some forms of which involve sticks called {Hut'Inmey tIq:n:nolink}.

nIq:v.hidden_notes: MO revealed this word after being asked about the Klingon word for "knit", and despite defining it to mean "weave", it's fairly clear that it also applies to knitting and crocheting.

notes.en: To use such a device, one may {qIp:v}, {'uy:v}, or {ngaH:v} it, depending on the particular device. The hole punch will {ghID:v} the paper (or other material).

nIqHom:n.hidden_notes: Ada Lovelace wrote that the Analytical Engine "weaves algebraical patterns" (see {nIq:v}) in the manner of the Jacquard loom. Its software was written on punch cards (see {nIqDob:n}).

notes.en: This is used for a major software update (e.g., 2.x to 3.x).

definition.sv: hindra, störa, avbryta, lägga sig i

nIS:v.hidden_notes:
This is defined in {TKD:src} as "hinder, interfere" and in {TKDA:src} as "disrupt, interfere (with)".

"Trespassing vessel" was translated as {nISbogh Duj:n:nolink} in a deleted scene from the 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie.

examples.en:
▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink}
  "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[3]

notes.en: These are powerful disruptors mounted on a ship.

definition.de: alleine, einsam, auf sich selbst gestellt

definition.en: A warrior does not let a friend face danger alone.
definition.de: Ein Krieger lässt einen Freund nicht allein der Gefahr entgegentreten.

examples.en: ▶ {nISwI' - cha' chang'engmey (telDaq lujomlu', nItebHa' lubaHlu'):sen:nolink} "Disruptor - 2 pairs (Wing Mounted, Fire Linked)[1]

notes.en:
This word refers to any digit on the hand, including the thumb.

Klingon has five verbs corresponding to each of the {nItlh:n:nolink}: {Sen:v}, {SIq:v}, {qay:v}, {qew:v}, and {qan:v:2}. In addition, when referring to a child's thumb, {rIl:v:1} is used instead of {Sen:v}.

Correspondingly, the fingers are called {SenwI':n} ({rIlwI':n} if it belongs to a child), {SIqwI':n}, {qaywI':n}, {qewwI':n}, and {qanwI':n}.

See {SIq:v} for an explanation of the usage of these finger verbs.

nItlh:n.hidden_notes: The verbs for the fingers come from names of the Finger Lakes in New York State.

notes.en: This is slang for {rItlh naQ:n}.
This refers to a computer input device.

definition.en: flat end of a pigment stick

examples.en: ▶ {Dujeychugh jagh nIv yItuHQo'.:sen}

notes.en: One of the designers of the {BoP:src} poster. See {bIl jo'rIj:n:name}.

examples.en: ▶ {lu'oghta' nIylo roDIS bIl jo'rIj je:sen:nolink} "Designed By: Nilo Rodis & Bill George"

notes.en: This refers to something that seems to appear, but isn't really there. It does not refer to a ghost or spirit, and is quite different from {qa':n}.

nIyma':n.hidden_notes: This refers to a {Saarbrücken qepHom'a':src} participant named "Nima" who never showed up. Also, in German, "niemand" means "nobody".

notes.en: Don't confuse this word with {tIq:v}.
See also {much:v} for the idea of "presenting" a gift to someone.

▶ {chorghSaD qelI'qam HIvchuq'e' vInoH.:sen}

definition.en: In war, there is nothing more honorable than victory.
definition.de: Im Krieg gibt es nichts ehrenvolleres als den Sieg.
definition.zh_HK: 在戰爭中,沒有事比勝利更光榮的。

en: there is nothing more honourable than victory.

notes.en: In the dialect of this region, toasts do not use special grammar, and the subject follows the verb in toasts just as they do in regular sentences (see {-jaj:v}).

noHva'Dut Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.26 and not in the glossary. It appears as {noHva'Dut:n:nolink} and not as {noHva'Dut Sep:n:nolink}, but it is implied that this is the name of a region (see {Sep:n}).

noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'l.entry_name: noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.

definition.en: Destroying an empire to win a war is no victory, and ending a battle to save an empire is no defeat.
definition.de: Ein Reich zerstören, um einen Krieg zu gewinnen, ist kein Sieg, und eine Schlacht zu beenden, um ein Reich zu schützen, ist keine Niederlage.

examples.en: ▶ {tIqIpqu' 'ej nom tIqIp.:sen}

nompuq:n.hidden_notes: The phrase "citation needed" is associated with Wikipedia. "Wiki" means "quick" ({nom:adv}) and "pedia" means "education, child-rearing" ({puq:n}).

definition.sv: vara rutten, vara murken, vara skämd

notes.en: There is a Klingon idiom, {nong; vulqangan rur}, which is meant ironically.

nop:v.hidden_notes: "NOP" is a no-op, a computer command to do nothing.

definition.en: type of animal, norg (shark-like sea creature)

notes.en: There is an idiom, {naS; norgh rur}.[1, p.132]

definition.sv: äta i små munfullar, nafsa på

notes.en: The use of this verb is derogatory (except for children and pets).

noS:v.hidden_notes: This is the Yiddish word for nibble, "nosh". It's also similar to the German verb "naschen".

examples.en: ▶ {not jegh tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "A Klingon warrior never surrenders."[2]

definition.en: No Klingon ever breaks his word.
definition.de: Ein Klingone bricht nie sein Wort.
Ich habe ihn/sie noch nie vorher gesehen.

notes.en: It is nowhere near as large as a {qa'rol:n}, which is really big.

▶ {notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.:sen}
▶ {notlh tonSaw'lIj.:sen} "Your fighting technique is obsolete."

notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.:s.entry_name: notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.

definition.de: Der Krieg ist überholt, aber wir werden bald auch überholt sein.

notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.:s.hidden_notes: The first part of this sentence, {notlh veS:sen:nolink}, appears on {KGT p.47:src}.

no'negh:n.hidden_notes: Pun: the smell of rotten ({non:v}) egg.

notes.en: {ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n}:{maH:n:1h} = {nu-:v:pref,nolink}

examples.en: ▶ {qeylIS bov nubwI':n}

notes.en: Watch Gowron say {nuchpu':n@@nuch:n, -pu':n}: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/VEQMLy2X2Y8}

definition.en: society; group of people with shared culture
definition.de: Gesellschaft (Gruppe von Leuten mit gemeinsamer Kultur)

notes.en: Do not confuse this with a society in the scholarly sense, which is called a {yej'an:n}.[3]

nughQeD:n.hidden_notes: This word was used in the title of a thesis in sociology, "Klingon as Linguistic Capital: A Sociologic Study of Nineteen Advanced Klingonists" {Hol Sup 'oH tlhIngan Hol'e'; wa'maH Hut tlhIngan Hol po'wI' nughQeD:sen:nolink}, by Yens Wahlgren. This usage was approved by MO.[1]

definition.de: jdn. die Fingerknöchel in den Kopf drehen

examples.en:
▶ {Hoch nuH qel:sen}
▶ {vISeHmeH Hoch nuHmey Qay!:sen}

A {nuH bey':n:nolink} has one {betleH:n}, one {naQjej:n}, and one {ghob'etlh:n:hyp}.[1]

nuH bey':n.hidden_notes: There is also a picture of one on {TKW p.124:src}.

definition.en: You have chosen your weapon, so fight!
definition.de: Du hast deine Waffen gewählt, also kämpfe!
definition.zh_HK: 你選擇了你的武器,打啦!

notes.en: This word means "promote" both in the sense of increasing someone's rank and in the sense of advertising an activity or advocating for a cause.

num:v.hidden_notes: The "Friend of Maltz" certificates are considered by some to be non-canon.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Danummo' pIquvmoH.} "Because you promote the Klingon language, we honor you."[2]
▶ {Danumlu'. Sa' Damoj.} "Promoted to General."[3]
▶ {qum DuSaQmeyDaq 'Irghbe'meH ghotpu' nabmey ghojmoH, 'ej pIj tay'taH Doch pIm num.:sen:nolink} "In public schools, it teaches procedures so that people don't bully, and it promotes Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations."[4]

notes.en: To refer to the preceding day, month, or year, consider using {Hu':n}, {wen:n}, and {ben:n:1}, respectively.

nung:v.hidden_notes: While {nungbogh:v:nolink} precedes a noun, {veb:v:nolink} comes after one.

nup:v.hidden_notes: MO confirmed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {nup:v:nolink} is intransitive.

notes.en:
This word fits into a sentence in the place which would be occupied by the answer.[1] It works like a pronoun in questions with "to be" in the English translations.[2]

Questions in English often map more naturally to imperatives in Klingon. If you want to ask a "what" question, consider using a command with a verb such as {ngu':v} instead.[2]  For example, consider {per:v}, {ja':v}, {Del:v}, etc.

Also, note that "What are your orders?" is expressed in Klingon as {chay' jura'?:sen} See {chay':ques}.

examples.en:
▶ {yIH nuq?:sen:nolink} "What is a tribble?"[2]
▶ {nuq mI'lIj?:sen}[3]
▶ {Dochvam nuq?:sen:nolink} "What is this?"[3]

notes.en: This is just {nuq:ques} plus {-Daq:n:suff}.

definition.en: Where do I put this? What do I do with this?
definition.de: Wo stelle ich das hin? Was soll ich damit tun?

notes.en: To ask where a person is, {ghaH:n} should be used instead of {'oH:n}. {nuqDaq ghaH ...'e'?:sen:nolink} "Where is ...?"

examples.en:
▶ {nuqDaq 'oH bIQ'a' HeH'e'?:sen} "Where is the beach?"
▶ {nuqDaq 'oH puchpa''e'?:sen} "Where is the bathroom?"
▶ {nuqDaq 'oH juHlIj'e'?:sen} "Where do you live?  Where is your home?"
▶ {nuqDaq 'oH Qe' QaQ'e'?:sen} "Where is a good restaurant?"

definition.en: Where do you live? Where is your home?
definition.de: Wo wohnst du? Wo ist dein Zuhause?

notes.en: Watch a lesson on this phrase: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/EMipQm5JZgI}

definition.en: Where do you keep the chocolate?
what did you say? huh? what?

notes.en: This is in clipped Klingon. The grammatical way to ask "What did you say?" would be {nuq Dajatlh?:sen@@nuq:ques, Da-:v, jatlh:v}

nuq mI'lIj?:sen.hidden_notes: In {CK:src}, the Klingon hotel clerk asks the Terran visitor, {nuq mI'lIj, tera'ngan?:sen:nolink} But this question works as well for telephone numbers as it does for hotel guest numbers.

notes.en: This is the name of a Class M planet which is home to the mugato.

definition.de: Sie haben uns ohne Zweifel ausgetrickst!

notes.en: This means "They've definitely tricked us!"
This refers to physical stability. To refer to an unstable person, use {ngIj:v}.[1, p.150]

examples.en: ▶ {targhlIj yIngagh, yIruch!:sen}

notes.en: The object of this verb is the thing that you squeeze, for example, {Ha'on vevwI':n} or {nIqDob:n}.
Don't confuse this word with {run:v}.

definition.sv: vara seg, vara läderaktig (i konsistensen), vara fast (ha tuggmotstånd)

ngal:v.hidden_notes: This is the Cantonese word for "bite" or "chew" (咬).

definition.en: be locked, be sealed, be secured, be fastened
definition.sv: vara låst, vara förseglad, vara säkrad, vara fäst

notes.en:
There is an idiomatic expression, {ngaQ lojmIt:sen}, which means that an outcome is unavoidable or a course of action irrevocable.

For "locking" onto a target, see {'uch:v:1}, and also consider {buS:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {yIngaQmoH!:sen}

notes.en: One can say {mab ngaQmoH:sen@@mab:n, ngaQmoH:v} and so on, but this is a special argot or frozen form. It may have been shortened from an earlier phrase, such as {mab Hung lojmIt ngaQmoH:sen@@mab:n, Hung:n, lojmIt:n, ngaQmoH:v}.

ngaQHa'moHwI':n.hidden_notes: For something like a keycard, some Klingon speakers unofficially use {lojmIt chaw':n:nolink}.

notes.en: This idiomatic expression means that a situation has an unavoidable outcome, or a plan or commitment is firm and cannot be changed.
The object is the thing being contained. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

ngat:n:1.hidden_notes: Gunpowder was discovered in China during the Tang dynasty.

notes.en: This is mixed with {tIr:n} and used to {pID:v:1} food.[1, p.89]

ngat:n:2.hidden_notes: The Japanese word "karaage" (唐揚げ), referring to food prepared this way, has Tang (as in the Chinese dynasty) as its first character.

definition.en: mixing stick with flattened, paddlelike end

notes.en: This is a {DuDwI':n} with a paddlelike end.

ngay':n.hidden_notes: An English definition has never been given for this word. Its meaning is inferred from the only example of its usage.

examples.en: ▶ {wo' ngay' bochoqmeH bowIvlu'pu'!:sen:nolink} "You have been chosen to preserve the glory of the Empire!"[1]

notes.en: The subject of this verb is all the involved parties.

nga'chuq:v.hidden_notes: The gloss is actually given as "sex (i.e., perform sex; always subject)". The fact that this verb indicates that the subject, which must be plural, are engaged in sexual intercourse with each other, was confirmed in July 2013.

definition.sv: vara förfalskad, vara falsk, vara oäkta

notes.en: To express what was done to bait someone, use this verb with {-meH:v}, e.g., "use a spaceship in order to lure/attract/tempt them".
This literally means "attracter" or "lurer".
There is an idiom, {tlhab; ngem Ha'DIbaH rur}.[1, p.132]
This idiomatic expression means that something is complex. It is often used in the form {ngem Sarghmey tlha'laH:sen:nolink} to describe someone who is capable of a difficult feat.

The shore of a lake is its {ngeng HeH:n}.

The lava-filled area of a volcano ({qulHuD:n}) is called its {qul ngeng:n}.[2]

This refers specifically to the shore of a lake. The shore of an ocean would be called a {bIQ'a' HeH:n}, and so on.

In the {paq'batlh:src}, the expression {qul ngeng HeH:n:nolink} is used to refer to the shore of the {qul ngeng:n} inside {QIStaq:n}, where the environment is so hostile to life that not even {tlheng'IQ:n} would grow.
This is a giant mythical creature which {qotar:n} fought for a day.[1]

ngengroQ:n.hidden_notes: The origin of this word appears to be a mistranslation by Bing translator, which turns "sea creature" into {ngeng roQ:sen:nolink} (with a space). This was then retroactively "vetted" by Marc Okrand after the book's publication.[2]

notes.en: In some {meqro'vaq Sep:n} dialects, this refers to any stairway but a {choghvat:n}, which is called a {letlh:n:2} there.

definition.en: bump into, run into, collide with
definition.sv: stöta på, springa in i, kollidera med

notes.en: This describes the collision of something moving with something stationary.[1] Unlike {paw':v:1}, {ngeQ:v:nolink} has an innocent party.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIlHal yIngev!} "Sell the mine!"[2, p.191]

notes.en: This word refers to a person, although it can be used to translate the word "store" or "shop". In {TNK:src}, "Where is the shop?" is translated as {nuqDaq ghaH ngevwI''e'?:sen:nolink} Note that {ghaH:n} is used rather than {'oH:n}.

examples.en: {Ha'quj nge':sen:idiom}

definition.en: ankle (also a slang term of deprecation)
definition.de: Fußknöchel (kann umgangssprachlich eine abwertende Bedeutung haben)

definition.sv: vara bråkig, vara stökig, vara oregerlig, vara bångstyrig

notes.en: Based on the {SkyBox 21:src} example, this means "have the courage to do something", rather than "provoke or challenge someone".

ngIl:v.hidden_notes: The example appears to be missing a conjunction.

examples.en:
▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink}
  "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[2]

definition.en: be negatively charged, have a negative charge

ngIng:v.hidden_notes: This was defined as "have a negative charge" in the {qep'a' 2016:src} booklet, but was confirmed to be stative afterwards.

definition.sv: vara rutten, vara äcklig, vara vidrig

notes.en: This word is used in {TNK:src} in the sentence {nuqDaq puH Duj vIngIp?:sen:nolink} to mean "Where can I hire (rent) a car?" However, it's not clear that the Klingon sentence expresses the idea that the car is to be borrowed for money.

This noun indicates that a single thing is being considered apart from others, or that a sequence of identical things is considered one after another. Like {Hoch:n} and {'op:n}, it precedes what it modifies.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIlHal yIngIv!} "Patrol the mine!"[2, p.191]
▶ {jogh veH lungIv.} "They patrol the quadrant border."[2, p.194]

notes.en: This verb is also used to express "pressurized" (as in what happens inside an airplane cabin). Air pressure would usually be expressed in units of {chebmey:n@@cheb:n, -mey:n} per {morgh:n}. To indicate that the air pressure is correct, the expression is {ngI'chu' muD:sen@@ngI':v, -chu':v, muD:n:1} or {ngI'chu' lay:sen@@ngI':v, -chu':v, lay:n:2h}. To indicate that this is the result of a process, one might say {ngI'choHchu'pu' muD:sen@@ngI':v, -choH:v, -chu':v, -pu':v, muD:n:1}.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'.:sen:nolink} "There, the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire."[2]

ngoDHom:n.hidden_notes: "Trekbits" was translated as {Hov leng ngoDHommey:n:nolink} in {STC 104:src}.

notes.en: This refers to a person who assembles bricks into something, such as a wall or a building.
Klingons don't have pillows, but Maltz said this is what he would call one if he had to call it something.

definition.en: move bat'leth from horizontal to vertical orientation
definition.de: Bat'leth von waagerechte in senkrechte Position drehen
definition.sv: förflytta en bat'leth från horisontell till vertikal position

notes.en: This word describes someone who is really into something and knows a lot about it, but doesn't necessarily partake in related activities.
This word describes someone who is really into something and knows a lot about it, but doesn't necessarily partake in related activities.

The subject of {ngon:v:nolink} (for example a liquid such as boiling water) produces or forms bubbles. A person blowing through a straw into a glass of water to make bubbles would be the subject of {ngonmoH:v@@ngon:v, -moH:v}.
See the example under {So'wI':n}.

The subject of this verb is the thing which is undergoing dissolution.

This word is also found in the archaic expression {ngoS tlhogh cha:sen:nolink} (see {tlhogh:n}), which is said during the ritual of divorce.[2]
This means "be accountable, be answerable". It can also be used in the sense of "be trustworthy, sensible, dependable".[2]

examples.en: ▶ {vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj; vangDI' qorDu'Daj ngoy' tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen}

notes.en:
Note that in Klingon, there is a different word for "be old (not new)" ({ngo':v:nolink}) than for "be old (not young)" ({qan:v:1}).

This word is applied to objects or ideas.[2]

This adverbial is used mainly to emphasize that one event occurred at the same time as another. It does not mean "at some (vague) time in the past" or "at some (unknown) time in the future".[1]

For a verb with a similar meaning, see {quq:v}. For an idiom meaning "by that time", see {pumDI':sen}.

Note that "then" in the sense of "subsequently" is {ghIq:adv}.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {DungluQ tIHIv. ngugh Qongbe' chaH.:sen:nolink} "Attack them at noon! They won't be sleeping then."[1]

notes.en: If a bird lands on land, the verb {Saq:v} is used, and if on water, then {tlhot:v}.

definition.en: authority, power, one in authority or in charge
definition.sv: auktoritet, befogenhet, makt, någon med auktoritet eller i

notes.en: This refers to the faction that controls most of the Gamma Quadrant.

definition.sv: vara arrogant, vara inbilsk, vara högfärdig, vara egenkär

notes.en: This is an undesirable trait.
There is no "upper case" or "lower case" in the Klingon writing system. {ngutlh tIn:n@@ngutlh:n, tIn:v} and {ngutlh mach:n@@ngutlh:n, mach:v} can be used for these, respectively.[2]

ngutlh:n.hidden_notes: This was defined as "letter, written character". The additional definition "glyph" comes from {jItuj'ep ngutlh:n:nolink}.

examples.en: {jItuj'ep ngutlh:n}

notes.en: For "bold", {pI':v} may be used. For "italics", {chongHa':v@@chong:v:1, -Ha':v} may be used.

definition.en: be dyed, be stained, be tinted
definition.sv: vara färgad, vara fläckad, vara tonad

notes.en:
This word is seldom used except in the question {chay' nguv?:sen:nolink} or when suffixed with {-moH:v} to form {nguvmoH:v}.[1, p.82]

Besides {chIS:v} and {qIj:v}, there are only two known color words in Klingon, {Doq:v} and {SuD:v:1}. The latter two words are suffixed with {-qu':v}, and/or combined with {wov:v} and {Hurgh:v}, to refer to more specific colors. To be even more specific, comparisons are used, such as {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen}.
A "what" question in English is often best translated into Klingon using the imperative form of this or a similar verb.[2]

Some possible objects of this verb are {pab:n}, {chut:n}, {nab:n}, {'Ip:n}, and {lurDech:n}.

In the context of a vow or promise which has been made (see {'Ip:v} and {lay':v}), {pab:v:nolink} means "to keep" or "to fulfill".[2]
This describes an obviously deliberate slight bending of grammatical rules, a common way to construct {mu'mey ru':n}.
See {jej:v} and {jejHa':v} for two idiomatic expressions involving {pach:n:nolink}.

definition.sv: nollte (om något som inte har hänt)

notes.en: This is used to describe something that was expected to occur, or could conceivably occur, but has not.

examples.en: ▶ {pawpu' 'avwI' paghDIch:sen:nolink} "the zeroth guard has arrived" (no guard has arrived even though one or more are expected)

notes.en: This is an emphatic alternative for {not:adv}.

examples.en: ▶ {paghlogh jegh tlhIngan SuvwI':sen:nolink} "A Klingon warrior never surrenders", literally, "A Klingon warrior surrenders zero times".

notes.en: In Klingon, the conjunction {pagh:conj} cannot be used to present two options to someone, such as "surrender or die". {bIjegh pagh bIHegh:sen:nolink} means "you're surrendering or you're dying" (as if the speaker is not sure which is happening). Instead, the sentence must be recast as "If you don't surrender, you will die". See {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen} for further information.

paH:n.hidden_notes: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "gown". In {TNK:src}, it is used for "dress", while {paH bID:n} is used for "skirt".

examples.en: ▶ {pan qeylIS betleH 'ej jach molor 'etlh HoS:sen:nolink} "Kahless's bat'leth sparks, And Molor's mighty sword roars."[2]

paq:n:1.hidden_notes: The Klingon Dictionary was published by Pocket Books. See also {buq:n}.

notes.en: The son of Torghn ({torghen:n:name}), and the main character of the holodeck simulation in {KCD:src}.

This is the name of a book recounting the legendary life and deeds of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}. Note that the name of the book is in {no' Hol:n}, and that in modern standard Klingon "Book of Honor" would be {batlh paq:n:nolink}; the apostrophe represents what may be a missing grammatical element that would explain the transposition.[1]

The {paq'batlh:n:nolink} is divided into three major parts, titled respectively {paq'yav:n:nolink} "Ground Book", {paq'raD:n:nolink} "Force Book", and {paq'QIH:n:nolink} "Impact Book".

See also {tIq'ghob:n:hyp} for a hypothetical similar grammatical construction.
This word can (but doesn't have to) take an object indicating what is being meditated about or reflected upon. It does not connote "entreat", so "pray" may not be an appropriate translation.
notes.de: Dieses Wort (muss aber nicht) ein Objekt haben, welches das Thema ist, über das man nachdenkt. Es enthält nicht die Bedeutung von "anflehen", daher ist "beten" keine passende Übersetzung.

definition.en: a mid-sized bird with particularly garish coloring (at least from a Klingon point of view)
definition.de: ein mittelgroßer Vogel mit sehr grellen Farben (jedenfalls aus der Sicht eines Klingonen)
definition.sv: en slags fågel (mellanstorlek, med särskilt grälla färger)

parbIng:n.hidden_notes: In golf, "one under par" ({bIng:n} means "under") is known as a "birdie", and golfers have traditionally worn garishly coloured clothing.

en: a mid-sized bird with particularly garish colouring

pargh:v.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}

notes.en: Love, Klingon style -- with much more intense connotations than the English word.
This word is rarely used in direct address. Instead, couples call each other by {bang pong:n}.[1, p.199]

definition.de: Du bist meine Liebe (d.h. romantischer Partner).

notes.en: See {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} for an idiomatic expression related to lateness, and {'eb:n} for some examples of how to express the concept of "too late".
This word is plural. It is unknown if a singular form exists.

This refers to systems in the physical (or physical-like) sense, as opposed to a methodology, which is {Ho'DoS:n}.[2]

Note that the Klingon term for a star system is {Hovtay':n}.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

definition.sv: rang, grad (i regering och militär), nivå, ställning, status, anseende

examples.en:
▶ {Hung buv rav; patlh Hut:sen:nolink} "Classified Level 9 and Above"[3]
▶ {qaSDI' nenghep, qa' patlh chu' chav tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "The Age of Ascension marks a new level of spiritual attainment by a Klingon warrior."[4]
▶ {SIQwI' lu'oy'moHmeH juppu'Daj 'oy'naQmey lo' chaH. SuvwI' qa' patlh veb chavlaHmeH tlhIngan lo'chu' chaH. toDujDaj toblu'.:sen:nolink} "The Painstik is employed by friends of the recipent who use the devices to inflict pain in a manner which will allow the Klingon to attain a higher state of spirituality as a warrior, proving his mettle."[5]

definition.en: be ranked, have a status, be graded; be sorted

notes.en: To sort a list of English words alphabetically, use a construction such as {wa'DIch a, HochDIch z:sen:nolink} (or {wa'DIch z, HochDIch a:sen:nolink} for reverse order). For Klingon words, use {wa'DIch bay, HochDIch qaghwI':sen:nolink} or {wa'DIch qaghwI', HochDIch bay:sen:nolink}. To reverse a list, use {DopmoH:v@@Dop:v, -moH:v}.[2]

When used with the "compare" meaning, the object of the verb must be plural. The implication is that the things are ranked in comparison to one another.[1]

The object of {patlhmoH:v:nolink}, when used to mean "sort", is not a list (as a whole) but the things in the list, the things to be ranked or sorted.[2]

definition.sv: vara brådskande, vara angelägen, vara akut

examples.en: ▶ {Qugh la'vaD QIn pav.:sen:nolink} "Urgent message for Commander Kruge."[2]

notes.en:
{paw:v:nolink} works in a similar way to {jaH:v}.[2]

Do not confuse this with {paw':v:1}.

examples.en:
▶ {Duj vIpaw.:sen:nolink} or {DujDaq vIpaw.:sen:nolink} (the {-Daq:n} is optional) "I arrive at the ship."
▶ {DujDaq jIpaw.:sen:nolink} "I arrive on the ship."  That is, "I arrive via the ship."

notes.en: This was shortened over time from {pawmeH 'aD:n@@paw:v, -meH:v, 'aD:n}.

The verb {paw':v:nolink} always takes a plural subject, namely, the things in motion which collide. When the subject is people, the verb is usually interpreted with the slang meaning of "butting heads" (see {paw':v:2,slang}). To describe the collision of something moving with something stationary, use {ngeQ:v} instead.[2; 3]

Do not confuse this with {paw:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {pe'vIl Supaw'jaj!:sen}

notes.en: As with the literal usage of this verb (see {paw':v:1}), when used in its slang meaning, it also takes a plural subject, in this case the people who butt heads. To say that two people collide without implying that they are butting heads, {ngeQ:v} might be used with {-chuq:v:suff}.[1]

pay:v.hidden_notes: Another way of saying "You'll regret this!" is "You'll pay for this!"

pay'Ha':adv.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

pay'an:n.hidden_notes: The name of the consonant "p" in Klingon is {pay:sen:nolink}, and "an" is an article in English, so "p-article".

notes.en:
This word is homophonous with {pa':n:2}. However, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} unambiguously means "in the room".

The {bIS'ub:n} of a {pa':n:1} is its {rav:n:1}, and its {'aqroS:n:1} is its {rav'eq:n}. If the {pa':n:1} is in the top story of a {qach:n}, then its {rav'eq:n} is called its {pa' beb:n}. The walls of a {pa':n:1} are {tlhoy':n}; if the other side of a wall is {Hur:n}, then the wall is also called a {pa' reD:n}. The word {tlhoy':n} can refer to any side of a room; a ceiling/floor between stories is called a {tlhoy' SaS:n}.

pa':n:1.hidden_notes: This word is defined as "room" in {TKD:src}, as "enclosed area" in {KGT:src}, and as "chamber" in {BoP:src} (see {cha'puj pa':n}).

notes.en: This word is homophonous with {pa':n:1}. As a locative, {pa':n:2} never takes the suffix {-Daq:n:suff}, and can only mean "there" ({TKD 3.3.5:src}). In contrast, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} can only mean "in the room".

definition.sv: innertak (i ett rum högst upp en byggnad eller konstruktion)

notes.en: This refers to the ceiling of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure. If there are rooms above it, then it is a {rav'eq:n}.[1]

en: ceiling of a top storey room

notes.en: In comparison, {'op ret:n@@'op:n, ret:n} means "at some point in the past".

pa'logh:n.hidden_notes: In German, the word for "in the past" is "damals", which can be pulled apart as "da" ("there", {pa':n:2}) and "mal(s)" ("times", {-logh:n:num,suff}).

notes.en:
{tlhIH:n}:{pagh:n:1h} = {pe-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)

Generally, when a verb describing a state of being is used as an imperative, the suffixes {-'egh:v} and {-moH:v} are used with it.[2]
This is soaked in {chanDoq:n} and eaten.

There is no known noun or verb for blizzard, but one can say {peDqu':sen@@peD:v, -qu':v}, {pe'vIl peD:sen@@pe'vIl:adv, peD:v}, or even {pe'vIl peDqu':sen@@pe'vIl:adv, peD:v, -qu':v}.[2]

This verb can also be used for other things whose falling motion resembles snowfall, for example breadcrumbs, confetti, or ashes. The falling thing is the subject.[3]

peD:v.hidden_notes: The example line appeared in the Kate Bush album "50 Words for Snow".

examples.en: ▶ {peDtaH 'ej chIS qo':sen@@peD:v, -taH:v, 'ej:conj, chIS:v, qo':n} "It's snowing and the world is white."[4]

notes.en: This verb can also be used without an object. See {pegh:v:2}.

pegh:v:1.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src}, this is defined in the K-E side as "keep something secret", and in the E-K side as "secret, keep something secret".

notes.en:
See {rav:n:2} for an example of how to talk about classified information.

This verb can also be used with an object. See {pegh:v:1}.

examples.en:
▶ {pegh De'vetlh.@@pegh:v:2, De':n, -vetlh:n} "That is classified information."[1]
▶ {De' pegh vIghaj.@@De':n, pegh:v:2, vI-:v, ghaj:v} "I have secret information."[2]

notes.en:
These are a set of proverbs which are most frequently used in situations where the speaker wishes to show that he or she can keep a secret under any condition.[2]

This is also infrequently shortened to {pegh vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.[1]
There is an idiomatic expression {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} "before it breaks its shell", meaning "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".
This literally means "before it breaks its shell", and as an idiomatic expression it has the meaning of "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".

examples.en: ▶ {pel'aQDaj ghorpa' qama' yIHoH.:sen:nolink} "Kill the prisoner now, while you've got a chance."

notes.en: This refers to the part of the day when it is light out (as opposed to {ram:n}).[2]
A planet in the Cardassian Union.
Known types of Klingon torpedoes include the {pach peng:n}, {moratlh ro':n}, and {notqa' pach:n}.

peng:n.hidden_notes: "Ping" is the sonar sound made by submarines.

examples.en: ▶ {'otlh peng:n}

pep:v.hidden_notes: A "pep" rally raises a team's spirits.

notes.en: This word connotes intention, targeting specific victims.

peq:v.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.

examples.en: ▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people."
▶ {bISuvtaHvIS qarDaS bIghHa' peQ botjan Daveghchu'.:sen:nolink} "Fight your way beyond magnetic shield of Cardassian prison."[2]

peQchem:n.hidden_notes: This is written as {peQ chem:n:nolink} (with a space) in {TKDA:src}. The space has been removed for consistency with the other terms ending in {chem:n:hyp}.

definition.sv: beteckna, fastställa, specificera, namnge, ge namn åt/till

notes.en: The verb {per:v:nolink} usually means "to assign or attach a name to", but it can also be used for such notions as "ascertain, specify, pin down". One way to ask for the time is {rep yIper!:sen}, literally, "Label the hour!"[2]
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
A code name usually ends in {Qu':n}, e.g., {targh Qu':n:nolink} "Operation Targ".[1, p.48]
The object of this verb is the thing which is given out.

peS:v.hidden_notes: "PEZ" is a brand of candy dispenser.

notes.en:
This is one of the most common Klingon epithets.

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/GonhyphPQPU}

petaQ:excl.hidden_notes: There's an explanation of the origin of this word on {paq'batlh p.70:src}.

definition.sv: medicinskt verktyg för att läka ben

notes.en: This is a device or substance used by the {HaqwI':n} to bond broken bones in place.

petqaD:n.hidden_notes:
This seems to refer to a device similar to one used by the Federation called a bone-knitting laser (knitter for short), bone regenerator, or osteo-regenerator.

"Duck tape". Possibly related to {pet:v}.

definition.en: Take action! Do it! Make it so!

notes.en:
This is used when addressing multiple people. To address a single person, say {yIvang!:sen@@yI-:v, vang:v}

pey:n.hidden_notes: This is almost how "pH" is pronounced in French.

notes.en: This refers to a tool knife, as opposed to a weapon knife.

definition.en: to do something at once, as a single event
definition.de: etwas mit einer einzigen Handlung erledigen

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "to forcefully sweep away".

examples.en: ▶ {romuluSnganpu' Dujmey DIQaw'pu'; pe'vIl DIbI'chu'pu'.} "We destroyed the Romulans' ships all at once."

notes.en:
This idiomatic expression conveys the idea that someone is particularly agile or nimble or spry.

The verb {roS:v:2} means "to use the third toe". It is also homophonous with a verb {roS:v:1} meaning "to lick". However, it's possible that this verb is actually an otherwise unknown or archaic verb {roS:v:3,hyp} meaning "to be agile".
This is a Klingon greeting used for welcoming a group to an event.

The word {mIvwa'mey:n@@mIvwa':n, -mey:n} is used to keep a tally or score. To say "out of", use a construction like {loSlogh pe''egh; vaghlogh nID:sen@@loS:n:1,num, -logh:n:num, pe''egh:v, vagh:n:1,num, -logh:n, nID:v} (i.e., 4 out of 5 points). This is used even if the person stopped after four and didn't attempt to get the fifth point.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {potlhbe'chugh yay qatlh pe''eghlu'?:sen}

notes.en: {maH:n:1h}:{SoH:n} = {pI-:v:pref,nolink}
Note that {ghaj:v} is used with this noun to indicate fault or blame.

examples.en: ▶ {pIch vIghajbe'.:sen} "It's not my fault."[1]
▶ {ghach jIvvo' naH. DaH pIghvamDaq So''eghtaH.@@ghach:v, jIvvo':n, naH:v, DaH:adv, pIgh:n, -vam:n, -Daq:n, So':v, -'egh:v, -taH:v} "There is a criminal hiding in these ruins."[2]
▶ {pIpIH.:sen@@pI-:v, pIH:v:1} "We're expecting you."[2]

definition.en: Don't trust those who frequently smile.

notes.en: This is the basic tenet of Vulcan philosophy, and the idea translates awkwardly into Klingon. The translation means something like "different things continue to be together always".

examples.en: ▶ {qum DuSaQmeyDaq 'Irghbe'meH ghotpu' nabmey ghojmoH, 'ej pIj tay'taH Doch pIm num.:sen:nolink} "In public schools, it teaches procedures so that people don't bully, and it promotes Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations."

pIj tay'taH Doch pIm:sen.source: [1] {Air & Space Magazine, August 2016:src}, [2] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

definition.en: be stimulated, be inspired, be motivated
definition.sv: vara stimulerad, vara inspirerad, vara motiverad

pIlHa':v.hidden_notes: This word is not defined as such, but to translate "apathy" or "apathy creature" for the Klingon Christmas Carol, one of MO's suggestions was {pIlHa'wI':n:nolink} "unmotivated one".[1]

notes.en: This can be applied to music.[1, p.71]
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
In this slang sense, {pIn:n:nolink} is never used alone, but is always the second noun in a noun-noun construction. The non-slang term for "expert" is {po'wI':n}.[1, p.158]

pIn tlhoy':n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the Pink Floyd album "The Wall", the songs of which were played at a concert in Berlin eight months after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

definition.en: If you want to eat pipius claw, you'll have to break a few pipiuses.
definition.de: Wenn du eine Pipiusklaue essen willst, musst du erst einige Pipiusse brechen.

notes.en: This is an expression telling someone (often a child) to get started on something or to devote more effort to a project.

A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the future for the following units:
▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {leS:n} "days from now"
▶ {jar:n} "month" - {waQ:n} "months from now"
▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {nem:n} "years from now"

For other units of time, {pIq:n:nolink} is used.
Little is known about how {pIqaD:n:nolink} works, except that it is not an alphabet.[2]

pIqaD:n.hidden_notes:
If interpreted as a sentence, {pIqaD:sen@@pI-:v, qaD:v} literally means "we challenge you".

In the promotional posters and videos for {DSC:src}, as well as in the backgrounds of the sets, Klingon is written in {pIqaD:n:nolink} treating the symbols as an alphabet. The mapping between the twenty-six symbols and Okrand's Latin transcription has a one-to-one grapheme-phoneme correspondence (e.g., so that {tlh:sen:nolink} is written as one symbol), and originated from an unknown source at Paramount and was popularised by the Klingon Language Institute.

definition.en: be indirect, be roundabout, be devious
definition.sv: vara indirekt, vara slingrande, vara irrande

notes.en: The moon of the Klingon Homeworld ({Qo'noS:n}), and the site of a major energy facility ({HoS waw':n}).
This refers to the underside of an object, and not to its interior bottom (which is its {bIS'ub:n}).

pIrmuS:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Pyramus, a character played by Nick Bottom in the play-within-a-play in Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream".

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran food. To Klingons, pizzas are apparently a kind of {chab:n:1}.

This refers to hair from the neck down. For example, "arm hair" is {DeS pob:n@@DeS:n:1, pob:n}. It is also used to tal about ear hair or nose hair. Using this word to refer to facial hair (see {rol:n} and {loch:n}) or head hair (see {jIb:n}) is possible, but would be considered very strange to do.[2]

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "when it falls". It is most frequently heard without a subject, but when a subject is specified, the most common is {'etlh:n}. Another word may be chosen as the subject as a form of word play, as long as it is something that can fall (e.g., {DaS:n}, {'obmaQ:n}, {nagh:n}, {rutlh:n}). When used idiomatically, {pumDI':sen:nolink} always precedes the main clause.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]
▶ {pung ghap HoS.:sen}

notes.en: This idiomatic expression refers to a group participating in a single activity. For example, a brawl may be described by saying {Suv qabDu' law':sen:nolink} "Many faces are fighting".

The {yor:n} of a {qach:n} is its {beb:n}, and its {Hur:n}-facing walls are called {reD:n:1}. The other side of the {beb:n} (that is, the {'aqroS:n:1} of a {qach:n}) is called the {pa' beb:n}; the {qoD:n} face of a {reD:n:1} is referred to as {pa' reD:n}.

For the {qoD:n} parts of a {qach:n}, see {pa':n:1}.

The names of the consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the names of the vowels consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception.

This word is often written in English as "gagh".

notes.en: This is a mildly dismissive remark used to mean that there's something wrong with someone, or that someone is acting suspiciously. It is also used to refer to someone as a coward.

notes.en: The parts of a foot include its {bem:n} "sole", {va'nuch:n} "heel", {mov:n} "top (of foot)", and {yaD:n:1} "toe(s)". The foot is attached to the {'uS:n} "leg" through the {ngIb:n} "ankle".
