definition.de: Der Körper des toten Feindes liegt zu meinen Füßen.

qamDu'wIjDaq Heghpu'bogh jagh tu'lu'.:se.hidden_notes: This sentence does not appear in canon. It is included here because it is used in some fan ceremonies.

qama':n.hidden_notes: MO accommodated the filmmakers by changing {qama':sen@@qa-:v, ma':v} to mean "prisoner" while {Star Trek III:src} was being filmed. See {qama'pu' jonta' neH.:sen}

examples.en: {qama'pu' jonta' neH.:sen}

qama'pu' jonta' neH.:sen.hidden_notes: This sentence was one of the most significant in the development of the Klingon language. It was originally supposed to mean "I told you, engines only." It was changed in the subtitles to say "I wanted prisoners." This led to the invention of the plural suffix for beings {-pu':n}, the accomplishment suffix {-ta':v}, the verb {neH:v} and the idea of clipped Klingon which was needed to explain its lack of any prefix, as well as a change in the meaning of the verb {ma':v} to mean "accommodate".

notes.en: According to legend, this is the name of an ancient village on {Qo'noS:n} where {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} and {luqara':n:name} fought a great battle against hundreds of enemies, a major component of their courtship.

The verb {muSHa':v} does not necessarily indicate romantic love, for which see the noun {parmaq:n}.

Contrary to some unreliable sources, the phrase "Urkuk lu Stalga" does not mean "I love you, baby" in Klingon. In fact, it is not Klingon at all. Calling someone a baby (see {ghu:n}) is not considered a sign of affection in Klingon.

Note that in Klingon, there is a different word for "be old (not new)" ({ngo':v}) than for "be old (not young)" ({qan:v:1,nolink}).

This word is applied to people and animals.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {jIH qan law' SoH qan puS:sen:nolink} "I'm older than you."[3]
▶ {cha' DISmo' jIH qan law' SoH qan puS:sen:nolink} "I'm two years older than you."[3]

notes.en: An idiomatic gesture (due to homophony with {qan:v:1}): to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.

examples.en: ▶ {qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

Note that {qanwI':n:nolink} can also mean "old person". An idiomatic gesture: to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.

In the Dr. Seuss book "If I Ran the Zoo", the word "nerd" is used as the name of an imaginary animal:
▶ "And then, just to show them, I'll sail to Katroo
   And bring back an It-Kutch, a Preep and a Proo,
   A Nerkle, a Nerd and a Seersucker too!"

definition.en: What's she doing? (Why is she going there?)

notes.en:
Here, "she" refers to the Enterprise ({'entepray':n:name}). Chang ({cheng:n:name}) was expressing puzzlement about the movement of the Enterprise.

The subtitle was "What's she doing?" but a more literal translation is "Why is she going there?"

qatlhDa':n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the "Why a Duck?" ("viaduct") routine from the Marx Brothers movie "The Cocoanuts". {Da'nal:n} and {Da'vI':n} are types of Klingon ducks. Also, "duck tape" or "duct tape" is a type of adhesive tape sometimes used in ductwork.

notes.en: This is used when addressing a single person. To salute multiple people, say {Savan!:sen}
notes.de: Diese Form richtet sich an eine einzelne Person. Um mehreren Personen zu salutieren, sagt man {Savan!:sen}

notes.en: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1h} a player has to pay when landing on a planet owned by another player.

definition.de: sich erinnern an, an etwas denken

examples.en:
▶ {bomDI' 'IwwIj qaqaw.:sen}
▶ {batlh Daqawlu'taH.:sen}

notes.en:
This refers to "memory" in the sense of the ability to remember or the power of recall. It does not refer to specific memories or recollections, for which see {wov'on:n}.

Someone who has an excellent memory may be said to have a {qaw pov:n@@qaw:n, pov:v}.
notes.de: Wenn jemand ein gutes Gedächtnis hat, kann man sagen, er habe ein {qaw pov:n@@qaw:n, pov:v}.

notes.en: This word is singular.

Based on the example, the subject does the reminding, the object is the thing remembered, and the person who is reminded is marked with {-vaD:n}.

More generally, it seems that when {-moH:v} is added to a verb {X:sen:nolink} which takes an object, the resulting bivalent verb {XmoH:sen:nolink} takes the same object, while the original subject of {X:sen:nolink} becomes the beneficiary of {XmoH:sen:nolink} and is marked with {-vaD:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

qaywI':n.hidden_notes: If someone is a {qay'wI'}, then you give them a {qaywI':n:nolink}.

definition.en: be a problem, be a hassle
definition.sv: vara ett problem, vara en svårighet

examples.en: {qay'be':sen}

qay'be':sen.hidden_notes: According to the Star Trek Encyclopedia, MO devised this phrase to honour Star Trek III visual-effects supervisor Ken Ralston and his ILM crew, who responded to every request with "No problem!"

notes.en:
The subject does the replacing, and the object is replaced.

This verb seems to have been derived from {qa'meH:n}, possibly through misinterpretation of what was originally the suffix {-qa':v}. Use this verb with caution, since it may not be accepted by all Klingon speakers (see {mu'mey ghoQ:n}).

examples.en:
▶ {Quj wa'DIch MONOPOLY Huch nav qa' tlhIngan QaS:sen:nolink} "Klingon forces replace original MONOPOLY bills"
▶ {Chance 'echletHommey Community Chest 'echletHommey je qa' quv 'echletHommey vIq 'echletHommey je:sen:nolink} "COMBAT and HONOR cards replace Chance and Community Chest cards"
▶ {Quj wa'DIch juH qachmey mebpa'mey je qa' raQmey chu' monmey chu' je:sen:nolink} "Custom OUTPOSTS and CAPITALS replace original Houses and Hotels"

notes.en: This refers to a sort of life force within a person which escapes when that person dies.[2]

qa':n.hidden_notes: This is an acceptable word to use for "ghost", but there may be another (and better) unknown word for that concept.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {qa' wIje'meH maSuv.:sen}
▶ {ghe'torvo' narghDI' qa'pu':sen}

definition.en: We fight to enrich the spirit.
definition.de: Wir kämpfen, um den Geist zu bereichern.

notes.en: This word was originally a shortened form of {quvqa'meH:sen:nolink} (see {qa'meH vIttlhegh:n}), but has since become accepted as a noun in its own right. It refers to something that takes over for or is used instead of something that is gone or which has been lost. To denote a temporary substitute or stand-in, use {lIw:n}.[2]

These are a set of proverbs used to restore respect or credibility after one has been embarrassed in a public setting.[2]

In the past, this used to be {quvqa'meH vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.[1]
This is used for a minor software update (e.g., 2.0 to 2.1).

Its claw is eaten. This word may also be spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink}.

Do not confuse this with the similarly named {Qaj:n}.

qa'raj:n.hidden_notes: On {KGT p.94:src}, this word is spelled {qa'raj:n:nolink}. However, it is spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink} in both the E-K and K-E word lists.

definition.en: end (of corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, sewer, road, bridge, long field, etc.)
definition.de: Ende (von Korridor, Tunnel, Rohrleitung, Jeffries-Röhre, Kanal, Straße, Brücke, langes Feld, usw.
definition.sv: slut, ände (på långsmalt avgränsat utrymme, t.ex. korridor, rör, väg, bro, fält etc.)

notes.en: This is the end of any clearly defined space longer than wide in which people might find themselves.

qa'rI':n.hidden_notes: This is a private joke referring to a specific person.

notes.en: It is much larger than a {notqa':n}.
notes.de: Er ist viel größer als ein {notqa':n}.

qa'rol:n.hidden_notes: The character of Big Bird on the children's show Sesame Street is played by Caroll Edwin Spinney.

notes.en:
This is the Klingon code name for the Federation's Genesis weapons research project.[2]

The word itself means "origin of everything" or "start of it all" or the like, and refers to the beginning of the universe. Unlike its English translation, the Klingon term doesn't contain the notion of an explosion.[3]

qa'vam:n.hidden_notes: Maltz said that it's possible to say {qa'vam nger:sen:nolink} "Big Bang Theory", but it sounded weird to him, since {qa'vam:n:nolink} is not a theory.[3]

examples.en: ▶ {qa'vam De' vIje' rIntaH.:sen}[2]

definition.en: I have purchased the Genesis data.
qa'vak (traditional game), game played with hoop and stick

qa'vaQ:n.hidden_notes: It may just be a coincidence, but this sounds like {qa' vaQ:n:nolink} "aggressive spirit". See {qa':n} and {vaQ:v}.

notes.en: This refers to the action of squeezing the bag part of the {DIron:n}, usually with the elbow.[1, p.76]

In the {paq'raD:n:nolink} "Force Book" of the {paq'batlh:n}, the second section is titled {qeHHa' loDnI':sen:nolink}, which is given the somewhat loose English translation "A Brother's Forgiveness". A footnote explains that the concept of forgiveness does not map exactly to Klingon culture, and that the literal meaning of the title is "A Brother Unresents". The title of the corresponding canto in the opera {'u':n:name,nolink} is {loDnI'Daj quvqa'moH:sen:nolink}, literally, "he causes the brother to have honor again".

definition.sv: vara vresig, vara grinig, vara elak, vara tarvlig
tänka på, ta hänsyn till, beakta, överväga

notes.en: This is a unit of measurement roughly akin to two kilometers.

definition.sv: hämta, ta med sig, bära med sig

examples.en: ▶ {naDev Dochvetlh qem!:sen}

notes.en: In the {paq'batlh:src}, the {qempa'QeH:n:nolink} are the enraged (see {QeH:v}) ancestral spirits populating {ghe'tor:n}.[2]

definition.sv: nyligen, för ett litet tag sedan, alldeles nyss

notes.en: A pregnant woman is said to {qeng:v:nolink} a {puq:n}.[2] See {yatlh:v}.

examples.en:
▶ {yatlh luqara' puqloD wa'DIch qenglI'} "Lukara, pregnant of their first-born son"[2]
▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[3]

notes.en: Played by {mayqel 'anSara':n:name}.
notes.de: Dargestellt durch {mayqel 'anSara':n:name}.

examples.en:
▶ {qep'a':n}
▶ {qepHom'a':n}

definition.en: annual meeting of Klingon speakers in Germany

notes.en:
The {qepHom'a':n:nolink} is the annual Klingon Language meeting in Saarbrücken, Germany. Please visit their website at {www.qepHom.de:url:http://www.qepHom.de/} for more information.

The official annual conference of the Klingon Language Institute is known as the {qep'a':n}, while other gatherings of Klingonists are known as {qepHommey:n:nolink}. The meeting in Saarbrücken, Germany, is the largest {qepHom:n:nolink} (and it sometimes even has more participants than the {qep'a':n:nolink}). For this reason, it is called {qepHom'a':n:nolink}. Its name contains an intentional ungrammaticality: two type 1 noun suffixes.
notes.de:
Das {qepHom'a':n:nolink} ist das jährlich stattfindende Klingonisch-Treffen in Saarbrücken, Deutschland. Siehe {www.qepHom.de:url:http://www.qepHom.de/} für mehr Informationen.

Die Hauptversammlung des Klingon Language Institute ist bekannt als {qep'a':n}, während all anderen kleineren Klingonisten-Treffen üblicherweise als {qepHommey:n:nolink} bekannt sind. Das Treffen in Saarbrücken ist das größte {qepHom:n:nolink} (und hat in der Regel mehr Teilnehmer als das {qep'a':n:nolink}). Aus diesem Grund wird es {qepHom'a':n:nolink} genannt. Dieser Name enthält einen beabsichtigten Fehler, denn er enthält zwei Nomensuffixe des Typ 1.

qepHom'a':n.hidden_notes: This intentional use of improper grammar was approved by MO.

notes.en: The {qep'a':n:nolink} is the official annual conference of the Klingon Language Institute ({tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}).
notes.de: Das {qep'a':n:nolink} ist die offizielle Hauptversammlung des Klingon Language Institute ({tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}).

notes.en:
Also related are the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v}.

Do not confuse with {Qeq:v}.

This is the name of a book.

The famous author {Qa'taq:n:name} wrote a commentary on this work.

examples.en: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

definition.de: Soße, die aus verdickter Marinade besteht

notes.en: This is sauce prepared by thickening {chanDoq:n}.

qev:n.hidden_notes: In its first appearance as a noun, in {HQ 4.4, Dec. 1995:src}, {qev:n:nolink} was described as "[among] those words already well-known for different types of groups". The noun {tlhach:n} was explicitly introduced as being a new word in the same article. This suggests that the verb {qev:v} was misread as a noun.

notes.en: This is a traded commodity, like {DIlyum:n}.

qevaS:n.hidden_notes: This is described in {The Star Trek Encyclopedia:src} as a type of gemstone.

qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n.hidden_notes: This has also been translated as {qeylIS lIjlaHbogh pagh:sen:nolink} in the {paq'batlh:src}.

notes.en: This is abbreviated QB in the {paq'batlh:src}.
This is abbreviated QBV in the {paq'batlh:src}. (This could be a typo for QBN.)

definition.en: Eyes of Kahless, a game played with dice

notes.en: This is a guessing game with dice in which the winner receives a punch.
All fermented meat is known as {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n:nolink}, with the word for the specific meat replacing the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.

qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n.hidden_notes: "Kiviak" is an Inuit food made of auks fermented in the body of a seal.

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun p.entry_name: qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.

definition.en: You would be the greatest warrior in the galaxy.
definition.de: Du bist der großartigste Krieger in der Galaxie.

qIbHeS:n.hidden_notes: This was apparently intended to be {qIb:n} plus {HeH:n}.

qID:n.hidden_notes: In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

definition.en: joke, make a joke, tell a joke

qID:v.hidden_notes: In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

notes.en: This verb always takes an object or {-chuq:v} in normal usage.[2]

qIl:v.hidden_notes:
"Kill". This is defined in {TKD:src} only as "cancel". The "abort" meaning was given at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}.[2]

This was used for "Cancel" (while {ruch:v} was used for "Ok") in Klingon Blockly.[3]

notes.en: This is the name of a city, where {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} once witnessed a foolish man stand outside the walls during a fierce storm in an attempt to make the wind respect him.
This is the general word for a season. For example, {qImroq tuj:n@@qImroq:n, tuj:v} would be something like "summer" on Earth.

qImroq:n.hidden_notes: "McCormick" is a brand of food seasoning.

examples.en: ▶ {tIqIpqu' 'ej nom tIqIp.:sen}

qIpmeH Qatlh'a'?:sen.hidden_notes: The line was originally supposed to have been {wIqIpmeH Qatlh'a'?:sen@@wI-:v, qIp:v, -meH:v, Qatlh:v, -'a':v} Either way, the grammar of this sentence is strange, as it means "It is being difficult in order (for us) to hit it."

qIQ:v.hidden_notes: {qIQ:v:nolink} is similar to "Kirk", who named his stolen Bird of Prey "HMS Bounty", in reference to the historical event of the mutiny on the Bounty.

definition.de: Wenn ich in der Lage wäre, Kirk zu besiegen...

qIrq vIjeylaHchugh...:sen.see_also: {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen}

notes.en: While this word is known only as the name of a ship class, it seems likely that it also refers to a bird or to a class of predatory birds (cf. {toQ:n}).

qISa'ruj:n.hidden_notes:
This is "Jurassic" spelled backwards.

In the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this ship class is referred to as {raptor:n:nolink} in Klingon, but this is likely a placeholder which was overlooked by mistake.

notes.en: This is a big, fat bird native to Kronos, which is able to fly, but not for a long time. A female one of these is a {qItbe':n:nolink}, while a male is a {qItloD:n:nolink}.[2] It resembles a Terran guineafowl.[1]

qIt:n.hidden_notes:
The source is Andrew Miller. This word was revealed for a Smithsonian Klingon Shakespeare skit that he and Marc Okrand were involved in. It was confirmed at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.

Note that {qItbe'@@qIt:v, -be':v} means "impossible".

qItI'nga':n.hidden_notes: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

qIv:n.hidden_notes: Arrows come from "quiv"ers, and you can take an arrow to the knee.

qIvon:n.hidden_notes: According to a message on the {msn:src} newsgroup, Maltz seemed reluctant to talk about what exactly this is.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {bIrchugh qIvon tuj 'Iw.:sen}

notes.en: To register or sign up for an account is also {mab qI':sen@@mab:n, qI':v}.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {mab qI'lu'ta':sen:nolink} "account already exists"[2]
▶ {qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

notes.en: The object of this verb is the space being squeezed into, such as a small car or crowded elevator, or clothes or shoes that are too small.

qoch:v.hidden_notes: "Coach" is the lowest (and most cramped) seating class in air travel.

notes.en:
This both holds up one's {yopwaH:n} and is used for hanging weapons.[2]

{qoghmey:n:nolink} generally means "belts", but could also mean "ears scattered all about", due to the homophony with {qogh:n:2}. This homophony is also the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[3]

This refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, or whatever. The internal organ of hearing is called {teS:n}.

{qoghDu':n:nolink} can only mean "ears", while {qoghmey:n:nolink} is usually the plural of {qogh:n:1} and means "belts". The homophony between these two words is the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[2]

qogh:n:2.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the painter Vincent van Gogh, who cut off his ear.

qogh qorghwI':n.hidden_notes: This construction doesn't appear in canon, but during a discussion of {qorghwI':n} at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2013:src}, everyone immediately knew what it meant.

notes.en: This expression literally means "take off one's belt". It derives its slang meaning from the homophony between {qogh:n:1} and {qogh:n:2}.

qogh tuQmoHHa':sen.hidden_notes: It's unclear why the expression is {tuQmoHHa':sen:nolink} and not {tuQHa'moH:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {qogh vItuQmoHHa'pu':sen:nolink} "I've taken off my belt; your secret is safe with me."

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/FJ7HlgaTt44}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/FJ7HlgaTt44}

definition.en: The wind does not respect a fool.
definition.de: Der Wind nimmt keine Rücksicht auf einen Narren.

notes.en: He is a member of the House of Kor ({qor tuq:n:name}).
This name is untranslated in {KGT:src}, and is possibly a misspelling for {qo'leq:n:name}.

definition.sv: kärna, essens, väsentlig del av något

qol'om:n.hidden_notes: A reference to Coloma, the originating site of the California Gold Rush.

notes.en:
According to Klingon legend, Kotar was the first Klingon. He and his mate slew the gods, and he now ferries the souls of the dishonored to Gre'thor ({ghe'tor:n}) on the Barge of the Dead ({Hegh Duj:n}).

This name is sometimes written as Kortar ({qortar:n:name,nolink}).
To prepare this, {tap:v} a mixture of {naH:n} and animal matter, and let {rogh:v}.

definition.sv: nedteckna, spela in (all slags inspelning och skrift), komponera

notes.en:
This word is used for the act of composing songs, stories, etc.[2, p.71] Klingons consider songs as things which just exist, and the act of composition is viewed as hunting down, trapping, and logging them.[3]

There is another verb, {gher:v}, which is used for compiling lists and the like, and which, in contrast to {qon:v:nolink}, suggests that information is merely passed along.[4]

qon:v.hidden_notes: This is defined as "record" in {TKD:src}, and as "compose" in {KGT:src}.[1; 2]

notes.en: Note that {qonwI':n:nolink} can also mean a recording device, as in {mIllogh qonwI':n}.

qop:v.hidden_notes: In English, "cop" is a slang term for a police officer.

notes.en: Played by {jan qalI'qoS:n:name}.
This is the House of {qol:n:name} and, of course, {qor:n:name}.

qor tuq:n.source: [1] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

qorDu':n.hidden_notes: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.
qorDu':n.source: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {SkyBox 13:src} (reprinted in {HQ 3.4, p.10-11, Dec. 1994:src}), [3] {SkyBox 20:src} (reprinted in {HQ 5.2, p.14, Jun. 1996:src})

definition.sv: täppa igen, täta, täcka över (ett hål)

notes.en: Unlike {teb:v}, this indicates stopping up an opening, but not filling up the inside.

This word refers to the cork or stopper of a bottle, such as a wine bottle.[1]

It can also be used for the device some Humans use to keep their babies quiet (which is not a Klingon custom).[2]
According to legend, this is the name of a Klingon who committed murder while his victim was sleeping. His name is synonymous with cowardice.[1]
According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a rodent that is considered a destructive pest on Klingon farms, where farmers have to set traps for them.

qorvIt:n.hidden_notes: Corvids are members of Corvidae, a family of birds containing crows, ravens, jays, magpies, and so on.

notes.en: This literally means "may you enjoy your birthday!" To wish a happy birthday to multiple people, say {qoSraj botIvjaj!}

qoSta':n.hidden_notes: While this word has appeared in canon only in reference to ribbon-like recording media, it refers to their form, rather than to their function.[2] It may be thought of as a flat version of {SIrgh:n}.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {wab qoSta' 'aplo':n}
▶ {mIllogh qonwI' qoSta':n}
▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

definition.sv: förtjäna, vara förtjänt av, vara värd

examples.en: ▶ {bIyIntaH 'e' Daqotlhbe'.:sen}[2]

definition.sv: be om, böna för, tigga om

notes.en: A planet in the Federation.

definition.en: the Great Tree of the World

notes.en: According to {The Klingon Art of War:src}, the ancient Klingon gods used to live here.[1]
This is made from digested {Su'lop:n}.
From the {BoP:src} poster, {qughDo motlh:n:nolink} is "normal cruising speed".

examples.en: ▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]
▶ {jIbDaj lumeQmoH qul bIQtIq qulHommey:sen:nolink} "Sparks from the fire river caught his hair"[1]

notes.en: This refers to pieces of animal skin soaked in liquor and set on fire, which must be eaten quickly.

definition.de: Beeil dich! Komm in die Pötte!

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "Eat the fire skin!"
This is the name of a famous novel written by {Qa'taq:n:name}. Note that the Klingon is a full sentence, as {naj:v} is a verb.

qul naj:n.source: [1] {TNG - The Measure of a Man:src}, [2] {The Klingon Art of War:src}, [3] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2014:src}

notes.en: This literally means "fire stick".
This term literally means "fire lake".

qul ngeng:n.hidden_notes: This term isn't actually explicitly defined in the {paq'bath:src}, but is just used this way.

definition.en: House of Fire, name of an opera
definition.de: Haus des Feuers, Name einer Oper

examples.en: ▶ {qum DuSaQmeyDaq 'Irghbe'meH ghotpu' nabmey ghojmoH, 'ej pIj tay'taH Doch pIm num.:sen:nolink} "In public schools, it teaches procedures so that people don't bully, and it promotes Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations."

qum DuSaQ:n.source: [1] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

examples.en: ▶ {jemS tIy qIrq. loDHom jIHDI' qIrq qun vIqImchoH.:sen:nolink} "James T. Kirk. I've followed his history since I was a boy."[2]

qun:n.source: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {Star Trek V notes:src} (not actually in the film)

definition.en: History is written by the victors.
definition.de: Geschichte wird geschrieben durch die Sieger.

definition.en: hole (like a hole in a musical instrument)

notes.en:
Based on the explanation in {HQ 10.2:src}, this seems to refer to a hole used to change pitch in a wind instrument, and apparently not to a soundhole for a stringed instrument. However, this is not explicitly stated.[1]

This word can't be used for a hole in the ground (for which see {QemjIq:n}), but it can be used for a bullet hole, a hole in a shirt (including buttonholes, moth holes, accidental rips, etc.), or a hole in the roof. The difference between a {QemjIq:n} and a {qung:n:nolink} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).[2] (In other words, a {qung:n:nolink} is a puncture or perforation, while a {QemjIq:n:nolink} is a cavity or depression.)

qung:n.hidden_notes: Possibly based on the Chinese "kǒng" (孔), also meaning hole.

notes.en: In the {paq'batlh:src}, {qanra':n:name} is referred to as the {qup'a':n:nolink} of {qamchIy:n:name}.

qup'a':n.hidden_notes: In referring to {qanra':n:name,nolink}, the translation of {qup'a':n:nolink} says "patriarch". The definition "matriarch" was added since the word itself is gender-neutral.

notes.en: The subjects are the events that happen simultaneously.[2]
This is allegedly the Morskan term for an architect. The {ta' Hol:n} term is {renwI':n}.

qurbuSwI':n.hidden_notes: This word was suggested by Quvar to MO as a new word for the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}. It's based on the name of the Swiss-born French architect Le Corbusier.

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "to sit in a chair". It is based on the homophony between {ba':v} and {-ba':v:suff}. It is used only condenscendingly in response to a statement that the speaker thinks is too obvious to have needed stating.

examples.en: ▶ {quSDaq bIba'.:sen:nolink} "What you said is quite obvious."

quSDaq ba'lu''a'?:sen.hidden_notes: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extraneous space after {ba':sen:nolink}.

definition.en: couch, bench, chair for multiple people

notes.en: This refers to making a prediction which is fraudulent or suspected to be fraudulent, or if it's a carnival act or the like.
notes.de: Dies ist eine Vorhersage, wie es unechte Wahrsager machen, d.h. ohne wahre Fakten.

qut:v.hidden_notes: That is, this is a prediction made based on a crystal ({qut:n}) ball.

notes.en: This weapon is associated symbolically with assassins.
This is a ceremony in which a young Klingon draws blood for first time.[1, p.62]

This word refers to personal honor, which is earned by one's behaviour, and can be bestowed, in contrast to {batlh:n}.[2]

Note that {ghaj:v} and {Hutlh:v} can be used with this noun to indicate that someone possesses or lacks honor, respectively.

examples.en:
▶ {quv lughaj 'archer HoD beqDaj je.:sen:nolink}[3]
▶ {quv Hutlh HoHbogh tlhIngan 'ach qabDaj 'angbe'bogh.:sen}[4]

notes.de: This was defined as "be honored" in {TKDA:src}. It was expanded in {HQ 12.3:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {pujwI' HIvlu'chugh quvbe'lu'.:sen}

notes.en: A {quv bey':n:nolink} has two {betleH:n} and two {Daqtagh:n}.

definition.en: The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honor.
definition.de: Ein Klingone, der tötet ohne sein Gesicht zu zeigen, hat keine Ehre.

en: The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honour.

notes.en: Klingon has more specific words to describe dishonor, which depend on the circumstances of the dishonor. If the honor paid to someone is unearned or undeserved, consider {HoQ:v}. If the dishonor involves deception about one's social status, consider {Qaq:v}. If it involves a fall from grace, consider {mIl:v}.
This is simply {quv:v} plus the suffix {-moH:v}, so verb suffixes of types 1 to 3 need to go before {-moH:v}, which is type 4. However, this rule is sometimes broken for rhetorical effect.[2]
This is the name of the Ferengi bartender on the Federation space station Deep Space Nine.

examples.en: ▶ {quwargh tach Qe' je qoDDaq Hov leng Soj DatIv.:sen@@quwargh:n, tach:n, Qe':n, je:conj, qoD:n, -Daq:n, Hov leng:n, Soj:n, Da-:v, tIv:v} "Enjoy Star Trek themed food and drink at Quark's Bar and Restaurant."[1]

quy'Ip:n.hidden_notes: Note that the reverse, {pI'yuq:sen:nolink}, is phonetically "puke".

definition.sv: vara vildsint, vara häftig, vara våldsam

notes.en: This verb is typically applied only to people or animals. When applied to something other than a person or an animal, it is likely that its slang meaning (see {qu':v:2}) is intended.[2]

definition.en: be great, be wonderful, be excellent, be splendid
definition.sv: vara storslagen, vara underbar, vara utmärkt, vara fantastisk, vara bra

notes.en:
When this verb is applied to a person or an animal, it is not always clear whether the slang or literal meaning (see {qu':v:1}) is intended. However, when applied to something other than a person or an animal, the slang meaning is more likely.[1, p.159]

Two out-of-fashion slang words with the same meaning are {Huv:v:2,slang} and {nong:v:2,slang}, the latter of which may be making a comeback.[1, p.161]
A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.
This is a geometric pyramid ({'Impey':n}) with a three-sided base ({ra'Duch:n}).

qu'vu':n.hidden_notes: "Khufu", also known as Cheops, is the Egyptian pharaoh generally thought to have built the Great Pyramid of Giza.

notes.en: This verb is used for wielding or swinging an ax, a club, or the like.[1, p.64] It can also be applied to a {betleH:n}.[2]

QaD:v:1.hidden_notes: This is defined as "be dry" in {TKD:src}, while {KGT:src} extends this with "be dried out".

notes.en: This sense of {QaD:v:2,nolink} comes from its similarity to {Qan:v}.
This can also be used to refer to a software "bug".[2]

definition.en: err, be mistaken, make a mistake
definition.sv: ha fel, ta fel, missta sig, göra ett misstag

definition.en: due to your apparent minor errors

notes.en: This is used in {TKD:src} as an example of a noun with all five suffix types.

definition.en: Have the courage to admit your mistakes.
definition.de: Habe den Mut, deine Fehler zu gestehen.

notes.en: This would be used in situations where the person needing help can't do whatever needs to be done without assistance, in contrast to {boQ:v}. The object of {QaH:v:nolink} can't carry out the task alone, so responsibility falls to the subject (or it is shared). There's nothing weak about asking for {QaH:v:nolink} when it is warranted, but an offer to {QaH:v:nolink} when {boQ:v:nolink} is expected may sometimes be mildly insulting.[2]
For help on using this program, see under {boQwI':n}.

A kradge has brown lips. The expression {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).[2]

Do not confuse this with the similarly named {qa'raj:n}.

QamvIS Hegh qaq law' torvIS yIn qaq puS..entry_name: QamvIS Hegh qaq law' torvIS yIn qaq puS.

definition.en: Better to die on our feet than live on our knees.
definition.de: Es ist besser, stehend zu sterben als knieend zu leben

examples.en: {Qang yIQan!:sen}

notes.en: This is the title of the leader of the Klingon Empire, when it is not ruled by an Emperor.

examples.en: {Qang yIQan!:sen}

notes.en: "To win" a competition is {Qap:v:nolink}. If the victory is decisive or particularly gratifying, the expression {Qapchu':v:nolink} is used, even if it's a bit redundant.[4]

Qap:v:1.hidden_notes: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "work, function, succeed", and in {KGT:src} as "win" and "operate, be in operation" (two separate entries). The "succeed" and "win" meanings are elaborated upon in {TKW:src}. In {HQ 2.4:src}, it is explained that to Klingons, to win is to function perfectly.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan 'IH qaD DaQap.:sen@@tlhIngan:n, 'IH:v, qaD:n, Da-:v, Qap:v:1} "Win Klingon beauty contest."[5]
▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[5]
▶ {Qapchu'meH 'aqroS chuq:n:nolink} "maximum effective range"[1]

notes.en: This word is used as a ritual greeting. See {Qapla'!:sen}.

definition.en: behave falsely honorably, behave in a falsely honorable manner
definition.sv: agera med låtsad heder, bete sig på ett falskt hedervärt sätt

notes.en: Deception is implied by the use of this verb. However, it differs from {toj:v} in that the deception involves honor or social status in some way. For example, this verb might be used of someone who claimed to be of a rank that he not had achieved, or to be a member of a house or family to which he did not belong.

en: behave in a falsely honourable manner

notes.en:
This is the verb (or adjective) meaning "to be good". Based on the examples, it's in the sense of having a desirable quality, rather than in the sense of not being evil (see {mIgh:v}).

For "good" as an exclamation expressing satisfaction, see {maj:excl}.

For describing enjoyable food or music, see {'ey:v} and {DuQ:v:2}.

examples.en:
▶ {bortaS bIr jablu'DI' reH QaQqu' nay'.:sen}
▶ {nuqDaq 'oH Qe' QaQ'e'?:sen} "Where is a good restaurant?"

notes.en:
The meaning of this word is like {negh:n}, but it excludes officers ({yaS:n}). The highest ranks of {QaS:n:1h,nolink} are:
▶ {bu':n} "sergeant"
▶ {Da':n} "corporal"

It's possible that this word can be used to refer to a single troop member.[2, p.51]

In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {tlhIngan QaS:n:nolink} is the unit of currency used in the game. From this game, we have the examples {"GO" DajuSDI' cha'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink} and {wa'vatlh QaS yItlhap:sen:nolink}. Note that the singular prefix {yI-:v} is used even though {QaS:n:1h,nolink} is an inherently plural noun whose members are being counted.[3]
He appeared in the episode {TOS - Friday's Child:src}.

definition.sv: vara svår, vara komplex, vara komplicerad

notes.en: For "hard (not soft)", see {let:v}. See also {ngem Sarghmey tlha':sen:idiom} for an idiom related to difficulty or complexity.

Qaw':v.hidden_notes: This word is listed erroneously as a noun in {TKD:src} in both word lists, but is described as a verb on p.49. It is also used in {TKW:src} on p.211 as a verb.

examples.en:
▶ {nuQaw'qu'be'.} "They have not finished us off."[1]
▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2]
▶ {not Soj QaQ Qaw' tlhInganpu'.} "Klingons never destroy good food.[3]

definition.en: blow one's top, lose one's temper
definition.sv: förlora besinningen, tappa behärskningen, tappa humöret, bli

notes.en: See {Qay':v:2} for a related idiomatic expression.

Qay':v:1.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src} this is defined as "blow one's top".[1] In {HQ 10.2:src}, the additional definition "lose one's temper" was added for clarification.[2]

notes.en: There is an idiomatic expression {'oy'qu' Qay'wI'wIj.:sen} This literally means "my little toe aches a lot", but it carries the idiomatic meaning "I'm extremely angry." The expression undoubtedly arose due to the homophony between {Qay':v:2,nolink} "use the little toe" and {Qay':v:1} "blow one's top".

Qay':v:2.hidden_notes: And this little piggy cried "wee wee wee" all the way home.

Qay'wI':n.hidden_notes: And this little piggy cried wee wee wee all the way home.

notes.en: More specifically, this animal is called the {jajlo' Qa':n}.[2]
Krada legs are a popular Klingon food made from the extremities of a krada.

definition.en: type of animal (similar to {Qa':n:1}, but smaller)
definition.sv: ett slags djur (snarlik en Qa', men mindre)

notes.en:
This does not make a ruckus at dawn, unlike the {jajlo' Qa':n}. It is mistaken for a bird by some.[2]

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/SIpF7Zak6CY}

Qa'Hom:n.hidden_notes: This word appears in the "Curses" section of the {KCD:src} Language Lab. In the introduction to the holodeck part of the game, it is used in a derogatory manner to describe someone who is weak and scares easily.[3]

notes.en: This is the author of {qul naj:n}, who also wrote a commentary on {qeS'a':n}. He is the son of M'Lind (see {mI'lInnID:n:name}).

Qa'taq:n.source: [1] {TNG - The Measure of a Man:src}, [2] {VOY - Author, Author:src}, [3] {The Klingon Art of War:src}, [4] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2014:src}

notes.en: This word can also be used for other kinds of (similar) jewelry, like for a toe (though it would probably be {yaD Qeb:n@@yaD:n:1, Qeb:n:1}, or more specific, like {Qay'wI' Qeb:n@@Qay'wI':n, Qeb:n:1}). This is not used for a link in a chain, unless the chain is made up of (jewelry-like) rings.[2]
Klingon sciences include {HolQeD:n}, {HuchQeD:n}, {nughQeD:n}, {porghQeD:n}, and {'otlhQeD:n}.
This appears as {QeD patmey noch patmey je:n:nolink} "science and remote sensing systems".

definition.sv: uppskatta, värdera, hålla av, anse värdefull

examples.en: ▶ {Qo'noS romuluS je boSuqlaH. vabDot tera' Qejbogh DIvI' ram boSuqlaH.:sen:nolink} "Kronos, Romulus and even the puny Federation's precious Earth, are all up for grabs."[1]

notes.en: This is the general word for a "doctor" or "physician". A doctor who performs surgery is a {HaqwI':n}.[2]
This word is not limited to weapons. For example, it can be used for putting a tool into a tool belt.

Qem:v.hidden_notes: This word was awarded to {janSIy:n:name,nolink} as a Friend of Maltz.

definition.en: hole (like a hole in the ground)

notes.en: This can be used for a hole in the ground, a hollow in a tree, and so on. The difference between a {QemjIq:n:nolink} and a {qung:n} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).[1] (That is, a {QemjIq:n:nolink} is a cavity or depression, while a {qung:n:nolink} is a puncture or perforation.)

QemjIq:n.hidden_notes: In the Beatles song "A Day in The Life", a line goes "Four thousand holes in Blackburn, Lancashire".

definition.en: ground-up, dried-up mixture for brewing tea
definition.de: trockene gemahlene Mischung um Tee zu brauen
definition.sv: mald, torkad blandning för tétillagning, téblandning

notes.en: This refers to the dried tea brew including plants or animal parts. For the drink made from this, see {Dargh:n}.

definition.en: any gas produced within the body
definition.sv: gas alstrad inuti kroppen (rap, fis etc.)

notes.en: To distinguish between gases emitted from different orifices, use a phrase involving {nuj:n}, {Hugh:n}, or {Sa'Hut:n}.[2]

The object is the projectile or weapon, and the target is marked with {-Daq:n:suff}. See {bach:v}.

Do not confuse with {qeq:v}.

examples.en:
▶ {yIQeqQo' neH. DoS yIqIp!:sen}[2]
▶ {'ay'vamDaq nuHmey tIQeq.:sen}[3]

notes.en: This means to heat meat in animal's blood and condiments.

definition.sv: vara åtsittande, vara fastsittande, vara tät

notes.en: This is a show performed at a {much Qe':n}.
The word for the command deck of a ship (also called a "bridge" in English) is {meH:n}.

QI:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the novel "The Bridge over the River Kwai" ("Le Pont de la Rivière Kwai") by Pierre Boulle.

notes.en: This refers to the phenomenon of speech. For speech sounds, see {QIch wab:n}. For pronunciation, see {QIch wab Ho'DoS:n}.[2]
An individual speech sound is {QIch wab:n:nolink}. Speech sounds collectively are {QIch wabmey:n@@QIch wab:n, -mey:n}.

To fully understand the sounds of Klingon, it is recommended that you purchase {The Klingon Dictionary:src}, which has a fuller description of the sounds, as well as the audio recordings {Conversational Klingon:src} and {Power Klingon:src}, in which you can hear them spoken.[1; 2; 3]

The transcription system used to write Klingon in the Roman (English) alphabet is phonetic, meaning that words are written exactly as they are pronounced. In the following description of the sounds of Klingon, which is intended only as a rough guide, IPA phonetic symbols are shown between a pair of slashes following the Roman letter or letters used to transcribe each sound.

The consonants {b:sen:nolink} /b/, {ch:sen:nolink} /ʧ/, {j:sen:nolink} /d͡ʒ/, {l:sen:nolink} /l/, {m:sen:nolink} /m/, {n:sen:nolink} /n/, {p:sen:nolink} /ph/, {t:sen:nolink} /th/, {v:sen:nolink} /v/, {w:sen:nolink} /w/, and {y:sen:nolink} /j/ are pronounced more or less as in American English.

{D:sen:nolink} /ɖ/ and {S:sen:nolink} /ʂ/ are retroflex, that is, they are pronounced with the tongue touching the roof of the mouth.

{gh:sen:nolink} /ɣ/ is similar to {H:sen:nolink} (see below), but voiced. It sounds somewhat like gargling.

{H:sen:nolink} /x/ is like the "ch" in the Scottish word "loch" or the name of the German composer "Bach".

{ng:sen:nolink} /ŋ/ is the same sound as is found at the end of the English words "sing" or "thing", but in Klingon it can come at the beginning of words.

{q:sen:nolink} /qh/ is like the English "k", but with the tongue reaching for or touching the uvula. It sounds a little bit like you're choking.

{Q:sen:nolink} /q͡χ/ is similar to a combination of {q:sen:nolink} and {H:sen:nolink}, and sounds like you're really choking and trying to dislodge food stuck in your throat.

The Klingon {r:sen:nolink} /r/ is slightly trilled or rolled.

{tlh:sen:nolink} /t͡ɬ/ is found in some Native American languages, and is produced by putting your tongue in the position to say {t:sen:nolink}, then forcing air through the sides of your mouth as if to say {l:sen:nolink}.

The glottal stop {':sen:nolink} /ʔ/ ({qaghwI':n:nolink}) is a slight pause or catch in the throat, like between the two syllables of "uh-oh".

The vowel {a:sen:nolink} /ɑ/ sounds like the "a" in "psalm" or "father".

The vowel {e:sen:nolink} /ɛ/ sounds like the "e" in "bed" or "egg".

The vowel {I:sen:nolink} /ɪ/ sounds like the "i" in "bit" or "misfit". Note that it is always written as a capital letter.

The vowel {o:sen:nolink} /o/ sounds like the "o" in "note" or "mosaic".

The vowel {u:sen:nolink} /u/ sounds like the "u" in "prune" or "food".

The diphthongs {aw:sen:nolink}, {ew:sen:nolink}, {Iw:sen:nolink}, {ay:sen:nolink}, {ey:sen:nolink}, {Iy:sen:nolink}, {oy:sen:nolink}, and {uy:sen:nolink} are possible, and sound essentially like their components. Note that {ay:sen:nolink} rhymes with English "why" or "my", whereas {ey:sen:nolink} rhymes with "way" or "may".

The names of the Klingon consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the names of the vowels consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception, being called the {qaghwI':n}.[4]
A "regional accent" would be {Sep QIch wab Ho'DoS:n:nolink} or {Sep QIch wab Sar:n:nolink} or {Sep QIch wab Ho'DoS Sar:n:nolink}.
This is a type of literary style.

QID:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

notes.en: This is a hand-held device, pressed up against an adversary.

examples.en: ▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

notes.en:
This is used when there's no way out, or there's nothing to lose. It includes ideas like "last-ditch, do-or-die, hopeless, doomed".[1]

This word is not used to mean "eager for, longing for, in real need of, having a great desire for", and so on. To express those ideas, one might use {-nIS:v} with {-qu':v}, or perhaps {neHqu':sen@@neH:v, -qu':v}.[2]

QIn:n:1.hidden_notes: This word is often used to refer to email messages among Klingonists.

notes.en:
This word also refers to the sharpened end of a pencil. It likely refers to the sharp end of any stick-like object.[2]

It is used to refer to the point on a (geometric) star ({DujtlhuQ:n}).[3]

definition.en: plain spearhead with single sharp point
definition.de: Speer mit einer einzigen scharfen Spitze
definition.sv: slät spjutspets (med en enda vass spets)

notes.en: It may have any number of points, not just five.

QIn 'echletHom:n.hidden_notes: In some early versions of {TNK:src}, "postcard" was translated as {ngeHmeH QIn nav:n:nolink}.

notes.en: Also spelled "Krencha", this is a reptilian animal native to {Qo'noS:n}.
This is similar to a {ghIntaq:n:1}, except that the handle is longer, the blade is much wider, and a downward-curved horn protrudes from the bottom of the blade. It is rarely used today.[1]

QIngheb:n.hidden_notes: This appears to have been the result of using Bing translator to translate "spear with horn", without understanding that {gheb:n:nolink} means "horn" as in the musical instrument, rather than a hooked point as in a weapon. This word was retroactively "vetted" by Marc Okrand after the book's publication.[2]

notes.en: This word is not limited to weapons. For example, it can be used for removing a tool from a tool belt.

QIq:v.hidden_notes: This word was awarded to {janSIy:n:name,nolink} as a Friend of Maltz. "Quick draw."

QIS:n.hidden_notes: A "kris" or "keris" is a type of wavy-bladed knife found in Southeast Asia.

notes.en:
This is the name of a Terran holiday.

There is no traditional Klingon way to say something like "Merry Christmas". An expression such as {wornagh yItlhutlh!} might be more appropriate.
This is the name of a volcano ({qulHuD:n}) on {Qo'noS:n}, where legend says {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} dipped a lock of his hair to forge the first {betleH:n}.
This refers to any military organization. The official Klingon {QI':n} is the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.
In {PK:src}, this is pronounced by Michael Dorn like {Qetlop:sen:nolink}.
This is the name of an outpost in the Klingon Empire near the Romulan border, where an important peace agreement was signed with the Federation.[3]

definition.en: Paradise (source of creation in Klingon mythology)

notes.en: There are two idioms associated with {QI'tu':n:nolink}, both to do with its age: {ngo'; QI'tu' rur} and {qan; QI'tu' rur@@qan:v:1, QI'tu':n, rur:v}. The first might be applied to an object or idea which is very old, while the second would be applied to an old person.[3]
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/IWW3uAXvOeM}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/IWW3uAXvOeM}

notes.en: A planet in the Klingon Empire, at one point colonized by Klingons.

QI'yoS wa':n.hidden_notes: It may or may not be a coincidence that the name of this planet appears to be made up of {QI':n} and {yoS:n}.

definition.sv: inte hålla med (varandra), inte samtycka, vara oense

notes.en: Disagreement is also expressed by the idiomatic expression {cha' DoSmey DIqIp.:sen:idiom}

Qoch:v.hidden_notes: At {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, MO accepted {maQoch 'e' wIQochbe':sen:nolink} as a way of expressing "we agree to disagree" in Klingon, though he did not compose the sentence.

examples.en: ▶ {jIQochbe'.:sen:nolink}[4]

notes.en: This word refers to the organ. For the sense of "mind", see {yab:n}.
This verb refers to the idea of war. For concrete fighting, see {ghob:v}.

definition.en: be hazardous, be perilous, be treacherous
definition.sv: vara riskfylld, vara riskabel, vara förrädisk, vara opålitlig

QonoS:n.hidden_notes: "Chronos" (Greek for "time"), from which comes the word "chronicle".

QongDaq:n.hidden_notes: A message on {msn:src} dated 1997.06.18 explains the etymology of {QongDaq:n:nolink}.

definition.en: Klingons do not lie in bed.

notes.en: Maltz said that this means "bed pouch", and perhaps a sleeping bag is {QongDaq buq'a':n:nolink} and a pillow is {QongDaq buqHom:n:nolink}.
This is a very non-Klingon concept.
This term does not appear as such in canon, but {QongmeH qItI'nga' Duj:n:nolink} appears as the translation of "a sleeper ship of this [K'Tinga] class" in {SkyBox 15:src}.[1]
This is usually applied to old weapons, tools, mechanical devices, and so on.[1, p.163]
This is used only in reference to food expected to be eaten live, such as {qagh:n}.[1, p.163]

Music is said be Klingons to {jaqmoH:v}, {SeymoH:v}, {tungHa':v}, or {pIlmoH:v}.[1]

This refers to any music, whether vocal or instrumental or both.[2]

QoQ:n.hidden_notes: This sounds like the Cantonese word for "song" (曲).

notes.en:
This may be shortened to just {jan:n:2} if the context is clearly musical, but this is seldom done.[1]

Types of Klingon musical instruments include: percussion ({'In:n}), wind (no overall term), windbag or bellows ({SuSDeq:n}), and stringed ({HurDagh:n}). Wind instruments include the {Dov'agh:n}, the {gheb:n}, and the {meSchuS:n}.
In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v:nolink}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

definition.sv: ta hand om, bry sig om

definition.en: The hunter does not lie down with the prey.
definition.de: Der Jäger legt sich nicht mit seiner Beute hin.

notes.en: This is the name of a leader who conquered neighbouring areas of his region.

Qotmagh:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

notes.en:
This region is named after Krotmag ({Qotmagh:n:name}).

In the Krotmag region, speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {m:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {N:sen:nolink}.[1, p.21]

Qotmagh Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

Qotlh:v.hidden_notes: Be careful not to say this word by accident if you mean {Hotlh:v:2} instead.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {QaptaHvIS So'wI', Hoch jagh Dujmey DaQotlh.:sen:nolink} "Disable all enemy ships while cloaked."[3]

notes.en: She is the Klingon language expert behind the dialogue in {DSC:src}.
This means "hear" and not just "listen". The hearer must actually perceive and understand what is being said.[2, p.31]

Qoy:v.hidden_notes: This is defined only as "hear" in {TKD:src}. The "listen to" definition was added based on the explanation in {TKW:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {Qoy qeylIS puqloD:sen:lyr}

notes.en: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

QoymoH:v.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in the word lists in {TKD:src}, but appears in the explanation of {-moH:v:suff} in {TKD 4.2.4:src}, where {chenmoH:v} also appears. This entry is here for ease of reference.

examples.en: ▶ {HIQoymoH:sen:nolink} "let me hear (something)"

Qoy qeylIS puqloD:sen.hidden_notes:
The actors who performed this song on {KCD:src} mispronounced the intended {Say'moHchu':v:nolink} as {SeymoHchu':v:nolink}. This error has since propagated to other recordings of the song.

The line {yoHbogh matlhbogh je SuvwI':sen:nolink} is not a mistake, but a deliberately poetic or archaic usage, which is mirrored by the English "warrior brave and true". In standard Klingon, it would be {yoHbogh 'ej matlhbogh SuvwI':sen:nolink}.[2]

notes.en:
This can be used for a certificate or a diploma, but not for a license or a permit, which would be a {chaw':n}. The difference is that a {Qoyje':n:nolink} is proof or verification of some sort of achievement or accomplishment, but it doesn't necessarily allow you to do anything as a result of that.

Klingons consider title deeds ({yer ghajwI' chaw':n}) to be a type of {chaw':n:nolink}, rather than a type of {Qoyje':n:nolink}, since property ownership is granted by a government or other authority, but isn't an accomplishment.

Qoyje':n.hidden_notes: Pun: {Qoy:v} "hear" + {je':v:1} "buy" = "hereby". Many certificates begin with "I hereby certify that...".

definition.en: no, I won't, I refuse, I disagree
definition.sv: nej, det tänker jag inte, jag vägrar, jag håller inte med

Qo':excl.hidden_notes: {TKD:src} lists this as "no, I won't, I refuse", and {TKDA:src} adds "no, I disagree".

notes.en: The Klingon Homeworld.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan wo' yuQmey chovlu'chugh Qo'noS potlh law' Hoch potlh puS. roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH. pa' 'oHtaH vaS'a''e'. tlhIngan qum waw' 'oH. yoq yIn yuQ 'oH Qo'noS'e'. yInSIp voQSIp je ngaS muDDaj.:sen:nolink}
  "The principal planet of the Klingon Empire, Qo'noS is usually referred to as simply "The Homeworld." This is where the Klingon Great Hall is located, the center of the Klingon government. Qo'noS is a class-M planet with an oxygen/nitrogen atmosphere."[2]

definition.en: Two Federation crewmen arrive on Kronos.
definition.de: Zwei Föderationsoffizieren kommen auf Kronos an.

notes.en:
This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

The slang meaning of {chong:v:2,slang}, when applied to a person, is equivalent to {Qubchu'} "think clearly".[3]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vIQub.:sen:nolink} "I think that you speak Klingon."[2]

notes.en: Note that the English idiom "(have a) happy holiday" (where "holiday" may be substituted for the actual name of a holiday) does not make sense when literally translated into Klingon. To translate such an expression, consider using {tIv:v} instead. (See {qoSlIj DatIvjaj!:sen} for an example.)
Regional words for forehead include: {boD:n}, {jargh:n}, {mIQ:n}, {'aQlo':n}, {Huy'Dung:n}, {tuqvol:n}, and {no''och:n}.
This does not mean exactly the same thing as {'IQ:v}, since it implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]
The difference between this and {reH:v} is that this refers to structured play, whereas {reH:v:nolink} refers to unstructured play.[2]

Quj:v.hidden_notes: In the "Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue", cricket (the sport) is translated as {ghew:n:nolink}. Specifically, "Cricket, please." was translated as {DaH ghew yIQuj.:sen:nolink}[3]
Quj:v.source: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}, [3] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}

notes.en: This word means "ball" in the sense of a spherical object for playing.
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {QujwI' lIw:n:nolink} is used to refer to the game pieces that stand in for the player.

examples.en: ▶ {polmeH jav QujwI' lIwmey} "6 Collectible Tokens"

notes.en: This word is used for a scroll which is implied to be important, sacred, or ancient (though it is not necessarily all three). Any {Qumran:n:nolink} is a {tetlh:n}, but not every {tetlh:n:nolink} is a {Qumran:n:nolink}. When a scroll is used in a ceremony, it is typically referred to as a {Qumran:n:nolink}.[2]

Qumran:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the archaeological site where the Dead Sea Scrolls were discovered.

examples.en:
▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink}
  "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

definition.de: Ich kann meinen Kommunikator nicht finden.

QumwI'wIj vItu'laHbe'.:sen.hidden_notes: {Sam:v} is probably better for this sense of "find" than {tu':v}, but that's how the sentence appears on {TKD p.171:src}.

notes.en: Little is known about the Klingon gods, except that it seems they acted collectively, and no single individual stood out from among them. {Qun'a':n:nolink} may or may not be an appropriate translation for the supreme deity of a monotheistic religion, since the {Qun'a':n:nolink} would still be one among many.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {jIH Qup law' SoH Qup puS:sen:nolink} "I'm younger than you."[2]
{baHwI', DoS yIbuS. QuQ neH.:sen}

notes.en: This does not mean a building ({qach:n}) or a collection of people or states ({DIvI':n}, {tlham:n:2}), but rather the way things fit together or the arrangement of the parts of something bigger. It can be used to mean "anatomy" when referring to animals.
This can only refer to physically supporting something. It cannot be used for psychological or any other non-physical type of support. The word {ghaq:v} is used for monetary support.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {qoD QutlhwI' ngaDmoHwI':n} "Inner Support Stabilizer"
▶ {jol Quv yIchegh.:sen}[2]

notes.en: This is the Klingon name of Lieven L. Litaer, a {Klingon teacher from Germany:url:http://www.youtube.com/user/KlingonTeacher}.

definition.en: May your coordinates be free of tribbles!
definition.de: Mögen deine Koordinaten frei von Tribbles sein!

notes.en: A {per yuD:n} usually ends in {Qu':n:nolink}.[2]

Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchu.entry_name: Qu' buSHa'chugh SuvwI', batlhHa' vangchugh, qoj matlhHa'chugh, pagh ghaH SuvwI''e'.

definition.en: If a warrior ignores duty, acts dishonorably, or is disloyal, he is nothing.
definition.de: Falls ein Krieger seine Pflicht missachtet, sich unehrenhaft verhält, oder unloyal ist, dann ist er nichts.

definition.en: When you begin a mission, remember Aktuh and Melota.
definition.de: Wenn du eine Mission antrittst, denke immer an Aktuh und Melota.

notes.en:
There are three shifts on a Klingon ship:
▶ {Qu' poH wa'DIch:n:nolink} "duty shift"
▶ {Qu' poH cha'DIch:n:nolink} "leisure shift"
▶ {Qu' poH wejDIch:n:nolink} "sleep shift"

Qu'Daj ta'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIn.entry_name: Qu'Daj ta'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.

definition.en: To die in the line of duty is the hope of every Klingon.
definition.de: Während der Ausführung seiner Pflicht zu sterben ist der Wunsch jedes Klingonen.

definition.en: One certainly finds it useful for the mission.

notes.en: The subtitle says "You will find it useful", which was the original English line filmed.

definition.en: Klingon curse, said in moments of extreme anger
definition.de: Beleidigung, verwendet bei sehr großem Ärger

Qu'vatlh:excl.hidden_notes: In a deleted scene from {Star Trek V:src}, the response to this curse was an invective in Klingon followed by the English "Screw you too!"

notes.en: The actor who plays Gowron ({ghawran:n:name}).

When this verb is applied to a person, it suggests an improvement in health. When it is applied to an inanimate object, it implies improvement or betterment. It is distinguished from {tI':v} because that verb is not usually applied to living beings, and suggests a restoration to a previous state and not improvement. It also differs from {Dub:v} in that that verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {chalqach rachlu'ta'bogh:n:nolink} "fortified tower"[2]

notes.en: There is no single term for "nurse" in Klingon. Other possible terms for a doctor's assistant are {Qel boQ@@Qel:n:1h, boQ:n:1h} (or {HaqwI' boQ@@HaqwI':n, boQ:n:1h} if the doctor is a surgeon) and {QelHom:n:nolink}.[1]

rachwI':n.hidden_notes: Nurse "Ratch"ed, from "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

examples.en: ▶ {Soj raghmoHlu'pu'} "The food has been decayed."[2]

notes.en: This is a type of food made from live serpent worms (not to be confused with {qagh:n}).

rajma':n.hidden_notes: Rajma is red kidney bean curry.

definition.en: be trivial, be trifling, be unimportant, be insignificant
definition.sv: vara trivial, vara obetydlig, vara oviktig, vara insignifikant

notes.en: See the idiom {pollaH pagh polHa'laH:sen:idiom}.
The opposite of this is {pem:n}, not {jaj:n}.[2]
Avian life-form indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} that only comes out in the dark.
This means "be in charge of, have authority over". It would be weird for this verb to be used without an object.[2]

The subject of {rap:v:nolink} are the things which are the same.[2]

This verb can also be used to express the concept that two things have the same amount of some quality. The verb {nIb:v} is used similarly, but it is usually used with measurable qualities and has the connotation of preciseness. However, it is not improper to use {rap:v:nolink} with a quality that is measurable. See the examples below.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {ghun 'Iw HIq, rap boqrat chej.} "The bokrat liver is as warm as the bloodwine."[3]
▶ {'ey ro'qegh'Iwchab, rap qagh.} "The gagh is as delicious as the rokeg blood pie."[3]

notes.en: The name of the actress who plays B'Elanna Torres.

This can be applied to the arts, weapons, or spaceships. It refers to any activity which involves having some control over some object. In the context of swords, it can be used with a similar meaning to {yan:v}. In the context of spaceships (see {Duj:n:1}), this refers to controlling a vessel "manually", rather than by computer. See {KGT p.79:src} for an explanation of this verb.
When stapling papers together (see {Ha'on vevwI':n}), the papers are the object of {rar:v:nolink}.[2]
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

definition.sv: stanna kvar, finnas kvar, återstå, ha kvar, vara kvar

examples.en: {yIratlh!:sen}

notes.en:
Note that each floor, or level, on a vessel is called a {choQ:n} (deck).

There is a Klingon idiom, {'IQ; rav rur@@'IQ:v, rav:n:1, rur:v}.

examples.en:
▶ {Hung buv rav; patlh Hut:sen:nolink} "Classified Level 9 and Above"[1]
▶ {nen rav; chorgh ben:sen:nolink} "Ages 8 to adult"[2]

definition.sv: innertak (i ett rum med ett rum till ovanför)

notes.en:
This refers to the ceiling of a room that has a room above it. The ceiling of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure is called its {pa' beb:n}.[2]

According to a message on the {s.k:src} newsgroup, the first element of this word is {rav:n:1} "floor", but the second element is unrelated to {'eq:v} "be early".[1]
Note that this is a verb in Klingon. In Klingon, one says "it lightnings", similar to how one says "it rains" in English.

definition.en: an aquatic bird with colorful plumage

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call Terran rice.

This is a triangle where each interior angle is 40.5 {lawmey:n:nolink}, or 60 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink}. (See {law:n} and {lawrI':n}.)

For other polygons with equal sides/angles, {HoS:v} is used instead of {tIQ:v:nolink}.[2]

ra'ghom:n.hidden_notes: This word is not defined, but its meaning is clear from the example and from {ra'ghomquv:n:nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {tera' jar Soch, DIS wa' Hut jav Hut, maSDaq SaqmeH Qu' wa'DIch HochHom turlu'taHvIS, wej logh lengwI'pu' pa'mey 'oH Apollo wa'maH wa' ra'ghom bobcho' Columbia'e'.:sen:nolink} "The Apollo 11 Command Module, 'Columbia,' was the living quarters for the three-person crew during most of the first manned lunar landing mission in July 1969."

notes.en: The High Command runs the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

definition.sv: raktaj, kaffe med sprit i, ett slags dryck

notes.en: This is a drink made from liquor added to coffee. Its name may have originated as a contraction of {ra'wI' taj:n:nolink}. An "export" version called "raktajino", popular in the Federation, is not alcoholic, but has added flavour.[1, p.96]
This refers to someone of rank {Sogh:n} or higher.
{maH:n:1h}:{tlhIH:n} = {re-:v:pref,nolink}

rech:v.hidden_notes: "Retch". Also, the words for inhale and exhale together sound like "poor wretch" ({pur rech:sen:nolink}).

notes.en: This word refers to the side of a polygon. Its only appearance in canon has been between a number and one of {mey':n} or {'Impey':n}.

examples.en: {loS reD mey':n}, {vagh reD mey':n}
▶ {cheqotlhchugh maHaghbe''a'? cheDuQchugh mareghbe''a'? cheQIHchugh manoDbe''a'?:sen}

notes.en: A planet in the Romulan Star Empire.
This is a tourist drink.
There is an idiom, {tun; reghuluS 'Iwghargh rur}.
Sometimes, it may be appropriate to use {-taH:v:suff} (without {reH:adv}) to translate "always". For example, see {Duj tIvoqtaH.:sen}
The difference between this and {Quj:v} is that this refers to unstructured play, whereas {Quj:v:nolink} refers to structured play.[2]

definition.en: The used kut'luch is always shiny.
definition.de: Ein benutztes Kut'luch ist immer blank.

definition.en: I've always wanted to engage a Federation ship.
definition.de: Ich wollte schon immer ein Föderationsschiff bekämpfen.

definition.en: Your father is a part of you always.
definition.de: Dein Vater ist immer ein Teil von dir.

definition.en: Always it is the brave ones who die.
definition.de: Es sind immer die tapferen, die sterben.

definition.en: May you always find a bloodworm in your glass!
definition.de: Mögest du immer einen Blutwurm in deinem Glas finden!

reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj p.entry_name: reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj puS.

definition.en: The fire is always hotter on someone else's face.
definition.de: Auf einem anderen Gesicht ist das Feuer immer am heißesten.

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/jCLUZvNDFZw}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/jCLUZvNDFZw}

definition.en: A Klingon warrior is always prepared to fight.
definition.de: Ein Klingonenkrieger ist immer auf den Kampf vorbereitet.

definition.en: A great warrior is always prepared.
definition.de: Ein großer Krieger ist immer für den Kampf bereit.

definition.en: One is always of his tribe.
definition.de: Man gehört immer zu seinem Stamm.

definition.en: May the Klingon Empire continue forever.
definition.de: Möge das klingonische Imperium auf ewig fortbestehen.

definition.en: I will remember this dinner forever.
definition.de: Ich werde mich immer an dieses Abendessen erinnern.

definition.sv: ängslare, fjant, pessimist (person som oroar sig mycket)

notes.en: He was a follower of {tIquvma:n:name} who was given the role of {Sech qengwI':n}.
This means dazed in the sense of confused, unable to think properly, bewildered.[1] It means delusional, in this sense.[2]
notes.de: Dies bedeutet verwirrt, unfähig klar zu denken.

examples.en: ▶ {'Iw remwI':n} "vampire"

notes.en: This word is used to describe the design of a physical object of some sort; it would not be used in the sense of making a plan to do something (which would be {nab:v}). It differs from {'ogh:v}, which implies the creation of something which has not been created before.

ren:v.hidden_notes: Christopher Wren and James Renwick, Jr., were the names of two famous architects.

notes.en: One can say either {tlheH reS@@tlheH:n, reS:v} or just {reS:sen:nolink} for "he/she casts a spell". It's unclear if anything other than {tlheH:n} can be the object of {reS:v:nolink}.

A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the past for the following units:
▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {Hu':n} "days ago"
▶ {jar:n} "month" - {wen:n} "months ago"
▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {ben:n:1} "years ago"

For other units of time, {ret:n:nolink} is used.
This does not refer to how to format a paragraph.
To be more specific, one can use {tlhop:n:1}, {'em:n}, {poS:n}, or {nIH:n}. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

definition.de: zusammendrücken und auseinander ziehen (Spielen eines Dudelsacks)

notes.en: This refers to the action of alternately squeezing and stretching out the bag part of the {may'ron:n}.
This refers to the process that food goes through.

definition.sv: ge energi till, koppla på, aktivera

notes.en: One first charges up ({Huj:v:2,t}) a device before energizing ({rIH:v:nolink}) it.

This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {Sen:v} instead.

The reflexive form of this verb has a special meaning. See the example below, and under {SIq:v} for an explanation.

examples.en: ▶ {nujDajDaq rIl'egh ghu.:sen:nolink} "The baby sucks its thumb."

notes.en: The usage of this verb is restricted to the {gheb:n}, while {SuS:v} is a more general term that applies to all wind instruments.

rIl:v:2.hidden_notes: {gheb rIl:sen:nolink} is a reference to the horn of Gabriel.

notes.en: This word is used by small children, or by adults talking to or about small children. Adults typically use {SenwI':n} instead.

By itself, {rIn:v:nolink} is used in radio transmissions to indicate end of transmission, similar to "over".

This verb is used with the suffix {-taH:v} to form {rIntaH:v}, a construction used to indicate finality (cf. the suffix {-ta':v}).

This special verbal construction follows another verb to indicate that the action described by the preceding verb is a fait accompli. It is similar in meaning to the verb suffix {-ta':v:suff}, but has the additional connotation of finality.

examples.en:
▶ {luHoH rIntaH:sen:nolink}
▶ {qa'vam De' vIje' rIntaH.:sen}

rIQ:v.hidden_notes: In {TKD:src} this is defined as "be injured". The "be damaged" extension of the meaning is from {Klingon Monopoly:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {Dumer DIvI' QaS 'ej DuHIv, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIrIQchoH.:sen:nolink} "Surprise attack by Federation leaves you unprotected and damaged."[2]

definition.en: make a cracking or snapping sound, emit a signal
definition.de: ein knackendes oder klickendes Geräusch machen, ein Signal aussenden

notes.en: This originally referred only to emitting sound. Later, the meaning was extended to mean emitting any sort of signal: sound, radiation, smell, etc. In comparison, {tlhuD:v} refers only to the emission of radiation.

rIS:v.hidden_notes: Snap, Crackle, Pop are the cartoon mascots of Rice Krispies, a breakfast cereal.
rIS:v.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}

examples.en: ▶ {DurIt tlhIngan yejquv.:sen:nolink} "Summoned to the Klingon High Council."[1]

notes.en:
There is no noun in Klingon meaning "color".[1, p.81]

This also refers to ink, as for a rubber stamp ({toqwIn:n}).[2]

rItlh:n.hidden_notes: "Ritz" is a brand of paint or dye.

rI':v.hidden_notes: This was defined only as "hail". The "communication" clarification was added to distinguish it from the weather phenomenon ({Heq:v}).

examples.en: {rI'meH wovmoHwI':n}

notes.en: Do not confuse this with {ro':n}.

ro:n.hidden_notes: This is defined as "trunk (of body)" in {TKD:src} and glossed as "torso" in the text of {KGT:src}.

definition.sv: få att jäsa, bringa i jäsning

notes.en: See {KGT p.91:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {DIvI' rojmab qep ghanglu' 'e' nIDlu', 'ach taH qep.:sen:nolink} "Despite efforts to halt them, peace talks with Federation continue."[1]

notes.en: This refers to hair on the face which covers the chin and neck area.
This word is also used by Klingon grammarians to refer to the rule that governs the use of pronominal prefixes, a rule Federation grammarians call "agreement".[2]
This is considered too potent for tourists.
There is an idiom, {matlhHa'; romuluSngan rur}.
This is also called {HoHwI':n} for short.

definition.sv: vara bankande, vara rollande, vara krängande (flygmaskin roterar runt sin ländaxel), vara rullande (om tärning)

notes.en:
In the context of aircraft attitude, {HQ 11.2:src} glosses this word as "aircraft wings tilt, one up, one down". (For a pilot to roll an aircraft would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.)

In the context of playing dice, this word refers to the action of the dice as they are rolling. (To "throw" or "roll" the dice would be {ronmoH:v:nolink}.)

ron:v.hidden_notes: The aile"ron"s control the roll on an airplane.

examples.en: ▶ {mI' naghmey tIronmoH:sen:nolink} "throw dice"[2]

notes.en: Diseases are referred to by the name for the disease followed by {rop:n:nolink}.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {ruDelya' rop'a':n}
▶ {matlh rop:n:nolink} "Maltz disease" (as an example)[2]

notes.en: This is a scar which is the result of some sort of disease, infection, etc.
notes.de: Eine Narbe als Resultat einer Krankheit, Infektion, usw.

roptoj:n.hidden_notes: This was defined as just "scar", with an accompanying explanation of the kinds of scars.

examples.en: {ropyaH yIghuHmoH!:sen}

notes.en: This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

roS:v:2.hidden_notes: This little piggy had roast beef.

notes.en: According to {HQ 10.2:src}[3], this verb consists of three elements: the verb {roS:v:3,is,hyp}, {-Ha':v}, and {-moH:v}.

roSwI':n.hidden_notes: This little piggy had roast beef.

notes.en: Do not confuse this with {ro:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {ro'lIj HI'ang!:sen}

notes.en: This idiomatic expression is used to challenge someone to take action in a manner consistent with something he or she just said. (It's similar to the English expression "put your money where your mouth is".)

en: put your money where your mouth is

ruch:v.hidden_notes: This was used for "Ok" (while {qIl:v} was used for "Cancel") in Klingon Blockly.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {targhlIj yIngagh, yIruch!:sen}
▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

notes.en: Don't confuse this word with {ngaj:v}.

runpI':n.hidden_notes: From the children's rhyme, a teapot is "short" ({run:v}) and "stout" ({pI':v}).

notes.en: The gas produced is called {SIp:n} (a general word for gas of any kind) or {Qep'It:n} (a gas produced within the body).[1] To distinguish between gas emission from different orifices, use a phrase involving {nuj:n}, {Hugh:n}, or {Sa'Hut:n}.[2]

ruq:v.hidden_notes: From the Latin "eructare", or the English "eructation". The belch definition came from {HQ 12.4:src}[1]. It was expanded to also mean fart in a message to the {KLI mailing list:src}.[2]

notes.en: This is a city in {ghevchoq Sep:n}.

This verb is used to form similes, such as {puj verengan; bIQ rur@@puj:v, verengan:n, bIQ:n, rur:v} "the Ferengi is as weak as water".[2; 4] It can also be used to translate "like" in the sense of "looks like".[3]

rur:v.hidden_notes: Possibly a reference to the science fiction play R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) by Karel Čapek.

notes.en: This is a Klingon penal colony, a planet mostly covered in ice. Prisoners are sent to work in its {tlhIlHalmey:n:nolink} (see {tlhIlHal:n}).

rura' pente':n.hidden_notes: The name is based on Rorapandi, the penal colony island in the Disney movie "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea".

definition.en: He can sell ice on Rura Penthe.
definition.de: Er kann auf Rura Penthe Eis verkaufen.

notes.en: This describes a bond such as exists between blood brothers.

definition.en: be positively charged, have a positive charge

ruS:v.hidden_notes: This was defined as "have a positive charge" in the {qep'a' 2016:src} booklet, but was confirmed to be stative afterwards.

notes.en: This is a ritual that allows an orphan to join another House.

rut:adv.hidden_notes: This is defined as "sometimes" in {TKD:src} and as "occasionally" in {KGT:src}.

notes.en: This refers to part of a computer input device (see {'eQway':n}).

definition.en: be ready to collapse or die (referring to food)

notes.en: This is an upper-class word to describe food that should be eaten live.
{jIH:n:1h}:{tlhIH:n} = {Sa-:v:pref,nolink}

examples.en: ▶ {tIqwIj Sa'angnIS.:sen}
▶ {mataHmeH maSachnIS.:sen}

notes.en:
This word is also spelled {SanID:n:nolink}.

Note that Klingon has words for "ten thousand" ({netlh:n:num}) and "hundred thousand" ({bIp:n:num}) which are independent of the word for "thousand".
To indicate "millennia ago" or "millennia from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {ghojwI'pu'lI' tISaH.:sen}

SaHHa':v.hidden_notes: This word is not defined as such, but to translate "apathy" or "apathy creature" for the Klingon Christmas Carol, one of MO's suggestions was {SaHHa'wI':n:nolink} "one who is not concerned".[1]

examples.en: ▶ {chobelHa'moH, DI'qar. SajlIj 'oHbe' quvwIj'e'.:sen:nolink} "You disappoint me, D'Kar. My honor is not your plaything."[2]

definition.sv: stiga uppför, fara uppåt, slutta uppåt

notes.en:
Based on its usage in the {paq'batlh:src}, the thing being ascended is the object, and the destination is marked with {-Daq:n}.[2]

This word is not used for sort order.[3]

definition.sv: lokalisera, leta reda på, söka och finna

notes.en: See the example for an illustration of the difference between this word and {nej:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {'avwI' nejDI' narghta'bogh qama' reH 'avwI' Sambej.:sen}

notes.en: The verb {chenmoH:v} can be used with {San:n}.[2]

San:n.hidden_notes: This was defined as "fate" in {TKD:src}. It was explained in a {KLI mailing list:src} message that "destiny" is another possible translation.

notes.en: This is a scar which is the result of a wound received in the course of a fight or battle.
notes.de: Dies ist eine Narbe als Resultat einer Kampf-Verletzung.

SanDIy:n.hidden_notes: This was defined as just "scar", with an accompanying explanation of the kinds of scars.

notes.en: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n:nolink}, {'Iptay:n}.

Santay:n.hidden_notes: This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

definition.sv: anmäla sig frivillig (till), ställa upp som frivillig (till)

definition.en: land; set down on land (like a bird)

notes.en: If a bird lands on a tree, the verb {ngun:v} is used, and if on water, then {tlhot:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {SaqtaHvIS toQDuj wa'vatlh loS vI' jav chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Landing Formation Height: 36.46 M"[3]

notes.en: This is the native region of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} on {Qo'noS:n:place}, and the location of his estate.
Klingons have no tear ducts, and there is no word for tear or tears. However, Klingons eyes do redden ({DoqchoH:v:nolink}) from time to time.[2]

definition.sv: vara omväxlande, vara varierande, vara skiftande

notes.en: This animal resembles a horse.

examples.en:
▶ {ngem Sarghmey tlha':sen}
▶ {ngem Sarghmey tlha'laH:sen:nolink}

definition.en: be shallow, be superficial, be uncritical; be unfortunate, be not good
definition.sv: vara ytlig, vara okritisk, vara oturlig, vara icke-bra

notes.en: This word is applied to a person to disparage his or her intellect. It is also used by itself as an expression of disapproval, similar to {Do'Ha'.:sen}[1, p.164]
This is the name of one of the planets in the Terran solar system. It does not follow proper Klingon phonology, since it is an alien name.

Saturn:n.hidden_notes: The tweet confirms that the translation was provided by MO.

examples.en: {Saturn yIvan:sen:nolink} "Wave at Saturn"

definition.en: I salute you, I salute you all!

notes.en: This is used when addressing multiple people. To salute one person, say {qavan!:sen}
{Sawchuq:v@@Saw:v, -chuq:v} would be understood as a same-sex marriage between two men.[2]

Saw:v.hidden_notes: MO confirmed at {qep'a' 4:src} that {Saw:v:nolink} and {nay:v:nolink} come from "sure" and "no" said with a Southern drawl.

notes.en: This is the 2nd rank of {yaS:n}.

Sa'Hut:n.hidden_notes: This word was revealed during a session of singing and dancing the Hokey Pokey. It is the Yiddish word "tuchus" written backwards.

notes.en:
This is a large region several thousand kilometers east of the First City ({veng wa'DIch:n}). In the dialect of this region, prepositionals take suffixes (see under {lurgh:n} for an explanation). Furthermore, toasts follow the normal word order, with the subject following the verb (see {-jaj:v}).

This region contains {HuD beQ yoS:n}.

Sa'Qej Sep:n.hidden_notes:
This is basically "jackass" spelled backwards.

This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

notes.en: This is a ceremonial position whose role is to activate the Beacon of Kahless.

examples.en:
▶ {Segh - bI'rel tlharghDuj:sen:nolink} "Model - B'rel Scout"[2]
▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}
▶ {vISeHmeH Hoch nuHmey Qay!:sen}

notes.en:
This word appears to consist of {SeH:v} (or a homophonous element) and {law:n:archaic} (or an otherwise unattested homophone).

This can be used for a "settings" or "preferences" page in software, but not individual settings, which are {DuH:n}.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {leng Dotlh SeHwI' pat:n}
▶ {muD ngeb SeHwI' pat:n}

notes.en: Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIl:v:1} instead.
Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIlwI':n} instead.

This is the name of a Federation starship (神舟 in Chinese).

As this is a non-Klingon name, there is some variation in how Klingons pronounce it. Some pronounce it more like {Senjaw:n:name,nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan quv DatIchDI' Seng yIghuH.:sen}

notes.en: Klingons breed some small animals for food.[2]
There is an idiom, {let mInDu'Daj; Separmey rur}.

definition.en: be formal, be ritualistic, be ceremonial
definition.sv: vara formell, vara rituell, vara ceremoniell
