SeQpIr:n.hidden_notes: His original Klingon name was never spoken in {Star Trek VI:src}, where he was only referred to as "Shakespeare".

notes.en: This can be applied to music.[2, p.71]

Se'tu':n.hidden_notes: This word is composed of {Se':n} and {tu':v}, which suggests that Klingons believe Terran saucepans to be satellite dishes. According to the explanation by {qe'San:n:name,nolink}, this was apparently based on "set-to" because there was a heated discussion about it.

notes.en: This word refers to a publication of any kind, whether printed or not.

Se'vIr malja':n.hidden_notes: This is a pun on the name of a well-known Terran publishing house.

notes.en: This refers to a device used for two-way communication. For the device which receives (but does not send) an audio signal, see {wab HevwI':n}.

definition.sv: senare, så småningom, om ett tag, tids nog

examples.en: ▶ {chaw'vam yIpol 'ej SIbI'Ha' yIlo' pagh 'oH yImech.} "This card may be kept until needed or traded."[1]

SID:n.hidden_notes: The actor Sid James played a patient in "Carry On Doctor". There are a number of medical abbreviations written "SID".

examples.en: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

notes.en: When used in the slang sense, this verb does not take an object.[1, p.164]

definition.en: type of knife (used for food preparation)

notes.en: This is used for finer work in cooking.
This is larger than a {neSlo':n}.

SIla':n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There", the sequel to "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland".

notes.en: See under {boq:v} for the basic mathematical operations.

When used with nouns marked with {-Daq:n}, the finger verbs mean "point (with that finger) at or towards" the object indicated by that noun.

There are some special cases of the reflexive (with {-'egh:v}) forms of the finger verbs. See the example below, and also under {rIl:v:1}.

If an implement is used for an activity typically performed by a finger, a finger verb may be used.

examples.en:
▶ {maghwI'Daq jISIq.:sen:nolink} "I point at the traitor with my index finger."[1]
▶ {ghIchwIj vISIq.:sen:nolink} "I touch my nose with my index finger."[1]
▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq:sen:nolink} "I point at my nose with my index finger."[1]
▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq'egh.:sen:nolink} "I pick my nose with my index finger."[1]
▶ {maghwI'Daq SIq naQjejwIj.:sen:nolink} "My spear points at the traitor."[1]
▶ {ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh pa' DaqHomvetlh wovDaq HInej.:sen}[2]

notes.en: Klingons use {SIQ:v:nolink} rather than {tIv:v} for some things that humans might consider pleasant or neutral.

SIrgh:n.hidden_notes: For "string" as in the variable type, see under {ghItlh:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {baS SIrgh:n}

SIrlIy:n.hidden_notes: Shirley Silver is an American linguist with whom Marc Okrand has worked in the past.

notes.en: This is an old word. Maltz liked this better than {may' Sut:n}.

SIr'o':n.hidden_notes: Shiro is the mass of thread-like hyphae which constitutes the mycelium, or vegetative part, of a fungus. This word was revealed to translate "mycelial network" for {DSC:src}.
SIr'o':n.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

notes.en: This verb can take an object. Its subject is usually unstated.[2]

SIS:v.hidden_notes: It's the sound of rain falling.

examples.en:
▶ {ghIq QavwI'chaj DuQchu' qeylIS betleH chaHDaq SIStaHvIS negh 'Iw:sen:nolink}
  "Then Kahless's bat'leth pierced the last of them, showered with the soldiers' blood."[3]

SIS yoD:n.hidden_notes: MO said at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that the apparent noun {SIS:n:hyp} is a fossilized remnant which is probably limited to this expression.[2]

notes.en: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object. When used as the second verb in a sentence as object construction, it is usually translated as "wonder if".[2]

SIv:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}, probably as a joke to make us wonder if it was a mistake.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISIv.:sen:nolink} "I wonder if you speak Klingon."  This means something like, "I am curious about whether you speak Klingon."[2]

definition.en: seventh tone of nonatonic musical scale
definition.sv: sjunde tonen på den nonatoniska skalan

notes.en: The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2,nolink}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.
This is the 7th rank of {yaS:n}.

definition.en: May the spirit of Kahless live within you.
definition.de: Möge der Geist Kahless' in dir leben.

notes.en:
This word applies to both food and beverages[2], or anything consumed for sustenance.[5] A single dish or course is called a {nay':n}.[2]

This word carries the idiomatic meaning of "matter, concern, affair". For example, {tlhIngan Soj 'oH; not bIyaj:sen:nolink} means "It is a Klingon matter -- you'll never understand."[3]

Soj:n.hidden_notes: The example appears to be missing a conjunction.

examples.en:
▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink}
  "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[4]

notes.en: This is rare unless the meal was interrupted.[1, p.102]
Of course, {Soj naQmey:n:nolink} are always used in pairs.
This refers to a food storage room.
This is usually served only on the most formal occasions.
The verb to use for compiling such a list is {gher:v}.
This refers to food that no one has done anything to.[1, p.84]

Soj tlhol:n.hidden_notes: The example appears to be missing a conjunction.

examples.en:
▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink}
  "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[2]

notes.en: See {KGT p.84:src}.

Son:v.hidden_notes: It is unclear whether this verb is used for the relief of pain, anxiety, distress, etc., or for the removal of someone from active duty. If it is used for the latter, then it is related in meaning to {cho':v} and {gheS:v}, and perhaps it also forms the first part of {SonchIy:n}.

notes.en: This is a ceremony which either precedes or is the initial part of the Rite of Succession (see {cho'tay:n:hyp}).

SonchIy:n.hidden_notes: Perhaps this word is related to {Son:v} and {che':v}.

notes.en: This is a typo for {Suq:v:nolink} which appeared in {HQ 6.2:src} in the transcription of {SkyBox 33:src}. The word is spelled correctly as {Suq:v:nolink} on the card itself.
Do not confuse this word with {QIch:n}.

There is an idiom, {lugh; Sor rur@@lugh:v, Sor:n, rur:v}, which is connected to the verb {Sor:v}.

This word can also refer to the "club" suit in a deck of playing cards (see {Degh:n:1}).[2]
This verb is connected with the idiom, {lugh; Sor rur@@lugh:v, Sor:n, rur:v}.
One kind of {Sor Hap 'In:n} is a tube which is open on both ends, with a longitudinal slit which doesn't go all the way to either end, and which is struck with a {mupwI'Hom:n}.

Sorpuq:n.hidden_notes: This is "kupros" backwards, a reference to "Cyprus" which is the origin of the English word "copper".

notes.en: The siblings of a {SoS:n} are {me':n} and {'IrneH:n}.

SoS:n.hidden_notes: The joke with {vav:n:nolink} and {SoS:n:nolink} is that in most human languages, the words for "father" and "mother" contain simple labial sounds (typically either "b" or "p" for father, and "m" for mother), whereas the fricatives {v:sen:nolink} and {S:sen:nolink} are difficult sounds for human infants to make. Also, "SOS" is an internationally recognised distress signal.

notes.en: Known only from {De'wI' SoSbor'a':n}.

SoS taj:n.hidden_notes: This is only spoken in Klingon in {KCD:src}, with no English translation. It is unclear whether it's one word or two.

notes.en: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISov.:sen:nolink} "I know that you speak Klingon."[2]

notes.en: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

SovmoH:v.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

notes.en: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used instead of {ghIH:v:1}.

If there is no object, then the subject is the one hiding (e.g., {nuqDaq So'taH yaS?:sen:nolink}[1]). If there is an object, then the subject is hiding the object (e.g., {Duj So':sen:nolink} or {Duj So'lu'pu':sen:nolink}[2]).

This verb is also used for the encryption of data.[3]
When this term is used for the decryption of data, it implies that the decryption is authorized and the way to do it is known.[1]

So'wI':n.hidden_notes: On {SkyBox 33:src}, the last two Klingon sentences were not translated into English: "A cloaking device which didn't disrupt weaponry was installed in one experimental ship. This ship was demonstrated on Stardate 9521.6 but it was destroyed."

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/BpdgUluBJOQ}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/BpdgUluBJOQ}

notes.en: {tlhIH:n}:{pagh:n:1h} = {Su-:v:pref,nolink}

definition.en: be brave, be heroic, be bold, be valient, be intrepid
definition.sv: vara modig, vara heroisk, vara djärv, vara dristig, vara

Sub:n.hidden_notes: A "sub" (submarine sandwich) is also called a "hero" in some places. Also, "sub" is the opposite of "super" as in "superhero".

Such:v.hidden_notes: The German verb for "to visit" is "besuchen".

examples.en:
▶ {vogh vISuch vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit some place."[2]
▶ {loHwI' vISuch 'e' vIpoQ!:sen}[3]

SuD:v:1.hidden_notes: All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v} and {SuD:v:1,nolink}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

definition.en: gamble, take a chance, take a risk

examples.en: ▶ {Doq'a' SuvwI'pu'?:sen} {ghobe'. SuD.:sen:nolink}[2]

notes.en: The literal meaning of this idiomatic expression is "Fek'lhr's eyes are green".

This is also written as {Su':excl:nolink}. Some speakers of Klingon pronounce this word as if it were {SSS:excl:nolink}.

This exclamation indicates that the speaker is about to give a command, or is ready to do something or that arrangements have been made for something to happen. ({TKD 5.5:src})

examples.en: ▶ {qaSuj'a'?:sen}

notes.en:
The use of this word involves the concept of deixis. It usually implies the subject is near the speaker, unless the context is set up to indicate the action is taking place somewhere else (for example, using {-Daq:n}). The suffix {-chuq:v} is not used with this verb.[2]

The expression {jISum:sen:nolink} has an idiomatic philosophical meaning, "I'm in touch with my inner self" (in a Klingon way).[2]

examples.en: ▶ {yuQ SumDaq cha'puj law' Datu'.} "Detect large sums of dilithium on nearby planet."[3]

Sup:v.hidden_notes: "Sup"erman can jump higher than a building.

notes.en: This is a type of {HurDagh:n}.

Supghew:n.hidden_notes: The word "ukelele" means "jumping flea" in Hawaiian.

definition.sv: förvärva, skaffa (sig), få, erhålla, få tag i

examples.en: ▶ {ghewmey tISuqQo'.:sen}

definition.en: prepare kud in a specific way
definition.sv: bereda qud på ett särskilt sätt

notes.en: See {KGT p.91:src}.
This might be used for the core of an apple, a planet, or the Sun. But it is not used to refer to the core of a group, which is {qolqoS:n}.

definition.sv: flå, skala, dra av skinnet på

SuS:n.hidden_notes: It sounds like the wind blowing.

definition.en: blow (into wind instrument) to produce sound
definition.de: (in ein Blasinstrument) blasen um ein Geräusch zu erzeugen
definition.sv: blåsa (i blåsinstrument) för att producera ljud

notes.en:
This is a general term which is applied to all wind instruments, while {rIl:v:2} is restricted to the {gheb:n}.[2]

This can also be used for blowing out a candle. Unlike with {jo':v}, air gets out of the thing that's blown onto/into/at (or never goes into it). If {-Daq:n} is used, it implies a miss: air was blown towards the object, but bypassed it.[3]

This is a category of musical instruments with a flexible bag which is alternately filled with and emptied of air. The sound is produced by the air passing over strips of material which vibrate (see {joQ:n:2}). Known types of {SuSDeq:n:nolink} include the {may'ron:n} and the {DIron:n}.
From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n:nolink}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.

Sutay:n.hidden_notes: This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

notes.en: The afterlife for the honored dead, where all true warriors go after they die to fight an eternal battle. The closest Klingon equivalent to heaven.

Suto'vo'qor:n.hidden_notes: Used by DeCandido in 2001 novel {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}; confirmed by MO at {qep'a' 2010:src}.

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

examples.en:
▶ {bISutlhnISchugh jaghlI' mInDu' tIbej.:sen}
▶ {bISuv 'e' yIwIv; bISutlh 'e' yIwIvQo'.:sen}

notes.en: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

definition.en: If a warrior does not fight, he does not breathe.
definition.de: Wenn ein Krieger nicht kämpft, dann atmet er nicht.

definition.en: Brute strength is not the most important asset in a fight.
definition.de: Reine Kraft ist nicht das wichtigste in einem Kampf.

definition.en: Klingons are born to fight and to conquer.
definition.de: Klingonen werden geboren um zu kämpfen und zu erobern.

notes.en: This word refers to a specific warrior. For warriorhood as concept, see {vaj:n}.
Calling someone a {Suy':n:nolink} is considered insulting, comparable to calling someone a "pig" in Federation Standard.[1, p.196]

Suy':n.hidden_notes: "Sooey" is a sound used in calling pigs. The Hog Call, a traditional cheer at the University of Arkansas, goes "Woo, Pig! Sooey!"

notes.en: In {TNK:src}, sugar (common table sugar) is translated as {Su'ghar qutmey:n:nolink}. Presumably, then, a single {Su'ghar qut:n:nolink} would be one grain of sugar.
This is partially digested and used as a sauce called {quD:n}

This is a general term for any kind of raised profile or relief, such as the ridges on the fingertips, the patterns on a car tire, or the profile of a shoe. It cannot be used for the ridges on the forehead, though.

This word is contrasted with {vem:n}, which is the trace left behind when someone touches something. For example, compare {nItlh Su'nIm:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n} "fingerprint" (ridges on fingertip) with {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} "fingerprint" (mark left behind after touching).

When used to refer to the fingerprint, etc., as a body part, this word takes the plural suffix {-Du':n}. (Otherwise, it takes the suffix {-mey:n}.)

In the following examples, the specific finger or toe name can be used instead of {nItlh:n} and {yaD:n:1}.

examples.en:
▶ {nItlh Su'nIm:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n} fingerprint (ridges on fingertip)
▶ {yaD Su'nIm:n@@yaD:n:1, Su'nIm:n} toe print (ridges on toe tip)
▶ {bem Su'nIm:n@@bem:n, Su'nIm:n} footprint (patterns on sole)
▶ {toqwIn Su'nIm:n@@toqwIn:n, Su'nIm:n} surface of a (rubber) stamp

definition.en: We will meet in the cocktail lounge.
definition.de: Wir treffen uns in der Cocktail-Lounge.

notes.en: This word also has the idiomatic sense of "don't move!" when given as a command, either as {yItaD:sen@@yI-:v, taD:v} (spoken to one person) or {petaD:sen@@pe-:v, taD:v} (spoken to a group of people).[2; 3] To order someone to literally freeze, the suffixes {-'egh:v} and {-moH:v} would be used: {yItaD'eghmoH:sen@@yI-:v, taD:v, -'egh:v, -moH:v} "Freeze yourself!" ("Cause yourself to be frozen!")[3]
The name of an ice-covered colony planet in the Klingon Empire. Its name literally means "frozen" ({taD:v}).

definition.sv: inleda en process, börja, sätta igång, starta

notes.en:
The subject of this verb is the person or thing starting the process, and the object is the process. For example: {Qu' DataghDI' 'aqtu' mellota' je tIqaw.:sen} "When you begin a mission, remember Aktuh and Mellota."[2]

If the starter of the process is unknown, unclear, or indefinite, the process becomes the subject of the verb (in which case it takes no object): {taghbej mu'qaD veS:sen:nolink} "Curse-warfare has definitely begun."[3]

Instead of using the verb {tagh:v:nolink}, consider using the verb suffix {-choH:v:suff}. For example, a student who is a beginner might be described as a {ghojchoHwI'} (one who is beginning to learn) or said to be {ghojchoH} (beginning to learn).

examples.en: ▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]

notes.en: This refers to a ship in space which has rotated its nose downwards. A rotation through a negative angle of 90 degrees would mean that the ship's nose was pointed straight down relative to its previous orientation.[2]

taHjaj wo':sen.hidden_notes: This song was composed by Rich Yampell, a.k.a. {HoD Qanqor:n:name,nolink}. Note that ordinarily, a rank such as {HoD:n} follows the name in Klingon, but {HoD Qanqor:n:name,nolink} comes from a region where one's rank precedes one's name.

definition.en: To be or not to be.

taH pagh taHbe'.:sen.hidden_notes: These lines have been translated from the original Klingon by Nick Nicholas and Andrew Strader.

definition.en: extra blade on a d'k tahg

definition.de: Messertyp (mit besonders langer Klinge, fast wie ein Schwert gehandhabt)

notes.en: Angles are measured in {lawrI':n} (or {law:n} in more ancient times or in traditional documents).[2]

talarngan:n.hidden_notes: Presumably, there is a place called {talar:n:place,fic,nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {cha'pujqutmey chIm lutamlu'.} "Drained dilithium crystals are replaced."[2]

notes.en: This appeared in {STC 104:src} as {DIvI' tamey ngo':n:nolink} "Federation Archives". A single archive record would be {ta ngo':n:nolink}.
A dim light would be {tamghay wovHa':n@@tamghay:n, wov:v, -Ha':v} (whereas {tamghay Hurgh:n@@tamghay:n, Hurgh:v} sounds odd).

tamghay:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Tom G. Smith of Industrial Light & Magic, who oversaw visual effects production for {Star Trek II:src} and {Star Trek III:src}.

tamler:n.hidden_notes: A reference to Tom Lehrer, who performed the song "The Elements" about the chemical elements.

definition.sv: ett slags djur (snarlik en tjur, används om både hannar och honor)

notes.en: This word was used in {ghIlghameS:n:nolink}, where {QI'tu' tangqa':n:nolink} refers to the Bull of Heaven.

tangqa':n.hidden_notes: The Lakota or Sioux word for "buffalo" is "tatanka".

tap:v.hidden_notes: A reference to the sound made.

examples.en: ▶ {yIntaH qIrq 'e' vIneH. DaSwIj bIngDaq latlhpu' vItap.:sen:nolink} "Kirk I want alive. The rest I will grind beneath my boot."[2]

notes.en:
The residents of this region greatly outnumber the residents of {Qotmagh Sep:n}.

This dialect is sort of half-way between the standard dialect and the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect. Speakers replace {b:sen:nolink} with {mb:sen:nolink} and {D:sen:nolink} with {ND:sen:nolink}.[1, p.22]

taq'ev Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} on p.22 and not in the glossary. It appears as {taq'ev:n:nolink} and not as {taq'ev Sep:n:nolink}, but it is implied that this is the name of a region (see {Sep:n}).

notes.en: This means "weird" as in bizarre, unnatural, maybe creepy.[2]

taQ:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

taQbang:n:1.hidden_notes: This is a reference to a line from the movie "Dr. Strangelove" ({taQ:v}, {bang:n}): "A big plane like a '52... varrrooom! Its jet exhaust... frying chickens in the barnyard!"

notes.en: This is just a Federation Standard word with Klingon pronunciation.
This is a kind of animal somewhat resembling a dog. It is popular as a pet, but its heart is also considered a delicacy.[2]

definition.de: Geh und paare dich mit deinem Targ!

targhlIj yab tIn law' no'lI' Hoch yabDu'.entry_name: targhlIj yab tIn law' no'lI' Hoch yabDu' tIn puS!

definition.en: Your targ has a bigger brain than all your ancestors put together!
definition.de: Dein Targ hat mehr Hirn als alle deine Vorfahren zusammen!

taSman:n.hidden_notes: The Tasman Sea separates Australia from New Zealand, and is colloquially called "the Ditch".

notes.en: This verb means to return something somewhere, for example a weapon to the weapons rack. To express the concept of returning to a place, use {chegh:v}.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {raSDaq jengva' vItatlh.:sen:nolink} "I return the plate to the table."[1]

notes.en: This word is similar to {chegh:v}, but suggests the action was forced.

examples.en: ▶ {pa'Daq jItatlh'egh.:sen:nolink} "I return to the room."  The implication here is that it is difficult or not desirable to return to the room.[1]

notes.en: This is what someone might do to wake somebody up, or what one might do to a drink or a limb. What freezing temperatures may do to someone is {jelmoH:v@@jel:v, -moH:v}, not {tav:v:nolink}.
notes.de: Das ist was man macht, um jemanden zu wecken, oder was man mit einem Getränk macht. Was kalte Temperaturen mit einem machen, ist {jelmoH:v@@jel:v, -moH:v}, nicht {tav:v:nolink}.

notes.en: This is the physical counterpart of {He:n}.

taw:n.hidden_notes: A reference to the Tao (道), obviously.

tay:v.hidden_notes: Klingons apparently consider a people to be civilized if they have rituals (see {tay:n:2}).

tay:n:2.hidden_notes: This is something that "tie"s a community together. Also, the procedure of putting on a neck"tie" is a kind of ritual.

notes.en: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3,nolink}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.

tay:n:3.hidden_notes: This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

notes.en: This word seems to be composed of {tay:n:2} or {tay:v} and {qeq:n} or {qeq:v}. Perhaps this is an indication of what Klingons consider important to a civilisation.
This verb is also used to specify membership in a Klingon House (see explanation under {tuq:n}).
A planet in the Klingon Empire, where the induction into the Order of the Bat'leth takes place.[2]

definition.de: Blut und Wasser vermischen sich nicht.

examples.en: ▶ {vIta'pu'be'.:sen}
▶ {ta'mey Dun, bommey Dun.:sen}

notes.en: This is short for {ta' tlhIngan Hol:n}.
This is the standard dialect of Klingon. It is also called {ta' Hol:n} for short.
This verb may be used for filling a hole ({QemjIq:n}), but not for merely stopping up an opening ({qung:n}), which would be {qorgh:v}.[2]

definition.en: food server in a Dok'e (fast-food restaurant)

teH:v.hidden_notes: The computer programming control flow concepts "if" and "while" were translated as {teHchugh:sen:nolink} and {teHtaHvIS:sen:nolink}, respectively, in Klingon Blockly. Setting a boolean variable to "true" was translated as {teHmoH:sen:nolink}, while setting one to "false" was translated as {teHbe'moH:sen:nolink}.[4]

tel:n.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

notes.en: This is the home planet of a founding member of the United Federation of Planets ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).
This star system is located near the Federation-Klingon border, and contains the two planets {Doy'yuS:n} and {'elaS:n}.
This means "contradict, disavow, claim as false" and the like. It does not mean "refuse, reject, turn down, don't permit".[2]

definition.sv: gå ombord, ge sig in på

notes.en: The child of a {tennuS:n:nolink} is a {tey':n:1}.

tennuS:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to "Uncle Tenoose" from the Danny Thomas Show.

notes.en: This is used only for numbered pages in a book or something similar.

examples.en: ▶ {tep jolpat - wa':sen:nolink} "Cargo Transporter - 1"

notes.en: In the {BoP:src} poster, this is a type of crane.
For the removal of something from the interior, consider {lel:v}.

This is the name of the Human Homeworld. For "earth" in the sense of "dirt", see {lam:n}.

The continents of Earth are:
▶ {'amerI'qa' tIng chan tIng:n} "South America"
▶ {'amerI'qa' 'ev chan 'ev:n} "North America"
▶ {'antartIq:n} "Antarctica"
▶ {'aSralya':n} "Australia"
▶ {'aSya':n} "Asia"
▶ {'avrI'qa':n} "Africa"
▶ {'ewrop:n} "Europe"

There is an idiom, {Hoj; tera'ngan rur}.

Note that a human ({Human:n}) is a member of the major indigenous language-capable species of Earth ({tera':n:place}), whereas Terran ({tera'ngan:n:nolink}) refers to any inhabitant of the planet.
If the context is clear, this may be shortened to {nagh DIr charwI':n:nolink}.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.

This term is used in the invitation to {Star Trek The Exhibition:src}. The invitation reads:
▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998".[1]

Based on the information on the invitation, when telling an Earth date:
▶ the days of the week are mapped to their Klingon analogues (see under {Hogh:n});
▶ {jar:n} followed by a number labels the month, starting with January, {jar wa':n:nolink};
▶ the day of the month is given as an ordinal, {jaj loSDIch:n:nolink} "the fourth day";
▶ the year is specified by giving its digits after the word {DIS:n:2}.[1]

The Terran months are:
▶ {jar wa':n:nolink} "January"
▶ {jar cha':n:nolink} "February"
▶ {jar wej:n:nolink} "March"
▶ {jar loS:n:nolink} "April"
▶ {jar vagh:n:nolink} "May"
▶ {jar jav:n:nolink} "June"
▶ {jar Soch:n:nolink} "July"
▶ {jar chorgh:n:nolink} "August"
▶ {jar Hut:n:nolink} "September"
▶ {jar wa'maH:n:nolink} "October"
▶ {jar wa'maH wa':n:nolink} "November"
▶ {jar wa'maH cha':n:nolink} "December"
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fungus.
This refers to the Terran plant.
This refers to the organ of hearing inside the head, while {qogh:n:2,body} refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, etc.
The object is the thing which is melted.
This word can be used for anything rolled up like a scroll, and has also commonly come to denote any kind of list, while {Qumran:n} refers to a more ceremonial kind of scroll.[3]

tetlh:n.hidden_notes:
The Klingon phrase as printed on the {BoP:src} poster contains typos.

This word was used for the "list" variable type in Klingon Blockly.[4]

notes.en: Aside from its literal meaning, this can also be used for the sense of being close or not having wiggle room or leeway in a situation. See {tey:v:2}.[2]

definition.en: be uncomfortable, be close, not have wiggle room or leeway

examples.en: ▶ {tey yay:sen:@@tey:v:2, yay:n:2h} (this describes something which was just barely a victory or a last-minute victory, or something like that)

definition.en: be comfortable, be not close, have wiggle room or leeway

examples.en: ▶ {teybe' yay:sen@@tey:v:2, -be':v, yay:n:2h} "the victory didn't scrape", "the victory was comfortable"

notes.en: This means "file" in the sense of a nail file and the like, not a data file (for which see {ta:n}).

teywI':n.hidden_notes: This is defined as "file" in {KGT:src}. The "tool" part was added for clarification.

definition.sv: kusin (fars brors ({tennuS:n}s) barn eller mors systers ({me':n}s) barn)

notes.en: This word refers to one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child (i.e., "parallel cousins").

definition.sv: brorsbarn (en mans brors barn), systerbarn (en kvinnas systers barn)

notes.en: For a man, this word refers to the child of his brother. For a woman, it refers to the child of her sister.

definition.sv: kvinnlig kusin (fars brors dotter eller mors systers dotter),

notes.en: A female {tey':n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's child or one's father's brother's child, or a niece in the sense of a man's brother's daughter or a woman's sister's daughter.

definition.sv: manlig kusin (fars brors son eller mors systers son), brorson (en mans brors son), systerson (en kvinnas systers son)

notes.en: A male {tey':n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's sister's son or one's father's brother's son, or nephew in the sense of a man's brother's son or a woman's sister's son.

{SoH:n}:{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {tI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
{tlhIH:n}:{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {tI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
This word appears on {KGT p.132:src}, but based on the context it is clearly a typo for {bIt:v}.

examples.en:
▶ {tlhIngan tIgh DaHaDrup'a'?} (one of several inscriptions used by MO when signing books or photos)
▶ {tlhIngan tIgh - SuvwI' DevmeH paq@@tlhIngan:n, tIgh:n, SuvwI':n, DevmeH paq:n} "The Klingon Way - A Warrior's Guide"[2]

notes.en: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur:sen@@Dogh:v, tIghla':n, rur:v}.[1, p.127]
This word refers to any energy beam. It is an extension of the traditional meaning of {tIH:n:2} (spear shaft) to modern weaponry.[2, p.65]

examples.en: ▶ {luHwI' tIH:n}

notes.en: This word has been adapted for modern weaponry; see {tIH:n:1} (energy beam).

examples.en: ▶ {nuqDaq lupwI' mIr vItIj?@@nuqDaq:ques, lupwI' mIr:n, vI-:v, tIj:v} "Where is the train station?"[2]

tIn:v.hidden_notes: A "tin" is a box used to hold "match"es.

definition.en: area southwestward, area towards the southwest

notes.en: This is approximately 220 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.

definition.en: all around, all over the place

examples.en: ▶ {tIngvo' 'evDaq chanDaq jIlengpu'.:sen:nolink} "I've traveled all over the place."[1]

notes.en: This is the midway point between the cardinal directions {tIng:n} and {'ev:n}. It is also referred to as {'ev tIng:n:nolink} with about the same frequency.[1] It is 270 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.
This is a type of {HurDagh:n}.

definition.sv: vara lång, vara långsträckt (om ett föremål)

notes.en: Don't confuse this word with {nI':v}.
The verb used for "beat" (as in a heartbeat) is {joq:v}.

tIq:n.hidden_notes: Tick tock, the sound of a heart beat. The heart is also colloquially called the "ticker".

examples.en: ▶ {tIqDaq HoSna' tu'lu'.:sen}

definition.en: Real power is in the heart.
definition.de: Die wahre Kraft liegt im Herzen.

definition.en: Hit them hard and hit them fast.

notes.en: An edged weapon, similar to an Earth longsword.
The tknag is a dangerous carnivore native to the Klingon planet Taganika.[2]

definition.sv: en slags mat, tknag-hovar, (refereras alltid till i plural)

notes.en: As a food item, they are always referred to in the plural.

T'Kuvma was proclaimed to be "T'Kuvma the Unforgettable" ({tIquvma lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':sen:nolink}) by his followers, in an allusion to Kahless the Unforgettable (see {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}).

His supporters include {lIr'el:n:name} and {voq:n:name}. His flagship is a sarcophagus ship covered in coffins (see {nebeylI':n}, {nev'aQ:n}, {pel'aQ:n:2}).

definition.en: I must show you my heart.
definition.de: Ich muss euch mein Herz zeigen.
definition.ru: Мне надо вам покозать свою сердцу.
definition.zh_HK: 我必須向你展示出我的心。

notes.en: This verb is also used for equilateral triangles (see {ra'Duch tIQ:n}).
This refers to the physical piece of dried bread, and not to the exclamations made while drinking.

definition.sv: njuta av, roa sig, ha roligt, tycka om

notes.en:
For verbs used to express the enjoyment of food or music among Klingons, see {DuQ:v:2} and {'ey:v}.[2]

Klingons do not typically speak about music in terms of enjoyment, but rather in terms of what it does to the listener. For example, music might be said to {jaqmoH:v}, {SeymoH:v}, {tungHa':v}, or {pIlmoH:v}.[2]

tIw:v.hidden_notes: It is stated that this cannot take an object.
tIw:v.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

notes.en: Unlike {rach:v}, this verb is not typically applied to beings, and it suggests only restoration to a previous state (and not necessarily improvement).[2]
There is an idiom, {bIt; tI'qa' vIghro' rur@@bIt:v, tI'qa' vIghro':n, rur:v}.

tI'qa' vIghro':n.hidden_notes: {bIt:v:nolink} is actually written incorrectly as {tIb:v:nolink} on {KGT p.132:src}, in the statement of the idiom.

notes.en: The son of Barot. See {barot:n}.

definition.sv: slutgiltigt pröva, testa (på ett avgörande sätt), bevisa

examples.en: ▶ {vaj toDDujDaj ngeHbej DIvI'.:sen:nolink}

notes.en: For courage of a surprising or unexpected kind, see {qajunpaQ:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}

definition.en: A beard is a symbol of courage.
definition.de: Ein Bart ist ein Symbol des Mutes.

notes.en: This is roughly like the English "Aha!" ({TKD 5.5:src})
If the deception involves honor or social status, see {Qaq:v}.

tojbogh pa' tuH:n.hidden_notes: In {STC 104:src} this was given as the plural {tojbogh pa' tuHmey:n:nolink} "Holodeck Adventures".

notes.en: This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This refers to a single technique executed in a fight or, by extension, a single maneuver played in a game.

tonSaw':n.hidden_notes: To translate "The Final Reflection", where "reflection" is a maneuver in a game (see {tlhInja:n}), Maltz suggested {tonSaw' Qav:n:nolink} or {neSlo' tonSaw' Qav:n:nolink}.[3]

notes.en: This is a rare mineral which is mined.
There is an idiom, {tlhIb; toppa' rur}.
Its small eggs are eaten whole, shell and all, by the handful.[1, p.88]

This refers to a tool or device, and not a postage stamp (for which see {HIjmeH chaw':n}).

To use such a stamp, one must first ink it up ({laS:v}) with an ink pad ({rItlh 'echlet:n}), then slam it down ({Dut:v}). The resulting image is called a {yang:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {toqwIn vIDut@@toqwIn:n, vI-:v, Dut:v} "I slam down the stamp."

definition.en: type of animal, similar to Terran bird of prey

notes.en: This verb describes the action of a person or animal. There is a homophonous verb {tor:v:2} which seems to describe a similar action applied to aircraft or spacecraft.

definition.en: pitch (aircraft tilts nose up or down)
definition.de: sich neigen (Spitze des Flugzeugs geht nach oben oder nach unten)
definition.sv: vara tippande, vara vippande (flygmaskin rör nosen upp eller ner)

notes.en:
There is a homophonous verb {tor:v:1} which describes a similar action undertaken by a person or animal.

Pitching downwards is indicated using a negative angle (see {taH:v:2}).

tor:v:2.hidden_notes: The eleva"tor"s control the pitch on an airplane.

notes.en: He is father to Pok ({paq:n:2,name}).
Based on its usage in the {paq'batlh:src}, the thing being climbed is the object, the destination is marked with {-Daq:n}, and the starting point is marked with {-vo':n}.[2]
This is the 3rd rank of {yaS:n}.
This refers to a moment of clarity between two warriors on the field of battle.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.:sen}
▶ {DIHIvbe'chugh qo'chajDaq toy'wI''a' DImoj!:sen}

definition.en: to take some time to consider a matter

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "to chew ligament".

examples.en:
▶ {to'waQ yIyIv.:sen:nolink} "Take your time thinking about it."
▶ {to'waQ vIyIvtaH.:sen:nolink} "I'm in the process of taking my time considering the matter."
▶ {to'waQ yIyIvQo', DaH yIwuq!:sen:nolink} "Don't chew ligament, decide now!"

notes.en: {tlhIH:n}:{jIH:n:1h} = {tu-:v:pref,nolink}
In comparison, {'op pIq:n@@'op:n, pIq:n} means "at some point in the future".

definition.en: to prophesize, see the future, know the future

notes.en: For Klingons, to prophesize is to be able to "summon" the future somehow.
This could also be shortened to {rItwI':n:nolink} if the context is clear.

examples.en: ▶ {Dujeychugh jagh nIv yItuHQo'.:sen}
▶ {tojbogh pa' tuH:n}

▶ {tujqu'choH QuQ.:sen}
▶ {ghorgh tujchoHpu' bIQ?:sen}

definition.en: A warrior's blood boils before the fire is hot.
definition.de: Das Blut des Kriegers kocht, bevor das Feuer heiß ist.

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/pS5XfZGmy34}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/pS5XfZGmy34}

notes.en: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {paq nojwI' tum:n}
▶ {QIn tum:n}

notes.en: This can be applied to music.[2, p.71]

tungyen:n.hidden_notes: Tung-Yen Lin was a pioneer in standardising the use of prestressed concrete.

notes.en:
To say "Kahlor of the House of Molor", one simply says {qeylor, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, House of Molor". To be more formal, one can add the father's name, as in {qeylor, qeylIn puqloD, molor tuq:sen:nolink} "Kahlor, son of Kahlin, (of the) House of Molor".[2]

Another formal and slightly archaic way to express membership in a House is to use the verb {tay':v}:
▶ {tay' qeylor molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "Kahlor is of the House of Molor"
▶ {matay' jIH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "I am of the House of Molor"
▶ {Sutay' SoH molor tuq je:sen:nolink} "You are of the House of Molor"
This construction seems to be related to the proverb {reH tay' ghot tuqDaj je.:sen}[2]
See under {tuq:n} for an explanation of how to express membership in a House.

definition.en: You honor me, you all honor me.

notes.en:
This phrase is used when speaking to multiple people. When speaking to one person, say {choquvmoH.:sen}

If the people you're speaking to are your superiors, consider adding {-neS:v:suff}.
This is a device that can read the contents of a subject's brain, which is alluded to in {TOS - Errand of Mercy:src}.

definition.sv: klä av sig, ta av sig (kläder)

notes.en: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.
notes.de: Siehe {qawmoH:v} für Beispiele, wie man dieses Verb verwenden kann.

definition.sv: klä på sig, sätta på sig (kläder)

notes.en:
See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.

The slang expression {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}, literally "to take off one's belt", means "to not hear".[2]

examples.en:
▶ {tera' jar Soch, DIS wa' Hut jav Hut, maSDaq SaqmeH Qu' wa'DIch HochHom turlu'taHvIS, wej logh lengwI'pu' pa'mey 'oH Apollo wa'maH wa' ra'ghom bobcho' Columbia'e'.:sen:nolink} "The Apollo 11 Command Module, 'Columbia,' was the living quarters for the three-person crew during most of the first manned lunar landing mission in July 1969."[1]
▶ {Da'Irghlu'chugh, potlhqu' Huch Daghaqbogh, 'ej yInmey lutoDlu'meH Qu' 'ut wItur 'e' QaH noblIj.:sen:nolink} "If you were bullied, money that you contribute is very important, and your gift will help us carry out an essential mission so that lives are saved."[3]

tur:v.source: [1] {Smithsonian GO FLIGHT app:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}, [3] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

turmIq:n.hidden_notes: From Latin "micturation", maybe also a reference to the colour of tumeric.

notes.en:
Note that this refers to the geometric figure, and not to a glass object used for refracting light.

A prism with a three-sided base is a {ra'Duch tut:n@@ra'Duch:n, tut:n:2}, and so on. A cylinder is a {gho tut:n}.
If you spit out liquid, then {bItuy':sen:nolink}, but if you spit out solids, then {bItlhIS:sen:nolink}.

definition.sv: upptäcka, hitta, finna, observera, lägga märke till,

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/dhcRzrNc_P0}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/dhcRzrNc_P0}

examples.en: ▶ {HurDaq tu'HomI'raHvetlh yIlan!:sen:nolink} "Get that piece of junk out of here!"[2]

notes.en: This is an upper-class word for {Dargh HIvje':n}. It's an archaic word which used to mean only metal cup.

This is the verb {tu':v} with the suffix {-lu':v}, the combination of which is often translated as "there is" in English.[1] Note that the third-person singular prefix is used, even if the object is plural (when one might expect the prefix {lu-:v:pref}).[1; 3; 4]
This can also be used for a "theme", as applied to an app.[2]

examples.en: {ngutlh tu'qom:n}

notes.en: In {TNK:src}, {tlhagh patat 'oQqar naQHommey:n:nolink} was used to translated "fries" (as in "French fries").

examples.en: ▶ {tlham chach chu'qa'.:sen}

notes.en: When used with the suffix {-qa':v}, the result has the sense of "retrieve".

examples.en:
▶ {jagh Duj DaQaw' 'ach pagh qama' Datlhapqa'.:sen:nolink} "Destroy enemy vessel without retrieving prisoners."[2]
▶ {qeylIS 'etlh Datlhapqa' 'e' DaQapbe'.:sen:nolink} "Fail to retrieve the Sword of Kahless."[2]

tlhapragh:n.hidden_notes: The song "Monster Mash" was released on Garpax Records.
tlhapragh:n.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

notes.en: In {TNK:src}, this word was used for "clock".

examples.en: ▶ {tlhaqwIj chu'Ha'lu'pu'.:sen}

tlharghDuj:n.hidden_notes: This may have been named for the explorer William Clark (of the Lewis and Clark Expedition fame).

notes.en: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v:nolink}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.
This word can be used for the grid on a spreadsheet and also for the gridlines on a map.
This is food made from brown leaves, best served without sauce. See {'uSu':n}.
Compare to {moq:v} and {weq:v}.
This is generally made from {veDDIrmey:n:nolink}.
This refers to animals living in a house.[1]

tlha'a:n.hidden_notes: This actually appeared as {tlh'a':sen:nolink}, but this is a known typo.[1]

notes.en: The Eleventh Tome of Klavek is part of the {paq'batlh:n}, and tells the story of the descent of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} into {ghe'tor:n} to rescue his brother.[1]
The word "with" (in the sense of "accompanied by") is usually translated by a phrase using this verb.[2; 4] The use of this verb is not restricted to the notion of going somewhere with someone.[4]

tlhej:v.hidden_notes: In the E-K word list of {TKD:src}, this was erroneously tagged as a noun.

examples.en:
▶ {Dargh vItlhutlhDI' mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or
   {Dargh vItlhutlh. mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink}; or
   {Dargh vItlhutlh 'ej mutlhej torgh matlh je.:sen:nolink} "I drink tea with Torg and Maltz."[2]
▶ {bIQongtaHvIS nItlhejchugh targhmey bIvemDI' nItlhej ghIlab ghewmey.:sen}[3]
▶ {QotDI' gheD tlhejbe' wamwI'.:sen}[3]
▶ {'Iw HIq vItlhutlh. mutlhej ghaH.:sen:nolink} "He/she drinks bloodwine with me."[4]

notes.en: This is a type of plant. In the {paq'batlh:src}, it is mentioned that the {ngeng HeH:n} of the {qul ngeng:n} inside {QIStaq:n} has an environment so hostile to life that not even the {tlheng'IQ:n:nolink} would grow there.

tlheng'IQ:n.hidden_notes: According to the novel {Kahless:src}, this plant flowers only every eight years.

definition.sv: vara klimpig, vara full av klumpar, vara ojämn

tlher:v.hidden_notes: This is a reference to a character named "Clar"ence Rutherford, who is nicknamed "Lumpy", from the television show "Leave It to Beaver". See {warjun:n}.

definition.en: type of spear (thrown with aid of a special tool)
definition.de: Art Speer (wird mit einer besonderen Vorrichtung geworfen)
definition.sv: spjut kastat dem hjälp av ett särskilt verktyg

notes.en: To say "to smoke" (as in inhale nicotine), use {tlhIch pur:sen@@tlhIch:n, pur:v}.[2]
According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a predatory animal with sharp teeth that it bares before attacking.
This refers to the extraction of resources (see {jo:n}) such as minerals (see {tlhIl:n}), and not to the deployment of explosives (see {jorwI':n}).
This refers to a place where minerals ({tlhIl:n}) are extracted ({tlhIl:v}), and not to a proximity explosive.

tlhIlHal:n.hidden_notes: In the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this word was incorrectly used to refer to proximity explosives. (It was also misspelled as {tlhHl:sen:nolink}, perhaps deliberately in an attempt to make it look like a different word.)

notes.en:
The verb for laying a carpet is {vel:v}. The verb {mutlh:v}, when applied to a carpet, means to assemble it.

The word {tlhIm:n:nolink} is also used for a fabric wall hanging. A {tlhIm:n:nolink} has to cover something. A fabric displayed at the end of a pole would be a {joqwI':n}.

Finally, {tlhIm:n:nolink} can also be used for a blanket, though Klingons generally don't use blankets.

tlhIm:n.hidden_notes: A "gelim" is a type of Persian carpet.

tlhImqaH:n.hidden_notes: According to {A Good Day to Die:src}, this is made from something orange.

notes.en: This does not mean simply "single, separate" but rather something like "be attributable to something or someone" or "be uniquely associated with something or someone".

tlhIn:v.hidden_notes: The fact that {qangtlhIn:n} appears to contain this word is apparently a coincidence.

examples.en:
▶ {DujwIj tlhIn:n@@Duj:n:1, -wIj:n, tlhIn:v} "my particular ship, my own ship"
▶ {betleHlIj vIneHbe', betleHwIj tlhIn vIghaj:sen@@betleH:n, -lIj:n, vI-:v, neH:v, -be':v, betleH:n, -wIj:n, tlhIn:v, vI-:v, ghaj:v} "I don't want your bat'leth, I have my own bat'leth"

definition.en: klin zha, a popular board game

notes.en: This is a game of strategy which has been compared to chess.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan juHqo'Daq tlhIng yoSDaq 'oH toQDuj chenmoHlu'meH Daq wa'DIch'e':sen@@tlhIngan:n, juHqo':n, -Daq:n, tlhIng yoS:n, -Daq:n, 'oH:n, toQDuj:n, chenmoH:v, -lu':v, -meH:v, Daq:n, wa'DIch:n, -'e':n} "1st Construction Site: The Kling District, Klingon Home World"[2]

notes.en:
Note that this refers to a Klingon person or to the Klingon people, but not to the Klingon language (for which see {tlhIngan Hol:n}). In Klingon, unlike in Federation Standard, the name of a language is not simply the name of the people who speak it, but must be an identifier followed by the word {Hol:n}.

There is an idiom, {Hem; tlhIngan rur}.

tlhIngan:n.hidden_notes: The TKD entry says only "Klingon". The "(person)" annotation has been added to distinguish this entry from "Klingon (language)", and to make it consistent with the entry for "Vulcan (person)", etc.

examples.en:
▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}
▶ {bogh tlhInganpu', SuvwI'pu' moj, Hegh.:sen}

notes.en: This is short for {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}.[3]

tlhIngan Hol:n.hidden_notes: This term doesn't actually appear in the word lists in {TKD:src}, but is used in the list of useful expressions.

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/YtWZNvQl6mc}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/YtWZNvQl6mc}

notes.en:
Consider using a type 7 verb suffix such as {-taH:v:suff} or {-lI':v:suff}:
▶ {tlhIngan Hol vIghojtaH.:sen:nolink} "I'm learning Klingon (ongoing)."
▶ {tlhIngan Hol vIghojlI'.:sen:nolink} "I'm learning Klingon (proceeding towards a known goal)."
Please visit the KLI website at {www.kli.org:url:http://www.kli.org/} for more information.
The official {QI':n} of the Klingon Empire, run by the {ra'ghomquv:n}. It is subdivided into {yo':n} and {nawlogh:n}.

definition.en: Klingons kill for their own purposes.
definition.de: Klingonen töten für ihre eigenen Ziele.

definition.en: When you insult a Klingon's honor, prepare for trouble.
definition.de: Wenn du die Ehre eines Klingonen beleidigst, rechne mit Schwierigkeiten.

en: When you insult a Klingon's honour

notes.en: The language spoken in the Klingon Empire is called {tlhIngan wo' Hol:n:nolink}, or {tlhIngan Hol:n} for short.
If you spit out liquid, then {bItuy':sen:nolink}, but if you spit out solids, then {bItlhIS:sen:nolink}.
This is a name from {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}'s play {'antonI' tlhI'yopatra' je:sen:nolink}.

This verb is used to make a request, whereas {ghel:v} is used for asking a question.[3]

The object of this verb is the person of whom the request is made, or {'e':n:pro} referring to the action which is requested.

examples.en: ▶ {lutlhob; naDevvo' vaS'a'Daq majaHlaH'a'?:sen:nolink} "They ask him, can we get to the Great Hall from here?"[4]

definition.sv: motsäga, stå i strid med, bestrida

definition.en: be somewhat obscured, filtered, smudged, fuzzy

examples.en: ▶ {wa'Hu' jul tlhoDmoHmo' 'eng} "Because it was (sort of) cloudy yesterday", literally, "Because yesterday clouds somewhat obscured the sun"

notes.en:
This word was long considered quaint or archaic, but is heard with increasing frequency. Unlike {Saw:v} and {nay:v}, it can be used by either partner regardless of sex or gender.

One can say either {B tlhogh A:sen:nolink} for "{A:sen:nolink} marries {B:sen:nolink}" or {tlhoghchuq A B je:sen:nolink} "{A:sen:nolink} and {B:sen:nolink} marry each other".
The object of this verb is plural.
notes.de: Das Objekt dieses Verbes steht in der Mehrzahl.

notes.en: This refers to the visual phenomenon in the sky, not the technical moment of sunset.
This is made by coating a block of {tlhagh:n} with {ngat:n:2} and {tIr:n}, then {mIQ:n}.[1, p.93]
According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is much larger than a {targh:n}, more difficult to subdue, and is sometimes used as a riding beast.
For the front section of an object, see {'et:n:2h}. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

definition.sv: vara besk, vara skarp (om smak på mat)
nästan, så gott som, inte helt

definition.de: auf dem Wasser landen (wie ein Vogel)

notes.en: If a bird lands on a tree, the verb {ngun:v} is used, and if on land, then {Saq:v}.

tlhov:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

definition.en: overly, to an excessive degree, excessively, too much
definition.de: übermäßig, in zu hohem Maße, zu intensiv
definition.sv: alltför mycket, i överdriven grad, för mycket

definition.en: wall, interior wall, interior face of exterior wall, territorial wall
definition.sv: vägg, innervägg, insida av yttervägg, territorialmur

notes.en: Also refers to floors/ceilings, see {tlhoy' SaS:n}.

examples.en: {chevwI' tlhoy':n}, {pIn tlhoy':n}

notes.en: Note that while it's possible to say "Thank you" ({qatlho'}) in Klingon, this is something which Klingons would not normally say.

tlho':v.hidden_notes:
In {TNG - The Mind's Eye:src}, Captain Jean-Luc Picard ({janluq pIqarD:n:name}) said {qatlho':sen:nolink} to Kell after the latter paid him a compliment. Kell responded with an odd look.[2]

At {qep'a' loSDIch:src}, MO explained that he never intended {qatlho':sen:nolink} to mean "thanks" (in the way English speakers use that expression).

definition.en: unit of volume (approx. one quart/liter), klorn

tlho'ren:n.hidden_notes:
The newsgroup message says only that one {tlho'ren:n:nolink} "seems to be in the quart/liter range."[1]

The spelling of "klorn" comes from the script to {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}.[2]

definition.sv: tömma, förbruka, göra slut på, pumpa ut

tlhuch:v.hidden_notes:
It is unclear if this means "to tire someone out" (see {Doy':v}), "to use something up completely" (see {natlh:v:1}), or (as in English) both.

Some people believe that this word means "to expel exhaust", based on its similarity to {tlhuH:v:1}, and that {ghImwI':n} was a mistake for {tlhuchwI':n:nolink}. See the KLI Round Table in {HQ 11.2, p.10, Jun. 2002:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {chIch vay' 'oy'moHmeH 'oy'naQ 'ul law' tlhuD 'oH.:sen:nolink} "[Klingon painstiks] emit a highly-charged shock for the express purpose of inflicting pain."[2]

definition.en: be exhilarated, be stimulated, be invigorated
definition.sv: vara upprymd, vara stimulerad, vara upplivad

tlhup:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

tlhutlhmeH HIq ngeb qaq law' bIQ qaq puS.entry_name: tlhutlhmeH HIq ngeb qaq law' bIQ qaq puS.

definition.en: Drinking fake ale is better than drinking water.
definition.de: Es ist besser, gepanschtes Bier zu trinken als Wasser.

notes.en: This is a shortened form of {Qu'vatlh:excl}.
This is used to say that something is unexpected or surprising or counterintuitive, not just additional. For that, one would use {je:adv}.

examples.en: ▶ {Qo'noS romuluS je boSuqlaH. vabDot tera' Qejbogh DIvI' ram boSuqlaH.:sen:nolink} "Kronos, Romulus and even the puny Federation's precious Earth, are all up for grabs."[1]

notes.en: There is an expression, {vaDjaj yaDDu'lIj:sen:nolink} "may your toes be flexible", the meaning of which is unclear, but which might be a wish for good fortune.

definition.en: fifth tone of nonatonic musical scale
definition.sv: femte tonen på den nonatoniska skalan

notes.en: The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2,nolink}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

examples.en: {vagh reD mey' HoS:n@@vagh reD mey':n, HoS:v} "regular pentagon"[2]

notes.en: This can actually be used for anything that acts as a cover for something one puts inside of it.[3]

definition.en: so, then, thus, in that case
definition.sv: så, därför, således, i så fall

notes.en: Note that this is not a conjunction, but an adverbial.
This word refers to the concept of warriorhood (e.g., "warrior spirit", and so on). To refer to a person who is a warrior, use {SuvwI':n}.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}
▶ {vaj Duj chIj:sen:idiom}

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "warrior ship" or "warrior instincts", due to the homophony between {Duj:n:1} and {Duj:n:2}.

examples.en: ▶ {vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "to navigate a warrior ship".

examples.en: ▶ {vaj Duj DachIj.:sen:nolink} "You have strength of character."

vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen.entry_name: vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.

definition.en: Shooting space garbage is no test of a warrior's mettle.
definition.de: Weltraumschrott abzuschießen ist kein Test für den Mut eines Kriegers.

vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen.hidden_notes:
This is a backfit for the sentence, {vaj toDDujDaj ngeHbej DIvI'.@@vaj:adv, toDDuj:n, -Daj:n, ngeH:v, -bej:v, DIvI':n} "That means the Federation will be sending a rescue ship of its own." Both sentences were spoken by Captain Klaa in {Star Trek V:src}.

The original line was to have been {logh veQDaq bachchugh, yoH 'e' toblaHbe' SuvwI'.@@logh:n, veQ:n, -Daq:n, bach:v, -chugh:v, yoH:v, 'e':n, tob:v, -laH:v, -be':v, SuvwI':n}

definition.sv: vara klipsk, vara smart, vara intelligent

van:v:1.hidden_notes: The 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie has a deleted scene with the line: {tIjwI'ghom bovanrupbe'chugh, vaj reQaw'.:sen:nolink}

examples.en: ▶ {Hovmey Davan.:sen}

definition.en: end (an event, voyage, battle, play, opera, story, song, etc.)
definition.de: beenden (eine Reise, Kampf, Spiel, Oper, Lied usw.)
definition.sv: avsluta (en händelse, t.ex. resa, strid, sång)

notes.en: The subject of this verb is the person causing an event to end. The object is the event that is ended. If the event was prematurely brought to an end, use {ghang:v} instead. To describe the ending of a period of time, use {Dor:v:2} instead.
notes.de: Das Subjekt dieses Verbes ist die Person, die ein Ereignis beendet. Das Objekt ist das Ereignis, welches beendet wird. Falls das Ereignis vorzeitig beendet wird, benutzt man {ghang:v} stattdessen. Um das Enden eines Zeitabschnitts zu beschreiben, verwendet man {Dor:v:2}.

notes.en: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.
notes.de: Ein Planet im Gamma Quadranten.

examples.en:
▶ {Qoy qeylIS puqloD:sen:lyr}
▶ {taHjaj wo':sen:lyr}
▶ {bI'IQchugh yIvang!:sen}

vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj;.entry_name: vangDI' tlhIngan SuvwI' ngoy' qorDu'Daj; vangDI' qorDu'Daj ngoy' tlhIngan SuvwI'.

definition.en: The family of a Klingon warrior is responsible for his actions, and he is responsible for theirs.
definition.de: Die Familie eines Klingonen ist verantwortlich für dessen Taten, und er ist verantwortlich für die Taten der Familie.

examples.en: ▶ {bI'reS qeylIS vaq molor:sen:nolink} "First, Molor taunts Kahless"[2]

notes.en: This is a planet in the Klingon Empire in which native languages have survived alongside Klingon.

vaq'aj cha':n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src}, and in English, but the original Klingon name is obvious.

definition.en: be aggressive, be effective, be vigorous
definition.sv: vara aggressiv, vara effektiv, vara energisk, vara kraftfull

notes.en: This word was originally used in describing weapons, but is now also applied to people. It has strongly positive connotations in slang.[2]
This is the seat of the Klingon government.

examples.en:
▶ {juHqo'Daq vaS'a' tu'lu'. ngoch luchermeH 'ej wo' San luwuqmeH pa' ghom tlhIngan yejquv DevwI'pu'. DaH che' ghawran. yejquv DevwI' moj ghawran 'e' wuqta' cho' 'oDwI' Dapu'bogh janluq pIqarD HoD.:sen:nolink}
  "On the Homeworld, there is a great hall where the leaders of the Klingon High Council meet to determine policy and decide upon the fate of the Empire. Gowron currently presides, named leader of the High Council by Captain Jean-Luc Picard, who was acting as Arbiter of Succession."[2]
▶ {cha'maH vagh vatlhvI' Hong, QIt yIghoS.:sen}

notes.en: To indicate "centuries ago" or "centuries from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[3]

vatlh DIS poH:n.hidden_notes: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

notes.en: The siblings of a {vav:n} are {tennuS:n} and {'e'mam:n}.

vav:n.hidden_notes: The joke with {vav:n:nolink} and {SoS:n:nolink} is that in most human languages, the words for "father" and "mother" contain simple labial sounds (typically either "b" or "p" for father, and "m" for mother), whereas the fricatives {v:sen:nolink} and {S:sen:nolink} are difficult sounds for human infants to make.

notes.en: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v:nolink}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.
To express an indefinite subject, see {-lu':v:suff}.
This means "Learn from your experiences."
notes.de: Dies bedeutet "Lerne von deinen Erfahrungen."

definition.sv: vara nästa, vara efterföljande (i ordning, serie)

notes.en: To refer to the next day, month, or year, consider using {leS:n}, {waQ:n}, and {nem:n}, respectively.

veb:v.hidden_notes: While {nungbogh:v:nolink} precedes a noun, {veb:v:nolink} comes after one.

examples.en: {puq poH veb:n}

notes.en: The plural of this word is {veDDIrmey:n:nolink} rather than {veDDIrDu':n:nolink}.[1; 2]

definition.en: go through (an open door, a tunnel, etc.)
definition.sv: gå igenom (en öppen dörr, tunnel etc.)

notes.en: This verb only means to go through an opening of some sort, and not "to traverse" (in the sense of "going through" a forest).[1] The object is the thing being gone through. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

vegh:v.source: [1] {HQ 6.3, p.5-8, Sept. 1997:src}, [2] {HQ 7.4, Dec. 1998:src}, [3] {Klingon Monopoly:src}, [4] {paq'batlh:src}, [5] {KLI mailing list 2013.07.29:src}

examples.en: ▶ {veH Qav 'oH logh'e':sen}

notes.en:
The text of {SkyBox 99:src} reads:
▶ {loS... qIb HeHDaq, 'u' SepmeyDaq Sovbe'lu'bogh lenglu'meH He ghoSlu'bogh retlhDaq 'oHtaH. HaDlu'meH, QuSlu'meH, SuDlu'meH lojmIt Da logh Hop Hut tengchaH. vaj loghDaq lenglaHtaH Humanpu'. veH Qav 'oH logh'e'.:sen:nolink}

The subject does the covering, while the object is covered.

This verb is used to describe the laying of a carpet. The person who lays a carpet is called a {velwI':n:nolink} (despite the fact that the grammar suggests that {velwI':n:nolink} would refer to the carpet itself).

examples.en:
▶ {rav vel tlhIm.:sen:nolink} "The carpet covers the floor."
▶ {rav velmeH tlhIm lo'.:sen:nolink} "He lays the carpet on the floor."

notes.en: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, the "Chancellor's Cane Replica" is referred to as {Qang naQ velqa':n:nolink}.

velSo':n.hidden_notes: This appears to be a combination of {vel:v} and {So':v}. Chromium is often used to coat things.

definition.en: print, mark, tracks, trace, image, pattern

notes.en:
This refers to the trace or marks left behind by touch, such as (the image of) a fingerprint, tire tracks, or the pattern in the dirt that results from stepping on it.

This word is contrasted with {Su'nIm:n} which refers to the pattern that makes the {vem:n:nolink}. But {Su'nIm:n:nolink} is used only when it's something very detailed which leaves the {vem:n:nolink}. For example, compare {nItlh Su'nIm:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n} "fingerprint" (ridges on fingertip) with {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} "fingerprint" (mark left behind after touching).

Note that an intentionally produced, stamp-like image is a {yang:n}.

In the following examples, the specific finger or toe name can be used instead of {nItlh:n} (or {yaD:n:1}).

examples.en:
▶ {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} fingerprint (mark left behind after touching)
▶ {bem Su'nIm vem:n@@bem:n, Su'nIm:n, vem:n} footprint (specific pattern of bottom of shoe)
▶ {bem vem:n@@bem:n, vem:n} footprint (basic outline of a foot left in dirt)
▶ {namwech vem:n@@namwech:n, vem:n} paw print (pattern left in dirt)

notes.en: This is a bird that feeds almost exclusively on the serpent worm from which {qagh:n} is made. Klingons are not particularly fond of this bird.

vem'eq:n.hidden_notes: An early bird catches the worm.

notes.en: This word describes someone who is really into something (or a number of things), who partakes in activities associated with it, and does so very seriously.

ven:v.hidden_notes: "Fan", or possibly a reference to a Venn diagram where "nerd" is at the intersection of "intelligence", "obsession", and "social ineptitude".

notes.en:
This word describes someone who is really into something (or a number of things), who partakes in activities associated with it, and does so very seriously.

A more common term for this is {qatru':n:nolink}.

definition.zh_HK: 第一城(克洛诺斯的首都)

veng wa'DIch:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

veng wa'DIch Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

definition.en: proclamation, notification, announcement, and the like

notes.en: There is an idiom, {qej; veqlargh rur}.

examples.en: ▶ {SuD veqlargh mInDu'.:sen}

definition.en: You pay attention to your Fek'lhr and I will pay attention to mine.
definition.de: Du passt auf deinen Fek'lhr auf und ich achte auf meinen.

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/PBM4fiXLc-U}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/PBM4fiXLc-U}

examples.en: ▶ {veQDuj 'oH DujlIj'e'.:sen}

definition.en: Your ship is a garbage scow.

notes.en: This word can be used to talk about the wind ({SuS:n}). For example, {ver SuS'a':sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n, -'a':n} means "a tornado happens". {ver SuS:sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n} or {ver SuSHom:sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n, -Hom:n} would most likely refer to a whirlwind.
notes.de: Mit diesem Wort kann man den Wind ({SuS:n}) beschreiben. Zum Beispiel {ver SuS'a':sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n, -'a':n} bedeutet "es findet ein Tornado statt". {ver SuS:sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n} oder {ver SuSHom:sen@@ver:v:1, SuS:n, -Hom:n} würde wahrscheinlich einen Wirbelwind beschreiben.

notes.en: Ferengis are known for their greed, as reflected in the comparison {qur; verengan rur}.

examples.en: ▶ {Huch nobHa'bogh verenganpu''e' yIvoqQo'.:sen}

notes.en: This is the name of the Ferengi Homeworld, the primary planet in the Ferengi Alliance.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/8MLXFbHYZOk}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/8MLXFbHYZOk}

notes.en:
The object is the vehicle that is docked.[3]

In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, "Free Parking" is translated as {vergh 'ach DIlnISbe':sen:nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {nuqDaq puH Duj vIvergh?:sen:nolink} "Where can I park the car?"[3]

notes.en: Contrast this with {noH:n}, which refers to a specific war.[1, p.47]

examples.en: ▶ {notlh veS, 'a tugh manotlhchoH je maH.:sen}

notes.en: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n:nolink}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.

veStay:n.hidden_notes: This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

definition.en: insert, put in, pin (attach or fasten with a pin)

vev:v.hidden_notes: This was defined as "insert, put in" in 2015, and expanded to include "pin, attach or fasten with a pin" in 2016.

examples.en:
▶ {veymey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink} "Limited Edition"
▶ {boSwI'vaD veyvam le' chenmoHlu':sen:nolink} "Collector's Edition"
▶ {wa' tlhIngan QaS vey:n:nolink} "one pack of Klingon forces"

notes.en: This is similar to {yap:v}, but {vey':v:nolink} implies being more than enough/sufficient.
notes.de: Dies ist ähnlich wie {yap:v}, aber {vey':v:nolink} bedeutet mehr als nur genug.

notes.en: This means more than not being enough or being insufficient (see {yap:v}).
notes.de: Dies ist noch weniger als zu wenig oder unzureichend (siehe {yap:v}).

definition.en: travel with a purpose, for a specific reason; travel on a mission
definition.de: mit einer Absicht bzw. Mission reisen

ve':v.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {DevwI' ghaH 'Iv'e'?@@DevwI':n, ghaH:n, 'Iv:ques:1h, -'e':n:suff}.

examples.en: ▶ {jIvuylaH. jIve'.} "I am here to help you."

notes.en:
{jIH:n:1h}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {vI-:v:pref,nolink}

When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to me".

definition.en: move through time toward the future
definition.de: durch die Zeit in die Zukunft reisen

examples.en:
▶ {wa'vatlh DIS vIvIb:sen:nolink} "I time-travel 100 years into the future."
▶ {jIvIb. qaSDI' vatlh DIS poH cha'maH Hut, jImev.:sen:nolink} "I time-travel to the 29th century."

vIb:v:2.hidden_notes: This was defined parenthetically in the definition of {vIb:v:1,nolink}. The note that this is not used in reference to plants implies that this means "to be transmitted, as through a medium", and not "to breed".

definition.en: move through time toward the past
definition.de: durch die Zeit in die Vergangenheit reisen

examples.en:
▶ {jIvIbHa'pu' 'ej qeylIS vIqIHpu'.:sen:nolink} "I time-traveled into the past and I met Kahless."
▶ {jIvIbHa'. wejHu' jImev.:sen:nolink} "I time-travel three days into the past."

definition.sv: vara stridslysten, vara stridande, vara krigförande

notes.en: This is a device that regulates the flow of gas, sound, etc.

definition.en: type of animal, v'gro (like a cat)

vIghro':n.hidden_notes: "Figaro" is the name of the cat in Disney's Pinocchio. This word isn't named directly for that, but via an actual cat named "Figaro".

notes.en:
This verb is intransitive. To say that someone or something moves someone or something else, use {vIHmoH:v:nolink}.[2]

For an idiomatic expression used to tell someone not to move, see {taD:v}.
This idiomatic expression means that an activity of finite (though perhaps indeterminate) length has started.

examples.en: ▶ {bISop DaneH'a'? vIHtaH gho.:sen:nolink} "If you want to eat, say so now before the food is gone."

definition.en: someone or something who is just there; someone who is around when you are
definition.de: jemand oder etwas das immer da ist

vIl:n.hidden_notes: When this word was defined at {qep'a' 2009:src}, a description of an object which was recognised as a "speed bump" was given as an example of a {vIl:n:nolink}.

notes.en: The suggestion was made at {qep'a' 2009:src} that a {vIlHom:n:nolink} could be a single ridge in a {Quch:n}.

definition.sv: en slags fågel (förmögen att härma språk)

notes.en: This is a bird capable of mimicking speech. Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

vIlInHoD:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Captain Flint, Long John Silver's parrot in "Treasure Island".

definition.sv: {lor:n:0} eller {tey':n:0}; kusin, brorsdotter, systerdotter, brorson, systerson

notes.en: In the singular, typically {tey':n:nolink} or {lor:n:nolink} is preferred unless the individual is being referred to as a member of a group that likely includes both {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}. The plural form {vInpu':n:nolink} is used for a group that includes {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}.

vIn:n.hidden_notes: A reference to the movie "My Cousin Vinny".

definition.en: compatriot, community member, cohort, fellow citizen
definition.de: Landsmann, Mitbürger, Mitglied der Mannschaft oder der Truppe

vInDa':n.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.

examples.en: ▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people."

notes.en: This word refers to the abstract concept of combat. A specific battle is a {may':n}.

This term is more general than a visual piece of art. It covers that, but also an artifact (not in the archeological sense), handicraft, gizmo, gadget, contraption, machine, device, etc. That is, it refers to something manufactured or made.

vItHay':n.hidden_notes: It's not specified whether this is a noun or a verb, but it's likely to be a noun, even though {Hay':n:nolink,hyp} is not known to exist as a noun.

definition.en: be high, great (in quantity, size, intensity)

notes.en: This is used for things that are measurable or quantifiable, but not necessarily countable. For countable things, {law':v} would normally be used, but {vItlh:v:nolink} would be used if the number is higher than normal or greater than before or greater than what was expected.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {DoDaj vItlh law' wab Do vItlh puS.:sen:nolink} "faster than the speed of sound"[1]
▶ {Do vItlh:n:nolink} "high velocity"[3]
▶ {chuq vItlh:n:nolink} "great range, great distance"[3]

notes.en: This is any liquid from a plant. In some regional dialects, this word is used for any liquid accompanying food.

vIychorgh:n.hidden_notes: "V8" is a juice blend made from tomato juice mixed with the juices of various vegetables.

notes.en: Earwax (see {Serrum:n}) is said to do this in the ear.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}
▶ {cha' vI' vagh choQmey lutoghlu':sen:nolink} "Number of Decks: 2.5" {BoP:src}

vI'laS:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Phileas Fogg, the protagonist of the Jules Verne novel "Around the World in Eighty Days".

notes.en: This refers to meat prepared by {HaH:v:2}. The word for the specific meat replaces the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.
When used as a locative, this word is not followed by the locative suffix {-Daq:n:suff}.[3]

examples.en:
▶ {vogh vISuch vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit some place."[2]
▶ {vogh tIghla' tu'lu':sen:nolink} "there's a t'gla somewhere"[3]

notes.en: This word can be the object of {wel:v}.

examples.en: ▶ {voHDajbo' qav'ap:n}

notes.en: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1h} the player receives for mortgaging a planet to the bank.

definition.sv: snara, snärja, fånga (i fälla), förleda, lura

von:v.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Captain "von Trapp" from The Sound of Music, who was played by Christopher Plummer, who of course was also General Chang ({cheng:n:name}).

notes.en: This slang term is not used in reference to games, but is applied only to more serious matters.[1, p.165]

vonlu':v.hidden_notes: Note that in the example, the prefix {bI-:v} is used rather than {Da-:v}. This might indicate that the apparent {-lu':v} suffix is a fossilized form and isn't truly the suffix.

examples.en: ▶ {bIvonlu'pu'.:sen:nolink} "You have failed completely."[1, p.165]

definition.sv: lita på, tro på, ha tillit till

examples.en:
▶ {Duj tIvoqtaH.:sen}
▶ {DujlIj yIvoq.:sen}

notes.en: Voq was an outcast who referred to himself as "son of none" ({pagh puqloD:n@@pagh:n:1, puqloD:n}). He is a follower of {tIquvma:n:name}, and was given the role of {Sech qengwI':n} after the death of {rej'aq:n:name}. He is an albino, whose skin colour was described as {Dem:v}.

definition.sv: kväva, kvävas, strypa, strypas, få något i halsen

notes.en: This word appears to consist of the verb {voQ:v} (or a homophonous but unknown noun) and {SIp:n}, so it means something like "choking gas".

examples.en: ▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

notes.en: It is unclear why Federation Standard corrupted the spelling of this word by moving the {qaghwI':n}.
One can also use {nungbogh:v@@nung:v, -bogh:v}.

voSpegh Sep:n.hidden_notes: This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

examples.en: ▶ {QIStaq qul bIQtIqHomDaq 'etlhDaj vo' nuch:sen:nolink} "The coward throws his sword into the fire streams of Kri'stak"[2]

definition.en: Cowards take hostages. Klingons do not.

notes.en: This verb can be used with {turmIq:n}, {qeQ:n}, and {taQbang:n:2}.

examples.en: ▶ {vulchoHbe' tlhInganpu'.:sen}

notes.en: A planet in the Federation.

Vulcans are also sometimes called Vulcanians in English.[2]

Note that this is {vulqangan:n:nolink} and not {vulqanngan:n:nolink} (the {n:sen:nolink} at the end of {vulqan:n:nolink} is dropped).

There is a Klingon idiom, {nong; vulqangan rur}, which is meant ironically.

definition.en: contemptible or despicable person, scumbag, bastard
definition.de: verächtliche oder verabscheuungswürdige Person, Drecksack, Bastard

vum:n.hidden_notes: The first part of the example sentence was a lip-match for {mughojmoH parmaqqaywI'}. The second part was a lip-match for a sentence beginning with {naDevvo'}.

examples.en: ▶ {potlhmo' batlh, vIqawba', 'ej chIvo' neH chIw vum'e'.@@potlh:v, -mo':v, batlh:n, vI-:v, qaw:v, -ba':v, 'ej:conj, chIvo':n, neH:adv, chIw:v, vum:n, -'e':n} "Because you care about honor. And this man has none."

definition.en: order (in a restaurant, from a catalog, etc.)

notes.en: Note that this is a verb in Klingon. In Klingon, one says "it hurricanes", similar to how one says "it rains" in English.

definition.sv: tycka synd om, ha medlidande med, beklaga

examples.en: ▶ {Hoch jaghpu'Daj HoHbogh SuvwI' yIvup.:sen}

definition.en: cook, prepare food, make a beverage

vut:v.hidden_notes: The definition in {TKD:src} is just "cook". On {KGT p.83:src}, this is expanded to include the preparation of any food, including beverages. Reverse of {tuv:v}.

notes.en: This is sometimes shortened to {vut'un:n}.
This refers to a place where food is prepared.
This is short for {vutmeH 'un:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {qoH vuvbe' SuS.:sen}

vuy:v.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {DevwI' ghaH 'Iv'e'?@@DevwI':n, ghaH:n, 'Iv:ques:1h, -'e':n:suff}.

examples.en: ▶ {jIvuylaH. jIve'.} "I am here to help you."

definition.sv: sköta, handha, ordna, få bukt med

examples.en: ▶ {Qu' vu'wI' yaH:n}

notes.en: See under {QIch wab Ho'DoS:n} for the names of the Klingon consonants and vowels.

examples.en: ▶ {wab qoSta' 'aplo':n}

notes.en: This refers to a device that receives (but does not send) an audio signal. For the device used for two-way communication, see {Se' HablI':n}.

This is used for a broadcaster, radio service, etc. It can also be used for the device that does the transmitting. If a distinction must be made, the device is {wab labwI' jan:n@@wab labwI':n, jan:n:1}.
notes.de: Dies kann gleichzeitig der Radiosender an sich sein, oder auch das sendende Gerät. Um zu unterscheiden, ist das Gerät {wab labwI' jan:n@@wab labwI':n, jan:n:1}.

notes.en: As a spelling convention, {wab Do:n:nolink} "speed of sound" is written as two words. When used as a measurement term ("Mach"), it is written as one word ({wabDo:n:nolink}). The pronunciation (and, for that matter, the meaning) is the same.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {wabDo loS:sen:nolink} "Mach 4"

notes.en: This is a more general meaning of {waH:v:2}.

This is a specialized meaning of {waH:v:1}. It means to try out food to see if it's been properly prepared or to determine if one likes it.[2]

Do not confuse this with {mum:v}, which means "taste" in the sense of perceiving flavors.

definition.en: vibrate, be in a state of vibration

notes.en: This means to move in a fast repetitive way, like a guitar string.
notes.de: Dies bedeutet sich sehr schnell hin und her bewegen, wie eine Gitarrensaite

notes.en: This is meat prepared with {ngat:n:2}. The word for the specific meat replaces the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.

wan:v.hidden_notes: This sounds like the Chinese word for "crooked" (彎).

wanHa':v.hidden_notes: There is an Indo-European root "wanha" with exactly this meaning.

notes.en: To express natural phenomena, the name for the effect is followed by the word {wanI':n:nolink}.[2]

wanI':n.hidden_notes: This word was defined in {TKD:src} as "phenomenon, event, occurrence". The definition "effect" was added in the booklet for the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.

examples.en: ▶ {matlh wanI':n:nolink} "the Maltz effect"[2]

waq:n.hidden_notes: You can certainly "wack" someone with it, or "walk" in it.

definition.sv: en slags fågel (med en väldigt lång näbb)

notes.en: This is a bird with a very long beak.

waqboch:n.hidden_notes: Kiwi is a brand of shoe polish ({waq:n} "shoe", {boch:v} "be shiny"), and also a kind of bird with a very long beak.

war:n.hidden_notes: From the term "warp and weft" in weaving. See also {wev:n}.

definition.en: type of knife (used for food preparation)

notes.en: This is large, sharp, and square-bladed, almost like an {'obmaQ:n}.

warjun:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Ward and June Cleaver, from the television show "Leave It to Beaver". See {tlher:v}.

notes.en: Note that this means "be amiss, awry" (something has gone wrong or didn't turn out according to plan), as opposed to {muj:v} "be incorrect, factually wrong".
For the mathematical operation of division, see {boqHa''egh:v}.

way:v.hidden_notes: "The White Stripes" was an American rock band.

definition.en: We succeed together in a greater whole.
definition.de: Wir haben Erfolg als Teile eines großen Ganzen.
Konzentriere dich auf ein einziges Ziel.

notes.en: This literally means "we hit one target". It can be shortened to just {DoS wIqIp.:sen:nolink}

wa' jaj 'etlh 'uchchoHlaH tlhIngan puqlo.entry_name: wa' jaj 'etlh 'uchchoHlaH tlhIngan puqloD; jajvetlh loD nen moj.

definition.en: The son of a Klingon is a man the day he can first hold a blade.
definition.de: Der Sohn eines Klingonen ist ein Mann sobald er ein Schwert halten kann.

definition.en: For one mission, there is one leader.
definition.de: Für eine Mission gibt es einen Führer.

wa' SuvwI' muHlu'DI', tuHchoH Hoch SuvwI.entry_name: wa' SuvwI' muHlu'DI', tuHchoH Hoch SuvwI'pu'.

definition.en: The execution of but one warrior brings shame to all.
definition.de: Die Hinrichtung eines einzigen Kriegers bringt Schande über alle.

notes.en: Maltz said that if, in school, a student responded to a teacher's question by saying this, the student was likely to be disciplined (unless that was actually the correct answer). He didn't elaborate further.[1]

definition.en: Kill one of them. I don't care which.

notes.en: In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Quj wa'DIch:n:nolink} is used to refer to the original Monopoly game. So {wa'DIch:n:nolink} can be used for "original" in the sense of "the first" (see under {qa':v} for the sentence).

examples.en:
▶ {veng wa'DIch:n}
