▶ {yaS wa'DIch:n}

wa'maH cha' pemmey wa'maH cha' rammey je.entry_name: wa'maH cha' pemmey wa'maH cha' rammey je

notes.en: This idiomatic expression refers to an event in the life of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}, when he fought his brother {moratlh:n:name} for twelve days and twelve nights (as recounted in the {paq'batlh:src}). The expression means not only that the length of the event is long, but also that the event is an important one, worthy of taking up so much time.

Klingons consider the number 13 to be special because of the way they used to count. The decimal number 12 used to be expressed as 3 x 3 + 3, and then the system became complicated. This association remained even after Klingons switched over to the decimal number system.

examples.en: ▶ {qatlh Suvbe' chaH? wa'maH wej.:sen:nolink} "Why aren't they fighting? It's complicated."[1]

notes.en: According to {The Klingon Art of War:src}, this is the name of the first Klingon god.[1]

definition.sv: vara i onåd, vara oönskad, vara utstött

definition.en: serve fermented food at its peak
definition.de: vergorene/vergärte Lebensmittel zum richtigen Zeitpunkt servieren
definition.sv: servera jäst mat när den är som bäst

notes.en: This is food mixed with {'atlhqam:n}, fermented, and served.[1, p.92]
This word is like {yot:v}, but with the connotation of surprise or speed.[2]

definition.en: A warrior fights to the death.
definition.de: Ein Krieger kämpft bis zum Tod.

definition.sv: charmerande, just snyggt, vackert (används endast ironiskt)

notes.en: Either the thing owed, or the person to whom something is owed, can be the object.

wel:v.hidden_notes: In English slang, to "welch" is to fail to pay a debt or to fulfill an obligation.

examples.en:
▶ {qawel:sen:nolink} "I owe you"[1; 3]
▶ {voHDajbo' wellu' 100:sen:nolink} "mortgaged for 100"[2]
▶ {yervamvaD voHDajbo' wellu'chugh, 'echletHom Dopvam yIcha'.:sen:nolink}
  "Card must be turned this side up if property is mortgaged."[2]

notes.en: The stereotypical {targh:n:nolink} makes a sound conventionally rendered {welwelwel:sen:nolink} (where the number of repetitions is variable).
notes.de: Der typische {targh:n:nolink} macht ein Geräusch, das man meist als {welwelwel:sen:nolink} nachmacht (Die Häufigkeit der Silbe ist variabel).

definition.sv: kränka, bryta emot, överträda, störa, skända

notes.en: This word has this meaning in the {voSpegh Sep:n} dialect.
Compare to {moq:v} and {tlhaw':v}.
This is the closest thing Klingons have to the "World Wide Web".

definition.en: lose, undergo a reduction of, suffer a reduction of

notes.en: To say that someone has died, just use {Hegh:v}. Using {weS:v:nolink} implies that someone is lost, i.e., gone or missing, or severely injured and not expected to return (or to return anytime soon), but not necessarily dead.

wev:n.hidden_notes: From the term "warp and weft" in weaving. See also {war:n}.

notes.en: This is a ship's full complement of personnel, crew plus officers.

examples.en: ▶ {wey jolpat - wa' (jav ghotpu'):sen:nolink} "Personnel Transporter - 1 (6 Man)"

notes.en:
{maH:n:1h}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n} = {wI-:v:pref,nolink}

When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to us".

definition.en: be sour, be bitter, be tart
definition.sv: vara sur, vara bitter, vara besk, vara syrlig

examples.en: ▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[3]

▶ {qaStaHvIS wa'maH puq poHmey, wo'rIv betleH ghaj qorDu'Daj. nuja' tlhIngan wIch ja'wI'pu' yIntaHvIS qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay' batlh 'etlhvam chenmoHlu'pu'.:sen:nolink}
  "Worf's bat'telh has been in his family for ten generations. According to Klingon legend, this sword of honor descends from the time of Kahless the Unforgettable."[2]

notes.en: This word connotes indiscriminate killing.

wID:v.hidden_notes: The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.

examples.en: ▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.} "He has killed many of our people."

notes.en: There is an idiom, {wIH; Hur'Iqngan rur}.
This is an expression used between close friends in the higher social classes. It should be avoided if possible, unless one's social standing is absolutely clear.

wIj jup:sen.hidden_notes: The real reason {wIj jup:sen:nolink} has this meaning is because some Star Trek writer looked up "my" and "friend" in {TKD:src}, found {-wIj:n} and {jup:n}, and attached them to each other without any regard for grammar or correctness. In standard Klingon, "my friend" (assuming said friend is a being capable of language) is {jupwI':n:nolink} (from {jup:n} and {-wI':n}).

notes.en: This refers to a stand-alone spike such as a stake.

wIl:n.hidden_notes: On the TV show "Buffy the Vampire Slayer", there is a character nicknamed Spike whose real name is William.

wIlpuq:n.hidden_notes: This is a double pun: it sounds like "will puke", and also refers to "Pudd'nhead Wilson" ({puqloD:n} means "son"), the name of the eponymous character of a Mark Twain novel.

notes.en: This is the name of a famous Klingon playwright.
According to {KGT p.99:src}, this verb may be used to describe the action of breaking off a portion of food to transfer from a serving platter ({'elpI':n}) to one's plate ({jengva':n}).
This verb is also used for clicking on a hyperlink on a computer.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {bISuv 'e' yIwIv; bISutlh 'e' yIwIvQo'.:sen}

notes.en: This refers to an abstract schematic of a battlefield, which is displayed on a {jIH:n:2}. Contrast this with {HaSta:n}.

wIy:n.hidden_notes: The first ever line of Klingon spoken on-screen was {wIy cha':sen@@wIy:n, cha':v}, in {Star Trek I:src}.

notes.en:
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/ooFuTPjRtEM}

The clipped Klingon form of this command would be {wIy cha'!:sen@@wIy:n, cha':v}

wIy yIcha'!:sen.hidden_notes: The first ever line of Klingon spoken on-screen was {wIy cha':sen:nolink}, in {Star Trek I:src}.

notes.en: This is not a Klingon word, but the Klingon pronunciation of a Federation Standard word, referring to a collaboratively edited website or database.

definition.en: hurl a spear by means of a {chetvI':n:2}

examples.en: ▶ {cha' 'ujmo' jIH woch law' SoH woch puS:sen:nolink} "I'm two {'uj:sen:nolink}es taller than you."[2]

notes.en: It is regrettable when this is applied to food.[2]

definition.en: transgress, do more than is acceptable
definition.sv: överträda, göra mer än vad som är acceptabelt, gå för långt

notes.en: {bIwogh:sen:nolink} might be translated "You go too far."

definition.sv: ta upp, plocka upp, lyfta upp

examples.en:
▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink}
  "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

woj:v.hidden_notes: The noun {woj:n} and the verb {Say'qu'moH:v} appeared next to each other in a word list published in {veS QonoS:src} (reprinted in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src} in Sept. 1992). Will Martin made an error in transcribing the words, and MO subsequently canonised his error, as a joke.

notes.en: This word is used for both eating and attacking by pecking.
Note that {'ol:v} is used for checking a fact, while {woq:v:nolink} is used for confirming it.

woq:v.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Magic to Make the Sanest Man Go Mad:src}

examples.en: ▶ {bIQong'eghqangchoHmoHlaHchu'pu'neSchugh:v}

notes.en: There is an idiom, {wov; ghI'boj Sech rur}.
Watch the Hallmark commercial in which this word appears: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/9eM1OSNGLwI}

wovmoHbogh jan:n.hidden_notes: This word has appeared in canon only in the formation {wovmoHbogh janHommey:n:nolink}[1; 2], but the noun suffixes have been removed here for ease of reference.

examples.en: ▶ {Qapqu' wovmoHbogh janHommey!:sen:nolink} "It even has working lights!"[1]

notes.en: This refers to specific memories or recollections, and is different from "memory" in the sense of the ability to remember or the power of recall, for which see {qaw:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {wov'on qaw:sen@@wov'on:n, qaw:v} "he/she remembers a memory", "he/she has a memory"

notes.en: {wo' tay':n:nolink} is an older name than {tuqjIjQa':n}. The Klingons who gave the country this name might have been thinking of the British Empire.[2]

wo' tay':n.source: [1] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2011.10.29:src}

wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhInga.entry_name: wo' toy'taHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.

definition.en: To die while serving the Empire is the hope of every Klingon.
definition.de: Im Dienste des Imperiums zu sterben ist die Hoffnung jedes Klingonen.

notes.en: The son of Mogh ({mogh:n:name}), and the first Klingon officer to serve in Starfleet. He is portrayed by the actor {mayqel Do'rIn:n:name}.
Breathe more noisily than {jev:v:2}.

wuD:v.hidden_notes: An idiomatic way of saying "snore" in English is "saw wood".

definition.sv: vara oskyddad, vara sårbar, vara utsatt

examples.en:
▶ {Dumer DIvI' QaS 'ej DuHIv, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIrIQchoH.:sen:nolink} "Surprise attack by Federation leaves you unprotected and damaged."[1]
▶ {DuHIv jagh Dangu'laHbe'bogh, vaj bIwunchoH 'ej bIpujchoH.:sen:nolink} "Attack by unknown enemy leaves you vulnerable and weak."[1]

wuqHa':v.hidden_notes: This means to undo a decision. Its only known use in canon is in the example.

examples.en: ▶ {vImuHlu' net wuqHa'!:sen}[1]

definition.sv: ha huvudvärk, ha ont i huvudet

examples.en: ▶ {jIwuQ.:sen}

definition.sv: förlita sig på, vara beroende av, vara hänvisad till

notes.en: This word refers both to the brain and to "mind, intellect". For the organ, see {QoghIj:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {targhlIj yab tIn law' no'lI' Hoch yabDu' tIn puS!:sen}

notes.en: This word does not appear in canon by itself, but can be inferred from {jIb yachwI':n}.

Klingon has five verbs corresponding to each of the {yaD:n:1,nolink}: {mar:v}, {Hom:v}, {roS:v:2}, {nan:v:2}, and {Qay':v:2}.

Correspondingly, the five toes are {marwI':n}, {HomwI':n}, {roSwI':n}, {nanwI':n:2}, and {Qay'wI':n}.

The toe verbs are used in the same way as the finger verbs, but they are not heard often outside of discussions about martial arts movements or dance, and are normally considered archaic.

yaD:n:1.hidden_notes: The verbs for the toes come from the nursery rhyme "This Little Piggy".

notes.en: This slang word originated from the similarity of {yan:n} and {yaD:n:1} in the {Qotmagh Sep:n} dialect.
A planet in the Gamma Quadrant, a part of the Dominion.

yaDpach:n.hidden_notes: This word does not seem to have appeared in canon, but it is obvious by analogy with {nItlhpach:n:1}.

notes.en: This refers to any place where one does work, and isn't limited to military usage.
This is in clipped Klingon. In standard Klingon, "Do you understand?" (speaking to one person) would be {bIyaj'a'?:sen:nolink}
This might be said in response to {yaj'a'?:sen}
This refers to a line such as on lined paper, or painted on the road.
notes.de: Dies beschreibt eine Linie auf liniertem Papier, oder einen Strich auf einer Fahrbahn.

yamtaw:n.hidden_notes: "What's My Line" ({watmay:sen:nolink}) was a TV show.

notes.en: This is a weapon with long blades.
The members of the {yan 'ISletlh:n:nolink} are the Chancellor's personal bodyguards.

examples.en: ▶ {Qang QanmeH yan 'ISletlh Damuv 'e' wIvlu'.:sen:nolink} "You are chosen to serve on the Yan-Isleth and protect the Chancellor."[1]

notes.en: According to {KGT p.79:src}, {raQ:v} can be used as a substitute for {yan:v:nolink} in the context of swords.

yanwI':n.hidden_notes: This is defined in the body of {KGT:src} on p.61.

yang:n.hidden_notes: The Chinese word for stamp (印) is "yìn". Negative images are like "yīn" and "yáng" (陰陽).

examples.en: ▶ {Suvlu'taHvIS yapbe' HoS neH.:sen}

notes.en:
There are nine ranks of officers:
▶ {'aj:n} "admiral"
▶ {Sa':n} "general"
▶ {totlh:n} "commodore"
▶ {'ech:n} "brigadier"
▶ {HoD:n} "captain"
▶ {la':n} "commander"
▶ {Sogh:n} "lieutenant"
▶ {lagh:n} "ensign"
▶ {ne':n} "yeoman"

Someone of rank {Sogh:n} or higher can also be referred to as {ra'wI':n}.
can be used as title
can be used as title
This is a gray (sometimes white) bird that can travel particularly long distances without pausing.
A pregnant woman is said to {qeng:v} a {puq:n}.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {yay chavlu' 'e' bajnISlu'.:sen} "Victory must be earned."[2, p.125]
▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2, p.211]
▶ {qIbDaq Hoch Hovtay'mey bocharghchugh, yay bochav.:sen:nolink}[3]

definition.sv: vara chockad, vara mållös, vara förstummad

definition.en: wrist (also a slang term of deprecation)

notes.en: This is an organization dedicated to scholastic pursuits or research. The distinction between {yejHaD:n:nolink} and {yej'an:n} is not clear, but {yejHaD:n:nolink} is usually used for larger organizations.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}

notes.en:
This is an organization dedicated to scholastic pursuits or research. The distinction between {yej'an:n:nolink} and {yejHaD:n} is not clear, but {yejHaD:n:nolink} is usually used for larger organizations.[1]

Do not confuse this with a society in the cultural sense, for which see {nugh:n}.[1]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan yej'an:n:nolink} would be "a group dedicated to the study of Klingons"[1]
▶ {bIyem'a'?:sen}

notes.en: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, {ghIH:v:2} means {yepHa':v:nolink}.
The subject is the cooperating parties.

yeq:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.

notes.en: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote a game square, including those corresponding to the four ship classes.

examples.en: ▶ {nom yer mechmeH Quj} "The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game"[2]

notes.en: Note that Klingons consider title deeds to be a type of {chaw':n}, rather than a type of {Qoyje':n}.[2]

yergho:n.hidden_notes: A reference to the walls of "Jericho".

notes.en:
{SoH:n}:{pagh:n:1h} = {yI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
{SoH:n}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n} = {yI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
{tlhIH:n}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n} = {yI-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)

If the command is given to multiple people and the object is none, be careful to use {pe-:v} instead.

Generally, when a verb describing a state of being is used as an imperative, the suffixes {-'egh:v} and {-moH:v} are used with it.[2]
There is an idiom, {'up; yIH rur}.
This can also mean "Put her on screen" or "Put it on screen". A shorter way of putting it in English is just "On screen". However, "Put them on screen" would be {tIHotlh.:sen:nolink}

yIje'!:sen.hidden_notes: The English translation given on {TKD p.170:src} is "Feed him!", but this also means "Feed her!" or "Feed it!"

examples.en: ▶ {yIn nI' yISIQ 'ej yIchep!:sen} "Live long and prosper!"

notes.en:
This word can be used transitively to say things like {tlhIngan yIn DayIn:sen:nolink} "You live a Klingon life."[2]

To say that someone "lives at" a place, use {Dab:v}.

yIn:v.hidden_notes: The Klingon sentence {tlhIngan yIn DayIn:sen:nolink} was written by MO in someone's {KGT:src} when he autographed it. It does not actually appear in the {HQ 7.4:src} article, but it is alluded to there by its English translation.

definition.de: Um das Leben zu verstehen, ertrage den Schmerz.

notes.en: This is a common Vulcan saying.

yIn nI' yISIQ 'ej yIchep!:sen.hidden_notes:
This translation also appeared in the Klingon subtitles for {DSC - The Vulcan Hello:src}.

An earlier translation of this phrase appears in UPN's Star Trek 25th Anniversary Special (1991), spoken by Leonard Nimoy (not in character as Spock): {yItaH 'ej yIcheptaH@@yI-:v, taH:v:1, 'ej:conj, yI-:v, chep:v, -taH:v}.
yIn nI' yISIQ 'ej yIchep!:sen.source: [1] {Radio Times Star Trek 30th Anniversary Special Issue:src}

notes.en: This literally means "life gas".
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/sKHEvMGdaxE}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/sKHEvMGdaxE}

yIntaHbogh qagh jablu'DI' reH nIvqu' qag.entry_name: yIntaHbogh qagh jablu'DI' reH nIvqu' qagh.

definition.en: Gagh is always best when served live.
definition.de: Gagh ist immer am besten, wenn es lebend serviert wird.

definition.en: There will be no peace as long as Kirk lives.
definition.de: Solange Kirk fortbesteht ist Frieden nicht möglich.

yIntaHvIS qIrq DuHbe' roj.:sen.source: [1] {Star Trek V deleted scene:src}, [2] {HQ 8.4, p.12, Dec. 1999:src}

yIpIv!:sen.hidden_notes: This was used by MO in a "get well" letter.

yIQ:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

examples.en: {puH yIQ:n}

definition.en: Don't just aim; hit the target!
definition.de: Ziele nicht nur; treffe das Ziel!

notes.en: For example, used to describe a warrior gathering his armour and weapons before a battle.

examples.en: ▶ {nuHmeyDaj may'luchDaj nIv je yIr qeylIS:sen:nolink} "Kahless gathered his weapons and his finest suit of armor"

notes.en:
This is used when addressing a single person. To address multiple people, say {peratlh!:sen@@pe-:v, ratlh:v}

Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/HVOJkR51lBU}
This is also spelled "Yridian" in English.

definition.en: Stand by to de-cloak for firing.
definition.de: Sei bereit zum Enttarnen. Sei bereit zum Feuern.

notes.en: Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/PUwSJai1cps}
notes.de: Siehe wie Gowron dies sagt: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/PUwSJai1cps}

notes.en: The subject of this verb can only be a person or creature, not an inanimate object or situation. See {KGT p.167:src} for an explanation of this slang word.

This word originally referred to a sleeveless garment (see {yIvbeH:n:2}).

In {TNK:src}, this word is used to translate "shirt", and {yIvbeH SeQHa':n:nolink} is used for "T-shirt".
This word has this meaning in the {voSpegh Sep:n} dialect.

definition.de: Habe vertrauen, aber achte auf die Türen.

yIvoq 'ach lojmItmey yISam.:sen.hidden_notes: There is a grammatical error with this sentence. It should be {tISam} rather than {yISam:sen:nolink}.

definition.de: Vertrauen ist gut, Kontrolle ist besser.

notes.en: yIvoq 'ach yI'ol.

definition.en: speak in an honorable or respectful fashion
definition.de: in ehrvoller und respektvoller Weise sprechen

yI':v.hidden_notes: The example sentence appears to be a lip-match for {HIja':excl}.

examples.en: ▶ {jIyI'.} "With respect."

en: speak in an honourable or respectful fashion

notes.en: This word is used for gathering plants or plant parts, whether {Du' naH:n} or {naH tlhab:n}. (See {KGT p.89:src}.)
According to {A Burning House:src}, this is a Klingon festival to celebrate the end of harvest. Its name literally comes from {yob:v} and {-ta':v}.

This word refers to a plate of material, often metal, carried by a warrior for protection. It is not used to refer to the force fields ({Surchem:n}) protecting a spaceship, for which see {botjan:n}.[2]
This is used for real shields. To "shield oneself" is {yoD'egh}. For force fields, use {botjan:n} with {chu':v:2}.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {QaghmeylIj tIchID, yIyoH.:sen}
▶ {reH Hegh yoHwI'pu''e'.:sen}

yomIj:n.hidden_notes: Reverse of {jImoy:sen:nolink} "Jimmy", a reference to the character Jimmy Neutron.

examples.en: ▶ {qab yon Da'agh. qablIj yon yI'aghHa' 'aghHa'pa' 'etlhwIj.:sen:nolink} "Scrape that smug look from your face before my blade does it for you."[2]

▶ {tlhIngan wo' yuQmey chovlu'chugh Qo'noS potlh law' Hoch potlh puS. roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH. pa' 'oHtaH vaS'a''e'. tlhIngan qum waw' 'oH. yoq yIn yuQ 'oH Qo'noS'e'. yInSIp voQSIp je ngaS muDDaj.:sen:nolink}
  "The principal planet of the Klingon Empire, Qo'noS is usually referred to as simply "The Homeworld." This is where the Klingon Great Hall is located, the center of the Klingon government. Qo'noS is a class-M planet with an oxygen/nitrogen atmosphere."[1]

notes.en: This word is not used for a removable top, which would be a {yuvtlhe':n} "lid". The other face of an object's {yor:n:nolink} is called its {'aqroS:n:1}.[1]

yor:n.hidden_notes: "You're the Top" is a song by Cole Porter.

notes.en: This is the general term for a fixed or non-fixed shelf.
This line was spoken in Klingon but was not subtitled.

yotlh:n.hidden_notes: This was defined only as "field (of land)" in {TKD:src}. The definition "park (e.g., recreational)" was added at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.

notes.en: The verb {yoy:v} does not appear with the suffix {-moH:v} in canon. However, MO approved of {yoymoHwI'} as a bit of technobabble meaning "inverter".[1]
A fleet consists of more than one {nawlogh:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {Hergh qengbogh yo':n}

notes.en: This term refers to a concept which appears in Klingon beliefs about the afterlife.

yo'SeH yaHnIv:n.hidden_notes: The sentence in which this appeared was actually written with hyphens, like this: {HoD, yo'-SeH yaH-nIv-vo' potlh De' wI-Hev-taH:sen:nolink}, with a newline between {potlh:sen:nolink} and {De':sen:nolink}.[1] The correct spelling (and spacing) was later confirmed.[3]

examples.en: ▶ {yo'SeH yaHnIvvo' potlh De' wIHevtaH.:sen}

definition.en: We are receiving a priority message from Operations Command.
definition.de: Wir haben wichtige Daten vom Operationskommando empfangen.

yo'SeH yaHnIvvo' potlh De' wIHevtaH.:sen.hidden_notes: This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}. The sentence in which this appeared was actually written with hyphens, like this: {HoD, yo'-SeH yaH-nIv-vo' potlh De' wI-Hev-taH:sen:nolink}, with a newline between {potlh:sen:nolink} and {De':sen:nolink}.[1]

definition.en: first (and last) tone of nonatonic musical scale
definition.de: erster (und letzter) Ton der neunstufigen Tonleiter
definition.sv: första (och sista) tonen på den nonatoniska skalan

notes.en:
The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n:nolink}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.[1]

The first and second {yu:n:nolink} are not an octave apart, but rather a nonave apart.[2]

yu:n.hidden_notes: Instead of "doe", which is a deer, an "ewe" is a sheep.

definition.en: husk, rind, peel, shell (of fruit, nut)

notes.en: Humans eat {yuch ngoghmey:n:nolink}, which Maltz finds strange.

examples.en: ▶ {nuqDaq yuch Dapol?:sen:nolink} "Where do you keep the chocolate?"[1, p.172; 2]

notes.en: There is an idiom, {yuDHa'; ghIt rur@@yuDHa':v, ghIt:n:0, rur:v}.

definition.en: include, consist of, be composed of

notes.en: This is used for talking about chemistry.

examples.en: ▶ {cha' bIQSIp HeySelmey, wa' yInSIp HeySel je yugh bIQ 'o'rIS@@cha':n, bIQSIp:n, HeySel:n, -mey:n, wa':n, yInSIp:n, HeySel:n, je:conj, yugh:v, bIQ:n, 'o'rIS:n} "the water molecule consists of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom"

definition.en: filter for X only, include X only

notes.en: This is the name of a play by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}, and also the name of its titular character.

examples.en: ▶ {mIn yuqwI':n}

definition.sv: Förenade planeters federation (United Federation of Planets)

notes.en: The United Federation of Planets is often simply called "the Federation" ({DIvI':n}). Another word for it is {yuQjIjQa':n}.

definition.sv: Förenade planeters federation (United Federation of Planets)

notes.en: Another word for the United Federation of Planets is {yuQjIjDIvI':n} (often shortened to just {DIvI':n}).
The object of this verb (when there is one) is the person or group of people (usually) being distracted.

This is the word for a musical scale, but it can also be used for other sorts of ranges.

The tones of the Klingon musical scale are: {yu:n:nolink}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.[1]

definition.sv: kusinbarn, tremänning, avlägset syskonbarn (syskons barnbarn, syssling etc.)

notes.en: The singular form is never used in place of {tey':n:nolink} or {lor:n:nolink}, but the plural may be used for a group including {tey':n:nolink} and/or {lor:n:nolink}, so long as there is at least one more distant cousin, niece or nephew in the group.
This is a chemical compound which reacts to create an explosion when combined with {'anISyum:n}.

yuryum:n.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Magic to Make the Sanest Man Go Mad:src}

yuwey:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the merger between United Airlines (UA) and Continental Airlines.

definition.sv: lock, kapsyl, propp, kork, överdrag, fodral

yuvtlhe':n.hidden_notes: Literally, "push, turn" (how you open a so-called child-proof lid).

notes.en: It may just be a coincidence, but {yu:n} and {'egh:n} are the first and third tones of the Klingon nonatonic musical scale.

yu'egh:n.hidden_notes: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

notes.en:
There is no difference between a paper form or a digital form on a computer screen.

The verb {naQmoH:v@@naQ:v, -moH:v} is used for filling out forms.

Both {'ab:v:nolink} and {'aD:v} mean "have a length of", but they are used in different contexts. {'ab:v:nolink} is used for long items and to express height. The object of {'ab:v:nolink} is the length or height of the subject.

examples.en:
▶ {wej 'ujmey 'ab 'oy'naQ.:sen:nolink} "Painstiks are a little over one meter long."[1]
▶ {jav 'ujmey 'ab SuvwI'.:sen:nolink}[2]
▶ {vagh 'ujmey vI'ab.:sen:nolink}[2]
▶ {wej 'uj 'ab naQjej.:sen:nolink}[2]

definition.sv: men, ändå, dock, trots allt, emellertid

notes.en: This is sometimes shortened to {'a:conj:nolink}.

'aD:n.hidden_notes: This was originally defined as "vein" in {TKD:src}, and subsequently expanded to mean "blood vessel" in general.

notes.en: Both {'aD:v:nolink} and {'ab:v} mean "have a length of", but they are used slightly differently. For flat objects such as tabletops, {'aD:v:nolink} is used for one dimension while {juch:v} is used for the other. For long objects, and for height, {'ab:v:nolink} is used instead.[2]
This is the 1st rank of {yaS:n}.

'al:v.hidden_notes: Muhammad Ali said to "float like a butterfly and sting like a bee".

'alnIl:n.hidden_notes: Alnilam is the star in the middle of Orion's belt.

definition.sv: yxa med med spets i änden

'al'on:n.hidden_notes:
The definition is given as "glass", in a list of materials.

"Aluminium oxynitride" is the ceramic known as "transparent aluminum".

notes.en: This is a specialized school.[2] (For the most general word for a place of learning, see {DuSaQ:n}.)

'ampaS:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).

notes.en: A planet in the Federation. Also called {'anDorya':n:nolink}. Not to be confused with the country on Earth called {'anDo'ra':n}.
This is the name of a country on Earth. Not to be confused with the planet {'anDor:n}.
This is a chemical compound which reacts to create an explosion when combined with {yuryum:n}.

'anISyum:n.source: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Magic to Make the Sanest Man Go Mad:src}

notes.en: This is a name from {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}'s play {'antonI' tlhI'yopatra' je:sen:nolink}.
This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

examples.en:
▶ {qablIj HI'ang:sen:nolink} "Show me your face!" (see {Hay':v})[2, p.68]
▶ {ro'lIj HI'ang!:sen}[2, p.195]

'ang'eghQo' quv Hutlhbogh jagh neH ghobt.entry_name: 'ang'eghQo' quv Hutlhbogh jagh neH ghobtaHvIS ghaH.

definition.en: Only an enemy without honor refuses to show himself in battle.
definition.de: Nur ein Gegner ohne Ehre zeigt sein Gesicht nicht während des Kampfes.

en: Only an enemy without honour refuses to show himself in battle.

examples.en: ▶ {logh chal je 'angweD:n}

'ap:v.hidden_notes: Arthur Philip Dent is the protagonist of {The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy:src}.

examples.en: {chuch 'aplom:n}

notes.en: This is the general term for a small container.[3]

'aplo':n.hidden_notes: This word was originally used to translated "Limited Edition" for {Klingon Monopoly:src}, as {'aplo'mey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink}, before {'aplo':n:nolink} was changed to {vey:n}. The Klingon version of the list of the game box's "contents" also has the heading {ngaS 'aplo':sen:nolink}. (There is a typo in {ngaS 'aplo':sen:nolink}: it actually reads {naS 'aplo':sen:nolink} on the box, but it's clear what was meant.)

examples.en: {'ul 'aplo':n}, {wab qoSta' 'aplo':n}

notes.en: This is a particular kind of {toQ:n} which flies particularly fast.

'apuStoQ:n.hidden_notes: "Apus" is the Latin name for the birds commonly known as swifts.

notes.en:
This refers to predicting based on deductive reasoning or research or science.

Note that weather forecasts (see {muD Dotlh:n}) tend to use {'e' -lu:sen@@'e':n, -lu':v} over {net:n}, but using {net:n:nolink} would not be wrong.
notes.de:
Dies bezieht sich auf eine Vorhersage, die auf wissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse basiert.

Man beachte dass es bei der Wettervorhersage (siehe {muD Dotlh:n}) üblich ist {'e' -lu:sen@@'e':n, -lu':v} anstatt {net:n} zu sagen, aber {net:n:nolink} zu verwenden wäre nicht falsch.

'aq:v.hidden_notes: The word for "reason" or "intellect" in Arabic is "'aql".

examples.en:
▶ {SIS 'e' vI'aq:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, vI-:v, 'aq:v} "I forecast/predict (that it will) rain."
▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu':sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v} "it is predicted that it will rain"
▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu'bej:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -bej:v} "it is predicted with certainty that it will rain"
▶ {SISbe' 'e' 'aqlu'bej:sen@@SIS:v, -be':v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -bej:v} "it is predicted with certainty that it will not rain"
▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu'law':sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -law':v} "it would appear that it will rain, it seems that it will rain"
▶ {ghaytan SIS 'e' 'aqlu':sen@@ghaytan:adv, SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v} "it's likely that it will rain"
▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu', javmaH vatlhvI' DIch:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, jav:n:1,num, maH:n:2,num, vatlhvI':n, DIch:n} "it is predicted that it will rain, 60% certainty", or "there's a 60% chance it will rain"

definition.en: type of weapon (half ax, half bat'leth)
definition.sv: ett slags vapen (hälften yxa, hälften bat'leth)

notes.en: This is a general purpose knife that seems to be able to cut through anything.

'aqnaw:n.hidden_notes: The phrase "Act now!" is used repeatedly in TV informercials for Ginsu knives.

definition.en: bottom surface of a table, ceiling

notes.en: The other face of an object's {'aqroS:n:1,nolink} is its {yor:n}.[1]

This word is used to specify a limit or restriction.

In other contexts, consider using the verb suffix {-qu':v}. For example: {nom yIghoSqu'!:sen}

examples.en:
▶ {'aqroS qughDo - pIvlob Hut vI' vagh:sen:nolink} "Maximum Cruising Speed - Warp 9.5"[1]
▶ {Qapchu'meH 'aqroS chuq:n:nolink} "maximum effective range"[1]

notes.en: A character in a famous Klingon opera.

definition.en: act of watching over a fallen warrior's body
definition.de: Betrachten des Körpers eines gefallen Kriegers

notes.en: This is an ancient tradition where the comrades of a warrior who had died in battle stayed with the body to keep away predators, which allowed the spirit ({qa':n}) to leave the body when it was ready for the journey to Sto-Vo-Kor ({Suto'vo'qor:n}).
This question word follows the noun to which it refers, which never has a plural suffix.

examples.en:
▶ {Haw'pu' yaS 'ar?:sen:nolink} "How many officers fled?" ({TKD p.70:src})
▶ {nIn 'ar wIghaj?:sen:nolink} "How much fuel do we have?" ({TKD p.70,170:src})
▶ {Dochvetlh DIlmeH Huch 'ar DaneH?:sen} "How much do you want for that?" ({TKD p.171:src})

'arDeH:n.hidden_notes: The ivy belongs to the genus "Hedera".

notes.en:
This is the most common of several ways of asking for the time in Klingon. One can also ask, {'arlogh wab Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} or {qen 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} The answer to this question is, for example, {cha'logh Qoylu'pu':sen:nolink} "It has been heard twice", meaning "two o'clock".

The Federation's 24-hour system ({tera' poH:n}) is sometimes used in interplanetary communication. When working within this system, the way to ask for the time is to issue the command, {rep yIper!:sen:nolink} In replying to this command, the hours are not counted, but rather numbered from 1 to 24. For example, {tera' rep cha':sen:nolink} or {rep cha':sen:nolink} is "two o'clock". When context is clear, {tera':n} may be left out.

examples.en: ▶ {mamejDI' 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen@@ma-:v, mej:v, -DI':v, 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen} "What time do we leave?"

notes.en: This is typically found on the feet of some sort of Klingon animal or on Klingon trees. In non-scientific, everyday speech, this seems to function as a general term for "fungus".[2]

definition.en: When an escaped prisoner looks for a guard, he always finds one.
definition.de: Ein entflohener Gefangener, der nach einem Wächter sucht, wird immer einen finden.

definition.en: A prisoner says to the guard...

notes.en:
This is a type of beverage made from (among other things) the {melchoQ:n} of a {teghbat:n}. It has a superficial resemblance to Terran root beer.[1, p.95]

This word refers not to a specific drink, but to a narrow class of related drinks.[2]

'awje':n.hidden_notes: "A&W" is a brand of root beer.

'aw':v.hidden_notes:
"Ow".

The example literally means "My eyes sting me", which shows that {'aw':v:nolink} can take an object.

examples.en: ▶ {mu'aw' mInDu'wIj.} "My eyes sting."[2]

notes.en: This can be used for any kind of building element, construction part, or even Lego pieces.[3]
This is a place name in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on Earth.

An opportunity is said to be captured ({jon:v}), and if one misses an opportunity, it is said to have escaped ({nargh:v:2}).[3] See examples below.

In a Klingon bar, the bartender ({chom:n}) shouts {'eb Qav:n} for "last call".[4]

examples.en:
▶ {jIpaSqu'mo' narghpu' qaSuchmeH 'eb.:sen:nolink} "Because I'm very late, the opportunity to visit you has escaped."[3]
▶ {qaSuch vIneH 'ach narghpu' 'eb. jIpaSqu'.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit you, but the opportunity has escaped. I am very late."[3]
▶ {qaSuchlaHbe'. jIpaSqu' vaj narghpu' 'eb.:sen:nolink} "I cannot visit you. I am very late, thus the opportunity has escaped."[3]

notes.en: This is shouted by the bartender ({chom:n}) at a Klingon bar ({tach:n}) before alcoholic beverages cease to be served.
This is the 4th rank of {yaS:n}.
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Quj 'echlet:n:nolink} is used to mean "game board".
This refers to a computer input device.

In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {'echletHom:n:nolink} is used for the various kinds of game cards. In {TNK:src}, {QIn 'echletHom:n} is used to mean "postcard".

The suits in a deck of playing cards are called {Degh:n:1}.

examples.en: ▶ {Quj wa'DIch juH qachmey mebpa'mey je qa' raQmey chu' monmey chu' je:sen:nolink} "Custom OUTPOSTS and CAPITALS replace original Houses and Hotels"[1]

definition.sv: arrogant person, inbilsk person, högfärdig person

notes.en: This refers to a person who is {nguq:v}.

'eDjen:n.hidden_notes: Mister Ed is a famous horse from television, and {jen:v} means "high". An arrogant person is said to be sitting on a "high horse".

notes.en: This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown. It appears to consist of the elements {SeH:v} and {cha:n}, or homophones thereof, and an element {'eD:v:hyp} whose meaning is unknown.

definition.en: third tone of nonatonic musical scale
definition.sv: tredje tonen på den nonatoniska skalan

notes.en: The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n:nolink}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

'egh:n.hidden_notes: The third tone of the musical scale is "me", and {-'egh:v:suff} is the "self" suffix.

notes.en: This expression indicates that the speaker is about to give a command.
The conjunction {'ej:conj} does not have any temporal or sequential implications.[2] To express those meanings, use {ghIq:adv} or {ngugh:adv}.
According to {TKD p.20:src}, it's likely that {Do':n:archaic,hyp} is an archaic word for the modern {Duj:n:1}.
This is what the Starfleet equivalent of {yo'SeH yaHnIv:n} would theoretically be called.

definition.en: And the blood was ankle deep (drinking song)

definition.sv: göra entré, gå in i, komma in

notes.en: The object is the thing being entered. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

examples.en:
▶ {HIq DaSammeH tach yI'el.:sen}
▶ {neHmaH Da'el net tu':sen:nolink} "Caught breaching the Neutral Zone."[3]

notes.en: Note that this is specifically a ticket for entry. For other types of tickets, consider another verb in place of {'el:v}.

'elmeH chaw':n.hidden_notes: At "By Any Other Name: An Evening of Shakespeare in Klingon", put on by the Washington Shakespeare company, the sign on the will-call tickets window said {'elmeH chaw'mey je'lu'ta'bogh:n:nolink}. This translation was supplied by MO.

'elI'jaH:n.hidden_notes: A reference to a Passover custom in which an empty seat is reserved for the prophet Elijah.

notes.en: This is usually made of metal.

'elpI':n.hidden_notes: This is an "LP", a long-playing music record.

notes.en: For the rear section of an object, see {'o':n}. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.
This is the name of a series of Federation starships.

examples.en: ▶ {'entepray' Hub patmey luchu'be'lu'pu'.:sen}

definition.de: Die Verteidigungssysteme der Enterprise sind ausgeschaltet.

'entepray' Hub patmey luchu'be'lu'pu'.:s.source: [1] {Star Trek V deleted scene:src}, [2] {HQ 8.4, p.13, Dec. 1999:src}

'entepray' yIghoS.:sen.hidden_notes: The subtitle actually says "Bear on Enterprise."

notes.en: This verb refers to an action which is between {Sop:v} and {tlhutlh:v}. In particular, it refers to consuming {chatlh:n:1}, which contains less liquid than what a Terran might identify as soup.[1, p.206]
This is what Klingons would call the Terran fruit.
This word should not be confused with {'eQway':n}.

'eQway:n.hidden_notes: "Kyle XY" was an American TV show the title character of which lacks this body part.

notes.en:
This refers to a computer input device. It typically has two buttons (called {leQ:n}): a {poS leQ:n@@poS:n, leQ:n} and a {nIH leQ:n@@nIH:n, leQ:n}.

This word should not be confused with {'eQway:n}.

'eQway':n.hidden_notes: A computer mouse is used to choose the (X,Y) coordinate on a computer screen.

definition.en: end (of stick, rope, etc.), other end from {megh'an:n}
definition.de: Ende (von Stab, Schnur, usw.), das gegenüberliegende Ende heißt {megh'an:n}

notes.en: This can refer to either end of the rope, stick or whatever, but once you arbitrarily choose an end to call {'er'In:n:nolink}, the other end is called {megh'an:n:nolink}. Before you make this initial reference, either end can be called either {'er'In:n:nolink} or {megh'an:n:nolink}.

'er'In:n.hidden_notes: This is a private joke referring to a specific person.

notes.en: This is the Klingon pronunciation of the word "spade", referring to the suit in a deck of playing cards.

'eSpeD:n.hidden_notes: In MO's message, he wrote "He [Maltz] just called a spade {'eSpeD:n:nolink}." The expression "calling a spade a spade" is an idiom in English.

notes.en: For the area in front of an object, see {tlhop:n:1}.
This could refer to the blade of a knife or spear.

definition.en: Even the best blade will rust and grow dull unless it is cared for.
definition.de: Sogar das beste Schwert wird rosten und stumpf werden wenn es nicht gepflegt wird.

definition.en: area northwestward, area towards the northwest

notes.en: This is approximately 320 degrees on a Terran compass, if north is 0 and degrees are counted clockwise.

'ev:n.hidden_notes: Eva Saint Marie starred in Alfred Hitchcock's "North-by-Northwest".

examples.en:
▶ {labmeH 'evnagh Se' lo' tlhIngan QumwI'. janmey ngo' lulo'lu'DI' pIj jabbI'ID nISpu' woj.:sen:nolink}
  "A Klingon communicator sends a signal through subspace radio. Older models were susceptible to radiation."[2]

definition.en: animal similar to a newt or salamander
definition.de: Tier ähnlich einer Eidechse oder Salamander

'evta':n.hidden_notes: A newt is called an "eft" in its terrestrial juvenile phase.

'ewrop:n.hidden_notes: This was accidentally left out of the continents section of the printed booklet.

definition.en: be good, be delicious, be tasty, be harmonious
definition.sv: vara god, vara delikat, vara välsmakande, vara harmonisk

notes.en: This word is applied to food and music.

'ey:v.hidden_notes: In English slang, "ey!" is an expression of satisfaction.

notes.en: This is used for food that has been prepared poorly.[1, p.84]
This is the name of a river in {mIyama:n}.

This pronoun is used as the object of the second sentence in a sentence-as-object construction. It refers to the previous sentence as a whole. In such a construction, the second sentence never takes an aspect suffix.

Normally, {net:n:pro} is used when the subject of the verb is indefinite (that is, {X net Y:sen:nolink} is used instead of {X 'e' Y-lu':sen:nolink}). However, this is not always the case. See {net:n:pro} for examples.

Do not confuse this pronoun with the suffix {-'e':n:suff}.

examples.en:
▶ {qama'pu' DIHoH 'e' luSov:sen:nolink} "They know we kill prisoners."[1]
▶ {yaS qIppu' 'e' vIlegh:sen:nolink} "I saw him/her hit the officers."[1]

notes.en: This is a word borrowed from Federation Standard to refer to the Terran animal.
notes.de: Dies ist ein Lehnwort und beschreibt ein irdisches Tier.

notes.en: The child of an {'e'mam:n:nolink} is a {lor:n:1}.

'e'mam:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to "Auntie Mame", a broadway play.

definition.en: someone who married into the family
definition.de: jemand der an die Familie angeheiratet ist
definition.sv: ingift person, någon som gift in sig i familjen

notes.en: This is a square or rectangular tub used to hold food while fermenting.

'IDnar:n.hidden_notes: James Randi is a famous magician.

notes.en: This refers to a true wizard or sorcerer. For a magician, see {mIn yuqwI':n}.
This word has negative connotations, and is considered quite insulting when applied to a person.[1, p.167]
In {voSpegh Sep:n}, this is used instead of {ghaw':n:1}.

examples.en: ▶ {tlhIngan 'IH qaD DaQap.:sen@@tlhIngan:n, 'IH:v, qaD:n, Da-:v, Qap:v:1} "Win Klingon beauty contest."[2]
▶ {DIvI' Se' wI'IjtaHvIS DaH ngoqDe' wIHevta'.:sen}

'Im:v.hidden_notes: [...] heating it up so that it boils. The general word for "boil" is {pub:sen:nolink}, but the verb used specifically to refer to the boiling of fat is {'Im:sen:nolink}. ({KGT p.94:src})

notes.en: A pyramid with a three-sided base is called a {qu'vu':n}. A pyramid with an n-sided base is an {n reD 'Impey':n:nolink} for n > 3. For example: {loS reD 'Impey':n@@loS:n:1,num, reD:n:2, 'Impey':n}, {vagh reD 'Impey':n@@vagh:n:1,num, reD:n:2, 'Impey':n}. A cone is a {gho 'Impey':n}.

'Impey':n.hidden_notes: "I. M. Pei" is the architect who designed the pyramid at the Louvre.

definition.en: sound made by a {vIghro':n} or a {ghISnar:n}

notes.en: A particular percussion instrument may be struck with the palm ({toch:n}; the verb is {weq:v}), the fist ({ro':n}; the verb is {tlhaw':v}), or a stick ({mupwI'Hom:n} if it resembles a small hammer, {naQHom:n} if a plain stick; the verb is {moq:v}).[1]
This refers to the bright part of a plant.

'InSong:n.hidden_notes: A reference to the novel "Flower Drum Song" by C. Y. Lee (see {'In:n}), or the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical of the same name.

notes.en: Maltz insisted that this was a proper Klingon word.[1]
To make an {'Ip:n} is to {'Ip:v} or {lay':v}; to keep it is to {pab:v} the {'Ip:n}.

examples.en: ▶ {tugh 'Ipvetlh Dapab DaneH'a'?:sen:nolink} "How would you like to keep that promise, very soon?"[2]

notes.en: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n:nolink}.

'Iptay:n.hidden_notes: This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

definition.en: be too much, be too many
definition.sv: vara för många, vara för mycket

notes.en:
This is not exactly the same as {QuchHa':v}, since the latter implies a change from being happy to not being happy.[2]

See {rav:n:1} for an idiom related to sadness.

examples.en: ▶ {bI'IQchugh yIvang!:sen}

▶ {Da'Irghlu'chugh, potlhqu' Huch Daghaqbogh, 'ej yInmey lutoDlu'meH Qu' 'ut wItur 'e' QaH noblIj.:sen:nolink} "If you were bullied, money that you contribute is very important, and your gift will help us carry out an essential mission so that lives are saved."

'Irgh:v.source: [1] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src}), [2] {qep'a' 2017:src}

notes.en: The child of an {'IrneH:n:nolink} is a {lor:n:1}.

'IrneH:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to Uncle "Henry" from The Wizard of Oz.

notes.en: This word fits into a sentence in the place which would be occupied by the answer.[1] It works like a pronoun in questions with "to be" in the English translations.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {SoH 'Iv?:sen} "Who are you?"[3]

'Iv juvwI':n.hidden_notes: This term does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

notes.en: There is an idiom, {HoS; 'Iw rur}.

'Iw:n.hidden_notes: This sounds like what a human would say upon seeing blood.

examples.en: ▶ {bomDI' 'IwwIj qaqaw.:sen}

definition.en: I travel the river of blood.
definition.de: Ich reise auf dem Fluss des Blutes.

definition.en: May you travel the river of blood.
definition.de: Mögest du auf dem Fluss des Blutes reisen.
definition.ru: Пусть ты путешествуешь по реке крови.

notes.en: This is best served at {porgh Hat:n}.[1, p.94]

definition.en: Sufficient blood wine does not exist.
definition.de: Sowas wie genug Blutwein gibt es nicht.

'Iw HIq yap tu'lu'be'.:sen.hidden_notes: This was the winning secrecy proverb entry, submitted by Lawrence Schoen ({'angghal:n:name,nolink}), in the proverbs competition at {qep'a' 2014:src}.

notes.en: This is used in the preparation of {qagh:n}.[1, p.87]
This is the name of a statue by the sculptor {mIStaq:n:name}.

definition.en: Listen to the voice of your blood.
definition.de: Höre auf die Stimme deines Blutes.

notes.en: Watch a lesson on this toast: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/_mHUA5QKSG0}

'IwlIj jachjaj!:sen.hidden_notes: When this toast first appeared in {CK:src}, it was thought that its grammar was incorrect. However, this toast was repeated in {PK:src}, where it was noted that toasts follow special grammar. This grammar was finally explained in {KGT:src} (see under {-jaj:v}).[3]

definition.en: My blood is thicker than yours.
definition.de: Mein Blut ist dicker als deins.

notes.en: This idiomatic phrase carries the meaning, "I am much stronger than you."

'I':n.hidden_notes: This word was originally made up by Mark Shoulson to illustrate why people shouldn't make up words, since no one else would understand them. When MO heard about it, he turned it into a real word as a joke.[2]

notes.en: This isn't an exact translation, but {'I'SeghIm:n:nolink} is the closest Klingon equivalent to the English word "curmudgeon".[1]

'I'SeghIm:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to "Isegrim" (or "Ysengrimus"), a wolf who is the chief character in a series of fables.

notes.en: This appears before a name used as direct address, almost like a vocative prefix.

examples.en: ▶ {'o 'oghlu'meH qul:sen}

definition.en: O for a Muse of fire

notes.en: This is the opening line of {HenrI' vagh:n:name} by {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}.

definition.en: order, group officially recognized by government
definition.de: Orden, eine durch die Regierung anerkannte Gruppe
definition.sv: orden, grupp officiellt erkänd av regering

notes.en: Parts of an ax include its handle, {DeS:n:2}, and its blade, {ghIt:n:2}.

This refers to a person who puts in pipes (whether for water or for anything else). There is a special word for a pipe that carries water, {qatlhDa':n}, but the person who puts this in is still called an {'och mutlhwI':n:nolink}.

'oDtu':n.hidden_notes: "Ode to Spot" is the name of a poem Data wrote to his cat, Spot.

notes.en: This word implies the creation of something which has not been created before. In this, it differs from {ren:v}.

definition.ru: он, она, оно, его, её (для вещей, не способных использовать речь)

definition.en: verify, check if (something) is true, make sure that (something) is true
definition.de: überprüfen, kontrollieren, prüfen ob etwas wahr bzw. richtig ist

notes.en: Note that {'ol:v:nolink} is used for checking a fact, while {woq:v} is used for confirming it.

'ol:v.hidden_notes: The {TKD:src} definition says only "verify". This was expanded upon at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}.

'om:v.hidden_notes: "Ohm" is the unit of electrical resistance.

definition.en: some, an unknown or unspecified quantity
definition.sv: någon, något, några, en del, en okänd eller ospecificerad mängd

notes.en:
Verbs related to aircraft (or spacecraft) movement include: {Dav:v}, {Der:v}, {jer:v}, {jIm:v}, {lol:v:2}, {ron:v}, {tor:v:2}.

It is unknown if all of these words have meanings outside of the context of aircraft attitude descriptions. However, {ron:v:nolink} can be applied to other objects such as dice (see {mI' nagh:n}), and {lol:v:nolink} and {tor:v:nolink} can be applied to people or animals (see {lol:v:1} and {tor:v:1}).
This is also called {'orghenya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[2]
This is also called {'orghenya' rojmab:n:nolink}.

Note that this is {'orghengan:n:nolink} and not {'orghenngan:n:nolink} (the {n:sen:nolink} at the end of {'orghen:n:nolink} is dropped).

This word is also written {'orghenya'ngan:n:nolink}.

definition.de: Pilot, jemand der ein Flugzeug lenkt

'orwI':n.hidden_notes: This word consists of the first two letters of "Or"ville and "Wi"lbur Wright's names.

'oS:v.source: [1] {TKD:src}, [2] {SkyBox 20:src} (reprinted in {HQ 5.2, p.14, Jun. 1996:src}), [3] {SkyBox 31:src} (reprinted in {HQ 6.2, p.9, Jun. 1997:src})

definition.en: quantum theory, quantum mechanics, quantum physics

'otlhQeD:n.hidden_notes: This was first defined as "quantum theory, quantum mechanics" in 2014, and subsequently as "quantum physics" in 2015.

'otlhtej:n.hidden_notes: In 2014, following the definition of {'otlhQeD:n}, this was glossed as "the corresponding scientist, someone who studies quantum mechanics". It was subsequently given the stand-alone definition of "quantum physicist" in 2015.

'oynot:n.hidden_notes: A reference to Antonio ({tonyo':sen:nolink}) from The Merchant of Venice.

'oy'naQ:n.hidden_notes: This is spelled "painstik" (without the "c") throughout Star Trek canon, except in {TKDA:src} where it is spelled "painstick".

definition.en: If you don't use the painstik, the child will never celebrate his Age of Ascension.
definition.de: Wenn du den Schmerzstock nicht benutzt, wird das Kind nie das Aufstiegsalter zelebrieren.

notes.en: This idiomatic expression literally means "My little toe aches a lot". See {Qay':v:2} for an explanation.
For the area behind an object, see {'em:n}.
The {'o' chuyDaH:n:nolink} is located near the {Hongghor:n}. They are listed together as {'o' chuyDaH Hongghor je:n:nolink} on the {BoP:src} poster.
This is a drum with skin stretched over both ends.[1, p.75]

This word is only used for songs. The final phrase or portion in other kinds of performances is referred to using {bertlham:n}.

All Klingon songs have {'o'meghmey:n:nolink}. If a song fades away instead of properly ending, as some Federation songs do, the ending of such a song may be called {'o'meghqoq:n:nolink}.

'o'roy':n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to O. Roy Chalk.

definition.de: Jemand mit zweideutigem oder undeutlichem Stand

notes.en: This term can be used for "double agent" (for which a slang term is {jey'naS ghoqwI':n}), but its meaning is a bit broader.

'o'wen:n.hidden_notes: Possibly a reference to Owen Lattimore, who was accused under McCarthyism of being a spy.

notes.en: This verb can also be used to mean "lock" in the sense of locking on a target: {DoS 'uchta':sen@@DoS:n, 'uch:v:1, -ta':v} "he/she locked on the target".[2]

definition.en: include, consist of, be composed of

notes.en: This is used for talking about chemistry.

'uD:n.hidden_notes: The word {'uD'a':n:nolink} appears in {HQ 1.3, Sept. 1992:src}, where it is also defined as just "laser".

examples.en: ▶ {bIQSIp 'ugh:n}

definition.en: have a hangover, be hung over

notes.en:
Based on the measurements given on the {BoP:src} poster, one {'uj:n:nolink} is very close to 34.83 cm.

Three {'uj:n:nolink} is about 3'5", five {'uj:n:nolink} is about 5'8", and six {'uj:n:nolink} is about 6'10".[2]
notes.de:
Basiert auf die Maßangaben auf dem {BoP:src} Poster. Ein {'uj:n:nolink} entspricht ca. 34.83 cm.

Drei {'uj:n:nolink} sind etwa 3 Fuß 5 Zoll, fünf {'uj:n:nolink} sind etwa 5 Fuß 8 Zoll und sechs {'uj:n:nolink} sind etwa 6 Fuß 10 Zoll.[2]

'uj:n.hidden_notes: In {KGT:src}, this unit is described as "about 35 cm".

examples.en:
▶ {wej 'ujmey 'ab 'oy'naQ.:sen:nolink} "Painstiks are a little over one meter long."[3]
▶ {wejvatlh loSmaH loS vI' vagh wej 'uj 'aD Duj:sen:nolink} "Length: 120 M"[4]
▶ {loSmaH jav vI' Soch loS 'uj 'ab meH:sen:nolink} "Bridge Height: 16.28 M"[4]
▶ {HIvtaHvIS toQDuj cha'vatlh wejmaH Soch vI' vagh chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Attack Formation Height: 82.75 M"[4]
▶ {qughtaHvIS toQDuj HutmaH vI' jav wa' 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Cruise Formation Height: 31.56 M"[4]
▶ {SaqtaHvIS toQDuj wa'vatlh loS vI' jav chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Landing Formation Height: 36.46 M"[4]
▶ {cha' 'ujmo' jIH woch law' SoH woch puS:sen:nolink} "I'm two {'uj:sen:nolink}es taller than you."[5]

notes.en: One {'uj'a':n:nolink} is equal to nine {'uj:n:nolink}. However, there is no unit {'ujHom:n:nolink} denoting one-ninth of an {'uj:n:nolink}.[1]
notes.de: Ein {'uj'a':n:nolink} entspricht neun {'uj:n:nolink}. Es gibt aber keine Einheit wie {'ujHom:n:nolink} die ein Neuntel eines {'uj:n:nolink} entspräche.[1]

notes.en: He is a member of the House of Mo'Kai ({mo'qay tuq:n:name}).

'ul:n.hidden_notes: This is a reference to the "Underwriter's Laboratories". A label with the acronym "UL" is found on all electrical appliances in the US.

'ul 'aplo':n.hidden_notes: This word appears in {TNK:src} only in the plural as {'ul 'aplo'mey:n:nolink} "batteries". Technically, what is commonly called a "battery" is a single cell, and a "battery" is an array ({DaH:n}) of such cells.

'umHa':v.hidden_notes: This word is not actually defined in the {paq'batlh:src}, but its derivation and meaning are clear.

definition.de: Topf (allg. Begriff für Kochtopf, auch wenn Hitze nicht involviert ist)

notes.en: This is {quD:n} produced using chemicals.
notes.de: Dies ist {quD:n} das mit Chemikalien hergestellt wird.

definition.en: be unsavory, disgusting, repugnant, loathsome, icky
definition.sv: vara smaklös, vara äcklig, vara frånstötande, vara avskyvärd,

examples.en: ▶ {reH 'uQvam vIqawtaH.:sen}

'uQ pa':n.hidden_notes: This is just a regular noun-noun construction. It was used as an example in a message on the {msn:src} newsgroup to show that the known vocabulary and existing grammar can be used to say a lot of things which aren't explicitly spelled out.

'ur:v.hidden_notes: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKDA:src}.

notes.en: This is a person who commits treason. For a person who betrays someone, see {maghwI':n}.
notes.de: Das ist jemand, der einen (Hoch)Verrat begeht. Für jemanden, deinen einen anderen verrät, siehe {maghwI':n}.

'urwI':n.hidden_notes: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKDA:src}.

notes.en: Maltz referred to the Federation card game "Poker" as {'urghwI':n:nolink}, although other Klingons would probably not understand this.[1]

definition.fa: پا (از بالای زانو تا مچ پا)

definition.sv: en slags fågel (för oljud i gryningen, vildsintare än en tupp)

notes.en: This is a noisy bird known to make a ruckus at dawn, which has been likened to a rooster (but is much fiercer than a rooster).
notes.de: Das ist ein lauter Vogel der morgens wie ein Hahn kräht, aber viel lauter.

'uSgheb:n.hidden_notes: The "leghorn" is a type of chicken, and Foghorn Leghorn is a cartoon leghorn rooster.

'uSqan:n.hidden_notes: The USS Constitution had the nickname "Old Ironsides".

notes.en: {'uSu':n:nolink} is native to the original inhabitants of the planet Tanganika.[2]

'uSu':n.hidden_notes: The "yuzu" plant is used in the creation of some sauces in Asian cuisine.

examples.en: ▶ {'utbe' bel.:sen}

'utbe':v.hidden_notes: This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

examples.en: ▶ {'utbe' bel.:sen}

notes.en: This refers to a chest of drawers regardless of whether or not there are actually drawers in it at the moment.

'ut'at:n.hidden_notes: Under Armour (UA) is a brand of casual and sports clothing.

notes.en: An officer who ended service in retirement.

This verb is used for clicking on a computer mouse button (even though the action is actually to press down and then release). For clicking on a hyperlink, the verb {wIv:v} is used rather than {'uy:v:nolink}.[2]
This is also the name of an opera, which narrates many of the same events as found in the {paq'batlh:n}.
notes.de: Dies ist auch der Name einer Oper, welche einen Großteil der Geschichte des {paq'batlh:n} erzählt.

notes.en:
The noun formed with {-'a':n:suff,nolink} refers to something that is bigger, more important, or more powerful than the noun without the suffix.

Note that the noun with {-'a':n:suff,nolink} need not be better than the bare noun in every possibly way, just in one way that is significant for that noun. For example, a {mIv'a':n} is not necessarily bigger in size than a {mIv:n:1}, and a {toy'wI''a':n} is probably worse off in many ways when compared to a {toy'wI':n}.
The noun formed with {-Hom:n:suff,nolink} refers to something that is smaller, less important, or less powerful than the noun without the suffix.

This is a rarely used suffix, which is used to indicate endearment. It is usually attached to a word for a relative, or sometimes an animal such as a pet.

It is suspected that a {qaghwI':n} is inserted before this suffix if the noun ends in a vowel, but no examples are known.

-oy:n.hidden_notes: This sounds like the Cantonese word for "love" (愛).

examples.en:
▶ {SoSoy:n}
▶ {vavoy:n}

definition.en: plural (beings capable of using language) (noun type 2)
definition.ru: множественное число (для существ, способных использовать речь) (сущ. тип 2)

notes.en:
This suffix is attached to a noun referring to beings capable of language when there is more than one of that type of being.

Note that whether {-pu':n:suff,nolink} is used is a property of the noun, and not necessarily of the things it is referring to. For example, a group of Klingons rendered unable to speak, or a group of Klingon babies too young to understand language, would still be referred to as {tlhInganpu':n:nolink}.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {tlhInganpu':n:nolink} "Klingons"

notes.en: This suffix is used to form the plural of body parts, whether they belong to beings capable of language or to any other animal. However, if a body part becomes separated from a being and is transformed into something which is no longer primarily a body part, then {-mey:n:suff,nolink} is used instead. For example, the plural of {veDDIr:n} "pelt" is {veDDIrmey:n:nolink} rather than {veDDIrDu':n:nolink}.

examples.en: ▶ {qamDu':n:nolink} "feet"

notes.en:
When this suffix is used for beings capable of using language (see {-pu':n}), it adds the notion of "scattered all about" to the meaning. This suffix cannot be used for body parts (see {-Du':n}), but this rule is sometimes violated by poets.

Some nouns are inherently plural in meaning, with singular forms which are utterly distinct. These inherently plural nouns are treated as grammatically singular, in that singular pronouns and verb prefixes are used for them. When the suffix {-mey:n:nolink} is applied to the singular forms of these nouns, the resulting plural word carries the connotation of "scattered all about".

examples.en:
▶ {pu'HIchmey:n:nolink} "phasers"
▶ {puqmey:n:nolink} "children all over the place"
▶ {jatmey:n:nolink} "scattered tongues"
▶ {DoSmey:n:nolink} "targets scattered all about"

notes.en: This suffix indicates the noun is being used in a false or ironic fashion.

examples.en: ▶ {rojqoq:n:nolink} "the so-called peace"

notes.en: This suffix indicates that the speaker thinks the object referred to by the noun is accurately described by it, but has some doubts.

examples.en: ▶ {DujHey:n:nolink} "an apparent ship"

notes.en: Ths suffix indicates that the speaker has no doubt that the object referred to by the noun is accurately described by it.

examples.en: ▶ {Dujna':n:nolink} "a definite ship"

notes.en: It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

definition.en: my (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
definition.sv: min, mitt (substantiv förmöget till språk) (substantiv typ 4)
definition.ru: мой, мои (для существ, способных использовать речь) (сущ. тип 4)

notes.en: See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.
It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

definition.en: our (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
definition.sv: vår, vårt (substantiv förmöget till språk) (substantiv typ 4)
definition.ru: наш, наши (для существ, способных использовать речь) (сущ. тип 4)

notes.en: See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.
It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

definition.en: your (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
definition.sv: din, ditt (substantiv förmöget till språk) (substantiv typ 4)
definition.ru: твой, твои (для существ, способных использовать речь) (сущ. тип 4)

notes.en: See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.
It is considered derogatory to use this suffix on a noun referring to a being capable of language.

definition.en: your (plural) (noun capable of using language) (noun type 4)
definition.sv: er, ert (substantiv förmöget till språk) (substantiv typ 4)
definition.ru: ваш, ваши (для существ, способных использовать речь) (сущ. тип 4)

notes.en: See under {-pu':n:suff} for an explanation of when a noun qualifies as a being capable of language.

This indicates that the noun refers to an object which is nearby or which is the topic of the conversation.[1]

For most words designating a fixed period of time, this suffix indicates the current such period: {DISvam:n:nolink} "the current year", {jarvam:n:nolink} "the current month", {Hoghvam:n:nolink} "the current week", etc. However, {jajvam:n} "the current day" is not quite interchangeable with {DaHjaj:n} "today".[2]
This indicates that the noun refers to an object which is not nearby or which is brought up again as the topic of the conversation.

This suffix indicates that an action is occurring (or has occurred or will occur) in the vicinity of the noun to which it is attached.[1] It can typically be used only for physical locations.[2]

Some verbs have locative notions in their meanings, and care must be taken when using {-Daq:n:suff,nolink} with such verbs. See {ghoS:v:1} and {jaH:v} for more details. With verbs of shooting, such as {baH:v} and {bach:v}, {-Daq:n:suff,nolink} marks the target.

When a verb is used adjectivally, this suffix and the other type 5 noun suffixes are attached to the verb rather than the noun. (According to {TKD 4.4:src}, when a verb is used in this way, it can have no other suffix except for {-qu':v:suff}. However, this has been contradicted by subsequent canon, e.g., {SuvwI' quvHa':n:nolink} from {HQ 12.3:src} and {Duj ngaDHa':n} from {KGT:src}).
This suffix is used when the action is in a direction away from the noun to which it is attached.[1] It can typically be used only for physical locations.[2]

definition.sv: på grund av, beroende på (substantiv typ 5)

notes.en: There is a verb suffix {-mo':v} with the same meaning.

This suffix indicates the noun to which it is attached is the beneficiary of the action.

It is used to indicate the indirect object when the object is the recipient of the action. ({TKDA 6.8:src})

See {qawmoH:v} for an explanation of how this suffix is used with the verb suffix {-moH:v}.

This suffix emphasizes that the noun to which it is attached the topic of the sentence.[1] It is used with the pronouns to form "to be" constructions.[2] It is also used to disambiguate which noun is the head noun in a relative clause (see {-bogh:v}).

If the object noun is marked with {-'e':n:suff,nolink}, it can come before adverbials, which still precede the verb.[3]

To use {-'e':n:suff,nolink} on a series of nouns (i.e., nouns joined with one of {je:conj}, {joq:conj}, or {ghap:conj}), it must be attached to each noun individually.[4]  This can happen if there are multiple head nouns in a relative clause, or if the subject of a "to be" construction consists of multiple things.

In the Morskan dialect, this suffix is not used to mark the subject in "to be" constructions. If the suffix is used in such a sentence, it serves its usual function of emphasis.[5]

Do not confuse this suffix with the pronoun {'e':n:pro}.

-'e':n.hidden_notes:
The example from {TKD:src} contains an error: the {jI-:sen:nolink} prefix was omitted by mistake.[1]

In {HQ 4.2:src}, this suffix is also described as a focus marker.[4]

examples.en:
▶ {jIlujpu' jIH'e'.:sen:nolink} "I, and only I, have failed." or "It is I who has failed."[1]
▶ {pa'DajDaq ghaHtaH la''e'.:sen:nolink} "The commander is in his quarters."[2]
▶ {cheng'e' DaH Sam!:sen}[6]
▶ Paramount Pictures {malja' permey bIH:sen:nolink} Star Trek {pong'e' Deghmey'e' je.:sen:nolink}[7]

-'e':n.source: [1] {TKD 3.3.5:src}, [2] {TKD 6.3:src}, [3] {TKDA 6.7:src}, [4] {HQ 4.2, p.5-6, Jun. 1995:src}, [5] {KGT p.23:src}, [6] {Star Trek VI:src}, [7] {SkyBox cards:src}

notes.en: When this suffix is used, the verb prefix must indicate "no object".
This suffix is only used with plural subjects. When this suffix is used, the verb prefix must indicate "no object".
This suffix indicates that the subject needs to do the action.
This suffix indicates that the subject is willing to perform the action.
The verb {ghuS:v:0} never takes the suffix {-rup:v:suff,nolink}.

definition.en: ready, set up (referring to devices) (verb type 2)

examples.en: ▶ {HablI', Su' labbeH.:sen}

notes.en: It is culturally taboo to use this suffix with a first person subject.

-vIp:v.hidden_notes: The unstated exception to the rule is that it is not taboo if {-vIp:v:suff,nolink} is negated with {-be':v:suff}, as illustrated by the sentences on {TKD:src} p.49.

definition.en: change in state, change in direction (verb type 3)
definition.sv: förändring i tillstånd, förändring i riktning (verbtyp 3)
definition.ru: изменение в состоянии, изменение в направлении (глагол тип 3)

notes.en: This suffix indicates that the action described by the verb involves a change from the state of affairs as it existed before the action took place. The English translation of this suffix may be "become" or "begin to".
This suffix implies that the action had been taking place, then stopped, and then began again.
See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use this with a verb which takes an object.

This suffix indicates that the subject is unknown, indefinite, or general. It is used only with prefixes which normally indicate a third-person singular object ({vI-:v}, {Da-:v}, {wI-:v}, {bo-:v}, and {lu-:v}; and also {0:v:pref}). When used with this suffix, these prefixes change in meaning so that instead of indicating the person and number of the subject, they indicate the person and number of the object instead.

examples.en: ▶ {batlh Daqawlu'taH.:sen} "You will be remembered with honor."

notes.ru: мочь, быть способным (глагол тип 5)

notes.en:
When used with some verbs of fighting, this suffix implies that the fighting results in death (see {Suvchu':v}, {Hay'chu':v}).[2, p.49]

When used with {chuH:v:1}, it means the target is actually hit by the thrown spear.[2, p.64]

examples.en:
▶ {lolchu':v}
▶ {HeDchu':v}

notes.en: This suffix indicates that the speaker thinks the assertion is obvious to the listener.
This suffix expresses uncertainty on the speaker's part. It may be translated as "I think" or "I suspect".
This suffix indicates that an action is completed.

This suffix indicates that an action is completed, and the activity was deliberately undertaken.

There is a special verbal construction, {rIntaH:v}, which denotes a similar meaning, but has the further connotation of finality.
This suffix indicates that the action is ongoing.

examples.en:
▶ {Duj tIvoqtaH.:sen}
▶ {wo' DevtaHjaj ghawran}[2]

notes.en: This suffix indicates that the action is ongoing, and is proceeding towards a known goal or stopping point.

This suffix is used infrequently by Klingons. It usually expresses extreme politeness or deference, and is used only in addressing a superior.[1]

This suffix is also used with some verbs of fighting to indicate that the verb refers to a suicide attack. For example, {HIvneS} implies that suicide is part of the attack plan, and similarly, {HubneS} implies that suicide is part of the defense plan.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {jIlajneS.:sen}

definition.sv: då, när, så snart som, samtidigt som (verbtyp 9)

examples.en: ▶ {jIjatlhpa' jatlh Hovmey.:sen}

definition.ru: пока, в то время как (глагол тип 9)

notes.en: This is always used with the type 7 suffix {-taH:v}.
There is a noun suffix {-mo':n} with the same meaning.

definition.en: for, for the purpose of, in order to (verb type 9)

notes.en:
The purpose clause always precedes the noun or verb whose purpose it is describing.[1]

There is an article in {HQ 7.3:src} which examines {-meH:v:suff,nolink} clauses modifying nouns.[2]

This suffix expresses a desire or wish on the part of the speaker that something take place in the future.[1]

This suffix is attached to the verb in toasts, which always comes last except in the dialects of {Sa'Qej Sep:n} and {noHva'Dut Sep:n}.[2]

-jaj:v.hidden_notes: When this suffix is used, there is allegedly never a Type 7 aspect suffix.[1] However, this "rule" is contradicted by canon, as can be seen from the examples.

examples.en:
▶ {wo' ghawran DevtaHjaj.:sen@@wo':n, ghawran:n, Dev:v, -taH:v, -jaj:v} "May Gowron continue to lead the Empire" (as a toast)[2]
▶ {wo' DevtaHjaj ghawran.:sen@@wo':n, Dev:v, -taH:v, -jaj:v, ghawran:n} "May Gowron continue to lead the Empire" (not as a toast)[2]

definition.en: one who does/is, thing which does/is (verb type 9)
definition.sv: en som gör, sak som gör, en som är (verbtyp 9)
definition.ru: тот, кто делает /то, которое делает (глагол тип 9)

notes.en: This suffix is not generally used on a verb without another suffix, or on one with a prefix. When it is attached to a stative verb, it gives a meaning like "-ness", while on an active verb it means something like "-tion".[2]

examples.en:
▶ {lo'laHghach} "value"[1]
▶ {lo'laHbe'ghach} "worthlessness"[1]
▶ {naDHa'ghach} "discommendation"[1]
▶ {naDqa'ghach} "re-commendation"[1]
▶ {tlhutlhtaHghach} "ongoing drinking", "the process of continuing to drink"[2]

notes.en: This follows the concept it negates. It cannot be used to form negative imperatives, i.e., it cannot be used to mean "don't" (for which use {-Qo':v} instead)[1; 3]. However, a command such as {HIleghbe'moH:sen:nolink} is possible.[3] This suffix can be applied to verbs used as adjectives.[2]

examples.en: ▶ {wa'maH yIHmey lI'be'@@wa'maH:n, yIH:n, -mey:n, lI':v:1, -be':v} "ten useless tribbles"[2]

notes.en: This suffix is used to denote refusal. It is also used in imperatives. It always occurs last, unless followed by a type 9 suffix.

This suffix indicates that something that was previously done is now undone, or that something is done wrongly. Despite being classified as a rover, this suffix occurs immediately after the verb, before any other suffixes.[1]

This suffix can be applied to some adverbials, but not to all of them.[2; 3] The expression {Duj ngaDHa':n} shows that it can also be applied to verbs used as adjectives.[4]

examples.en: ▶ {Duj ngaDHa':n} [4]

notes.en:
This suffix emphasizes whatever immediately precedes it.

It can follow verbs used adjectivally, in which case it means "very".

Qugh la'vaD QIn pav.:sen.hidden_notes: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

definition.en: The Federation controls the Genesis Device.

qa'vam jan SeH DIvI'.:sen.hidden_notes: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

qa'vam yuQ Quv DaghojmeH Duyma'vaD yIjat.entry_name: qa'vam yuQ Quv DaghojmeH Duyma'vaD yIjatlh.

definition.en: To learn the Genesis Planet's coordinates, speak to our agent.
definition.de: Um die Koordinaten des Genesis-Planeten zu lernen, sprich unseren Agenten an.

qa'vam yuQ Quv DaghojmeH Duyma'vaD yIjat.hidden_notes: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

qa'vam jan yISuq.:sen.hidden_notes: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

potlhbe' to'.:sen.hidden_notes: This appears on the back of the DVD case, but not in the movie itself.

notes.en: This was the name of a documentary on the {Star Trek V Special Edition:src} second disc, in which Spice Williams ({vIqSIS:n:name}) and Todd Bryant ({tlha'a:n:name}) are interviewed about their experiences working on the movie.

tlhIngan chang'engvetlh:sen.source: [1] {Star Trek V Special Edition - That Klingon Couple:src}

toH, SomrawDu' Dunqu'!:sen.hidden_notes: The subtitle actually said {Somraw'Du':sen:nolink}, but this is a typo.
toH, SomrawDu' Dunqu'!:sen.source: [1] {Star Trek V Special Edition - That Klingon Couple:src}

notes.en:
This is the {HoD:n} of a starship named {'entepray':n:name}.

In Klingon, titles generally go after the name.

'archer HoD:n.hidden_notes: The name {'archer:n:name,nolink} has been heard spoken in Klingon, but has not appeared in written canon.

definition.en: Captain Archer and his crew are honorable people.
definition.de: Captain Archer und seine Crew sind ehrenwerte Leute.

definition.en: Let them continue on their way.
I have nothing to say to you, human.
definition.de: Ich habe dir nichts zu sagen, Mensch.

definition.en: I demand to see the magistrate!
definition.de: Ich verlange den Verwalter zu sehen!

definition.en: What do you want with me?

notes.en:
This literally means "Why do you (plural) want me?"

To address a single person, say {qatlh choneH?:sen@@qatlh:ques, cho-:v, neH:v}
This can also mean "Secure her!" or "Secure it!"

definition.de: Ziele die Waffen auf diesen Ort.

notes.en: This literally means "aim weapons on this section".

definition.de: Gehen Sie zurück zu den Transportkoordinaten.

ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh.entry_name: ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh pa' DaqHomvetlh wovDaq HInej.

definition.en: Then Kahless pointed to a star in the sky and said, "Look for me there, on that point of light."
definition.de: Dann zeigte Kahless auf einen Stern am Himmel und sagte: "Bringe mich an diesen hellen Ort hier oben."

notes.en: This is part of the Story of the Promise, which tells of the departure (and prophesies the return) of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.

ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh.hidden_notes:
The Klingon text comes from an inscription seen on one of the {DSC:src} trailers, while the English translation is from {TNG - Rightful Heir:src}.

Set photos show that this sentence is preceded by {Suto'vo'qor vIjaH 'ach 'opleS jIchegh 'e' vIlay'.:sen@@Suto'vo'qor:n, vI-:v, jaH:v, 'ach:conj, 'opleS:n, jI-:v, chegh:v, 'e':n, vI-:v, lay':v}

ghoSlI' chaH.:sen.hidden_notes: The Klingon translation was done by {Qov:n:name}. The English comes from the subtitles, with punctuation edited for clarity.

notes.en: This literally means "We are Klingon, may it continue". The English subtitles render this as "Remain Klingon!"

tlhIngan maH! taHjaj!:sen.hidden_notes:
The line was deliberately translated this way as it was believed that audiences would recognise the embedded {tlhIngan maH!:sen}

This can also be interpreted as {tlhIngan maHtaHjaj!:sen@@tlhIngan:n, maH:n:1h, -taH:v, -jaj:v}, "May we continue to be Klingon". This technically violates the rule that a Type 7 suffix cannot be used with {-jaj:v:nolink} (see {TKD 4.2.9:src}), but this rule has been violated in canon.

notes.en: According to the glossary to {Honor Bound:src}, this is an animal native to {bo'retlh:n}, which makes bleating sounds and tends to run around in circles.
This is the name of a female in the Duolingo Klingon course.
This is the name of Captain Lorca's previous ship.
This term doesn't appear in canon, but rather was invented for a blog post about science. It's here so that someone else doesn't invent a different term.

chalqut ngat:n.hidden_notes: This term was coined by Felix Malmenbeck ({loghaD:n:nolink}), and roughly means "sky-crystal gunpowder".

notes.en: The element {chem:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {ghe'chem:n}, {HoSchem:n}, {peQchem:n}, {pIvchem:n}, {Surchem:n}, and {tlhamchem:n}.

chem:n.hidden_notes: In {TKDA:src}, {peQ chem:n:nolink} actually appears as two words (with a space).

notes.en: This was carried out by {mo'qay tuq:n} on {voq:n}, to transform him into Lt. Ash Tyler.

choH'a':n.source: {DSC - The War Without, The War Within:src}

notes.en: This word does not appear in canon. However, it follows the pattern of the other {tay:n:2} words, and is included here for reference.
This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {bo'DIj:n} and {ghIpDIj:v}. Its homophony to {DIj:v:1} suggests that it describes two parties pitted against one another.
According to {TKD p.20:src}, it's likely that {Do':n:archaic,hyp,nolink} is an archaic word for the modern {Duj:n:1}. This conjecture is supported by {'ejDo':n} and {Delaq Do':excl}.
This element is not known to exist as a word, but appears as a component of {nenghep:n} and {peHghep:n}.
These are creatures bred by Klingons specifically to eat tribbles.[1]

ghIlo'meH:n.source: [1] {TAS - More Tribbles, More Troubles:src}, [2] {How to Speak Klingon, p.4:src}

notes.en: This is described in the glossary to {A Burning House:src} as a game involving tokens and wagers.

definition.en: trusted adviser of a Klingon house

notes.en: In {TNG - Firstborn:src}, K'mtar is the gin'tak to the House of Mogh.[1] In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, it is claimed that this word and {ghIntaq:n:1} are in fact the same word.[2]
This is one of the items traditionally displayed on a {nuH bey':n}. It is a gutting device used in balance with a shield.[1]

ghob'etlh:n.hidden_notes: The spelling of this word is not confirmed, and it is only spoken in {KCD:src}. It may be {Qob'etlh:n:nolink} or {ghab'etlh:n:nolink} instead.

notes.en: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a vegetable usually served diced.
The element {ghor:n:hyp,nolink} is not known to appear by itself, but is found in the words {pIvghor:n} and {Hongghor:n}.
This is a name used in the Duolingo Klingon course.
This is a type of stone indigenous to {Qo'noS:n} which is often used in the contruction of statuary.
notes.de: Dies ist eine auf {Qo'noS:n} vorkommende Steinart, die häufig durch Bildhauer verwendet wird.

notes.en: In the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is described as a fruit grown on Klingon farms.
